T.C.
Homonym Number:
Word Class: abbreviation
Sense Number:
Definition: (Teachers) Training College
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1953
Source:  Unorganized Games
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  1/404
Edition:
Quote:  The most widely known game with insects is a game named variously by T.C. students as Butcher Boys (Gisborne, New Plymouth, Kaponga, [405] Te Pohu, Newall, Sth. Wellington), Butcher Bats (Ohau, Takaka), Penny Doctor Beetles (Tauranga, Pipiriki, Rotorua), or Fishing (Morunui). It is a game in which straws which have been suitably moistened with spittle are placed in an insects [sic] hole and are flicked out when the insect bites the end of the straw. Most of the reports of this practice come from the North Island, though it was known in the South as early as 1900 (Waikouaiti).

Date:  0/0/1954
Source:  Take My Tip
Author:  JOURNET
Vol / Page:  71
Edition:
Quote:  The T.A.B. shop is the easiest thing in the world to use. Its straightforwardness is startling. There is no attempt to mesmerise you with jingling bells or fabulous dividends and no nonsense about weights or jockeys. ... Many patrons cannot accept this simplicity and try to complicate things for themselves by examining the charts on the T.A.B. shop walls. These are cyclostyled sheets of paper giving the name of every horse running that day together with an appropriate number by the name.
Notes:

table
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1876
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  8/177
Edition:
Quote:  The constant outflow of crushed quartz and water from the stamp boxes is received on a table, having on it grooves or ripples, containing quicksilver and a large extent of amalgamated copper plates smoothly nailed on. This may be called the silver table; ... The flow then passes over blanket tables, which arrest mechanically all the heavier particles. <i>Ibid.</I> 179 The blanket tailings or blanketings, as they are otherwise called, consist mostly of iron pyrites and other sulphides, cobines with quartz, and contain a fair proportion of gold ...that had escaped over the silver tables. These tailings are treated in berdans with extra quicksilver and ground up. The berdans now in use at the Thames ... are generally five feet in diameter ... At one time a couple of rotating balls were considered sufficient for the amount of crushing required; now, the general practice is to have a loose ball as well as a stationary one attached to a chain, and it is called a drag ball; this drag does more work than a loose ball ... for the drag grinds the bowl as much as the tailings.


Notes:  (Goodall Thames Gold-fields)

Date:  0/0/1868
Source:  Thames Miner's Guide, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  93
Edition:
Quote:  The battery has three stampers in each box, double cams, quickslver placed in battery boxes, grating perpendicular, with round holes. The copper-plate tables are about 12ft. long by 5ft. wide, and raised about 14in. above the blanket boards; ... [The blankets] appear to be ordinary grey blankets of a very inferior description.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1896
Source:  Adventures by Sea and Land
Author:  MOFFATT
Vol / Page:  70
Edition:  1970
Quote:  Yet still they dig and delve, be the weather foul or fair, / And talk of plush and tables, and a thousand pounds a share.
Notes:  [a1882] 1896 Moffatt Adventures (1979) 70 [Walter D. Moffatt, d. 3.1.1882: poem]

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  G'day Country
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  32
Edition:
Quote:  Inside the station they had the big red metal boxes that work the old-fashioned tablet signalling system. If you ever wonder what drivers are picking up or unloading on the end of a curved piece of wood, it is the tablet or biscuit. A train cannot get through a section of rail without the biscuit matching the one in the red metal box, which is connected to the manually operated signals. Automatic signals are phasing this system in to rural museums.

Sense Number:
Definition: typical Army ball(s)-up
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:

Notes: (cf NABU, SABU, P: TCCFU: typical coastal command fuck up; ca1941-44 TABU: Army: mostly officers': N. Africa: 1940-45
Citations
Date:  0/0/1944
Source:  Troop Target
Author:  FULLARTON
Vol / Page:  38
Edition:
Quote:  There are three words in the Middle East soldiers' vocabulary describing the normal maladministration of an army. A tabu, an acrostic word, is `typical Army ball-up', a Sabu is self-adjusting ball-up, while a Nabu is a non-adjustable ball-up. <i>Ibid.</I> 207 <i>Tabus</i> had dwindled to a minimum.

taewa
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also tiver
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  28/8/2003
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  C7
Edition:
Quote:  The indigenous Maori potato Taewa could be a hot new gourmet food on menus, thanks to trials now under way at seven sites around New Zealand... At their best, Taewa are a flavoursome root vegetable in colours ranging from purples to reds and yellows, which are traditionally boiled or steamed... [The research] builds on a number of other research projects already carried out into Taewa, which have helped identify four cultivars... These are called Tutaekuri, Kowiniwiri aka Karuparera, Moemoe and Huakaroro.
Notes:

Date:  18/5/1999
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  [Hdg] Maori spud seen to be money spinner. Taewa - the Maori potato - which has an important place in Maori culture, could be a money-spinner... The urenika  variety, with its bright purple flesh and skin, and the kowiniwini, with its purple and cream skin, would look a treat on any restaurant table.... It was probable the taewa arrived by ship in the mid to late 18th century and had become established by the time of the major settlement about 1840... Northland's Ngati Hine people have identified the Maori varieties karoro, peruperu, uwhiwhero, kowiniwini and urenika as possible pre-European varities.


Notes:

Date:  18/9/2003
Source:  Dominion Post

Taewa have been grown in New Zealand for centuries, forming the basis of the market garden industry established in the 1800s to supply early European settlers.

In July a hui was held for marae groups who now grow taewa semi-commercially, feeding their families and selling the surplus... There are more than a dozen varieties of taewa, some purple-skinned, others with mellow yellow flesh.

Complaints regarding inferior grade of "tagged" potatoes are investigated by a committee of the association, the association having authority to deprive offenders of benefits and even membership in the case of deliberate faulty packing .. to establish confidence on the part of purchasers in respect to the quality of "tagged" potatoes, and incidentally to command for their produce a premium over other potatoes.

The wise chief knew that to slay the pakeha would be to cut off the supply of European products, hence the red blanket saved Wellington.

Date:  0/0/1834
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  MARKHAM
Vol / Page:  43
Edition:  1963
Quote:  We returned the seven miles but found the Tide, ti Puddie <i>[tai pari]</i> or Ebb Tide, had made so that the Boat would not float, so we staid that night. So we Cooked our Pork and Potatoes, drank my Grog and took a Stroll. [fn] The Maori phrase literally means flowing tide.
Notes:

tai timu
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: with TAI PARI perhaps indicative of the change in time and place of Pakeha vernacular knowledge of Maori Williams 361 Tai (i) ... Sea.: timu `ebb(ing)' (he tai timu<I> `low water'); pari</I> `flowing (of the tide)'.  Both were intelligible to many English speakers up to at least the 1930s, and possibly the 1950s in the North Island, as witness the following joke first heard by me as a child in Havelock (South Island) possibly from an original King Country version; and first mentioned as early as 1845 by Walter Brodie in <i>The State of New Zealand </i>where it is attributed to Mr [?initial] Williams.

Tim and Paddy were walking along the beach when they came across two Maoris arguing, as it semed to them, ferociously. One was crying out `Tie Tim!' and the other, `Tie Paddy!'. Paddy took to his heels shouting: `You can bloody well tie Tim if you like, but I'm damned if you'll tie Paddy!' Enjoyment of the joke depends not only on knowing the meaning of the Maori forms, but also on a non-Maori perception of Maori /r/ as [d], and failure to hear a devocalised /u/ final. In 1986 it is usually necessary to `prepare' the joke with tedious explanation.


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1840
Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/170
Edition:
Quote:  The timber-dealer in conducting his raft down the river at flood tide (<i>tai parre</i>[e-acute],) drops an anchor, (a heavy piece of wood or bag of stones) at the end of the flood

(<i>tai pakoa</i>[a1-acute]) in deep water, that he may be enabled to pursue his route at the finish of the ebb (<i>tai timu</i>.)


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1935
Source:  Hero Stories of NZ
Author:  COWAN
Vol / Page:  58
Edition:
Quote:  The <i>taiaha</i>, the most shapely and effective wooden weapon of the Maori, is a kind of two-handed sword, with the added advantage that both ends can be used, the tongue-shaped point as well as the broad blade.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/149
Edition:
Quote:  <i>taiaha</i>, weapon of hard brown wood, up to six feet long or more, with tongue-like point and slightly-broadening balde for thrust and stroke, the tongue proceeding as if from a carved mouth, with [150] paua eyes inserted for realism: used somewhat in the manner of a quarter-staff: often adorned below the head with a plaited flax band with red kaka-feathers were ominous of victory or defeat; victory if they glowed when the protecting cover was removed, defeat if they looked dead and dull: a weapon prized as highly by the owner or collector as the mere, and much used by chiefs in oratory as well as in war.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.
Author:
Vol / Page:  175

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Evil Day
Author:  BRATHWAITE
Vol / Page:  381
Edition:
Quote:  TAIAHA A weapon, superficially like a broad-hafted spear, but actually a broadsword. It is made of hardwood, with the `point' of the blade rounded, the edges sharp, and a carved, pointed tongue where the hilt would be on European broadsword. It is wielded in a manner that has something of the two-handed sword, the quarterstaff and the modern rifle-and-bayonet combination. The carved tongue is decorated where it joins the blade, with a collar of dog-hair.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1968
Source:  Landfall
Author:
Vol / Page:  221/359
Edition:
Quote:

Quote:  The Fisheries Minister has agreed in principle to a proposed taiapure (local fishery) in the waters surrounding Te Wakatehaua Island (the Bluff), Ninety-Mile Beach. Taiapure (local fisheries) can be established in areas of special significance to an iwi or hapu as a source of food or for spiritual or cultural reasons.

Homonym Number:

Vol / Page:  10

Quote:  A spot was selected in front of the house and with native assistance a `Tieupha' [i-acute][Taiepa] fence was soon completed. This is made of stout sticks six feet high stuck in the ground perpendicularly and tied round in two or three places with rods and a tough creeper (clematis) more durable than any cord.

taigook
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: possibly ta[a]huka Williams 361 I>Ta[a]huka ... </I>A cloak resembling a <I>korowai</I>, but without <I>hukahuka</I>.: [fringes or thrums on a cape]
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  4/6/1773
Source:  Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author:  FORSTER
Vol / Page:  2/291
Edition:
Quote:  [The chief] was covered with a black <i>Taigook</i> [a-macron, o1-grave], a Mat for cloathing, it was close woven, very strong & of a fine jett black & here and there patched with white Dogskin. [ed. fn] This word is omitted by George: possible [sic] it was <I>tieke</I>[e-macron], a black flax cloak or <I>topuni</I>[o-macron] (<I>topaki</I>[o-macron], a black dogskin cloak. George describes it as `a perfect black cloak of the close-wrought kind,

patched in compartments with dog-skin', <I>Voyage</I>, I, 223.
Notes:

Notes:

taihoa
Homonym Number:
Word Class: exclamation
Sense Number:
Definition: wait-a-bit! hold on!
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: also taiho, tao hoor, tie-ho, taisho, et al ca1890-1910 P.S. Ardern Used as an exclamation `wait a bit!' in Auckland colloquial;  Anglicised pron. usually [tai|hou] (occas. esp. in Northland, [|tai ou]) or [tai|hou ]: R. Mason notes [taihou] heard in Christchurch in the 1950s; [taihou] heard in Northland only
Citations
Date:  5/1/1912
Source:  Marlborough Express
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  "Taihoa" does not mean careful

consideration, prudent and wise

advancement, careful deliberation,

putting on the brake, chewing things

over, although it may be used for these

reasons.  English-ised, this word

corresponds to our own adverb 'by-and-

by'- postponing indefinitely for any

reason or for no reason at all what may

be said or done at once.  It has always

meant this and can never mean anything

else, whether applied to the occasional

or habitual procrastinations of a pakeha,Maori chief, or honourable

Parliamentarian grievously pestered by

urgent petitions of insatiate

constitutents.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1905
Source:  Bush Boys of NZ
Author:  THOMSON
Vol / Page:  170
Edition:
Quote:  "Taisho, Mac." [Note : the bush-boy corruption of the Maori "Taihoa, " "Wait a bit."

Date:  0/0/1842
Source:  Journey in NZ
Author:  WADE
Vol / Page:  66
Edition:
Quote:  <i> `Taihoa'</i>. This word has been translated, By and by; but in truth it has all the latitude of directly, - presently, - by and by, - a long time hence, - and nobody knows when ... the deliberate reply is, `Taihoa' ... this patience-trying word.
Notes:  [repub. in 1895 NZ Reader 124]

Notes:  1878 Mar Mrs Grace Journal in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 302



Date:  0/0/1881
Source:  Poenamo
Author:  CAMPBELL
Vol / Page:  87
Edition:
Quote:  That irritatingly provoking word, `taihoa' ... [88] The drawled out t-a-i-h-o-a fell upon the ear. ... [271] Great is the power of taihoa. ... [276] The imperturbable taihoa, given to us with the ordinary placid good humour. <i>Ibid.</I> Bk2/5/87 We had intended to make an early start in the morning ... but whoever has had to do with Tongata Maori well knows how one's temper is tried by that irritatingly provoking word `taihoa'. [fn] By-and-by. <i>Ibid.</i> Bk4/4/268-269 <i>`Taihoa, taihoa, taihoa',</i> was ever the answer, /drawled out in the most inimitable and imperturbably good-humoured voice, each <i>taihoa</i> longer than the one before. <i>Ibid.</I> Bk4/4/269 In vain my protestations. <i>`Taihoa, taihoa,</i> all in good time - what's the hurry, O Pakeha!' time was made for slaves - hurry no man's cattle, as we in the classics say. `What's the odds, a day or two sooner or later? There's Motu-Korea; it won't run away - <i>taihoa nei?' </i>with a chuck back of the head as they ended with the interrogative.
Notes:

Date:  6/1/1892
Source:  Chudleigh Diary
Author:
Vol / Page:  378
Edition:
Quote:  Found Captain Romeril[????] telling the natives my extension leases were no good. Stirring up the natives to injure us. Tai hoa Captain. Most of the men and all the women at fude[????]. Waitangi is the home of evil.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1905
Source:  Where the White Man Treads
Author:  BAUCKE
Vol / Page:  261
Edition:
Quote:  By taking the native lad into [sic] and treating him as a home apprentice he will imbide the charms which embellish ... the orderly pakeha's home life; ... assuredly it is worthier ... than ... the insolent cry of : `Come, bestir yourselves, there has been too much taihoa.' <i>Ibid.</I> 272 Month after month 52 children are contemptuously told `taihoa; these things take time.' <i>Ibid.</I> 283 To attain [a better life] unaided is a dream of the expert at experiments, the foolish crier of `Bestir yourselves, there has been too much taihoa.'

Notes:

taihoa
Homonym Number:
Word Class: exclamation
Sense Number:
Definition: wait on!


Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Anglicised pron. usually [tai|hou] (occas. esp. in Northland, [|tai ou]) or [tai|hou ]: R. Mason notes [taihou] heard in Christchurch in the 1950s; [taihou] heard in Northland only

Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: delay, procrastination
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1910
Source:  Hone Tiki Dialogues
Author:  GRACE
Vol / Page:  4

taihoa
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: Cassytha paniculata, a Northland creeping plant parasitic on (or associated with) the tea-tree: a back-translation from WAIT-A-WHILE


Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Environment
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  Matthews of Kaitaia
Author:  MATTHEWS
Vol / Page:  17
Edition:
Quote:  This was his first introduction to the New Zealand bush but, though interested, he had little time for observation of nature, being hard put to it to keep the pace set by his guide. There was no path, part of the way was very steep, and the thorny vines of the `bush lawyer' or, as Pene called it, <i>Taihoa</i> (Wait-a-bit) made travelling difficult.

Vol / Page:  Bk2/5/88
Edition:

I knew I was not starting on a wild-goose chase without a certainty of being able to get back to the island within a given time - always making due allowance for Maori <i>taihoa</i>-ism.  <I>iIbid.</I> Bk4/5/277 ... we began to have misgivings that the very potatoes we had planted might, by the virtue of

taihoaism, be ready to dig before the dining-room was finished in which we hoped to have eaten them.

Edition:
Quote:  Suppose a piece of timber - a flitch nine inches by twenty-four and sixteen feet long - is on the carriage, and that we intend cutting nine by three-quarter boards. After taking off a `face' cut, setting the gauger rollers, and placing the flitch in position, the man at the head starts the machinery. `Kreash,' says the saw. and in twelve seconds she is out at the other end. The man at the `tail' at that instant reverses the motion of the table, which gigs back.

Quote:  <i>Tail</i>.- (1) The t. of a mob is the last part of it; hence the weakest and worst sheep. (2) To keep sheep or cattle together in a mob allowing them to move ahead slowly as they feed. (Homebush Station diary, February 24 185(2)) 3. To cut the t. off a lamb. Euphemism for

<i>cut and t. </i>([1898 Morris Austral-English], which quotes 2 as used in 1855; C)

tail sample
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
Author:  Mc ARA
Vol / Page:  334
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Tail samples</i>: Regular samples of the tailings were taken to check that maximum recovery of precious minerals was being obtained. The values contained in the tailings did not usually exceed half a pennyweight of gold per ton of ore, except in the concentrate tailing, which it was uneconomic to grind to the degree of fineness required to recover the last six pennyweights (0.3 oz) per ton. Overall recovery was usually over 90% of the values.
Notes:

tailender
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:  a bad doer or low producing farm animal or a lamb or calf born late in the lambing/calving season.

Notes:

tailing
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: 1. the removing of lambs' tails with knife, searing iron or runner ring. [Used loosely to include ear-marking and castration of male lambs at the same time and used mainly in the South Island.] 2. the quiet following of stock as they graze while being driven.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See: docking
Pronunciation:
Notes: docking		two senses in one entry here

Quote:  Without moving his feet, he leaned down to his right and pulled a long-handled tailing-iron from the perforated oil drum that served as a brazier.

tailings
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the waste material removed during the processing of mineral ores
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (cf TAIL v)

Quote:  We saw on Monday four ounces of very fine gold, the result of the labour of six men in five days, who had washed the tailings left by the diggers three years and a-half ago.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1876
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  8/179
Edition:
Quote:  The blanket tailings or blanketings, as they are otherwise called, consist mostly of iron pyrites and other sulphides, cobines with quartz, and contain a fair proportion of gold ...that had escaped over the silver tables. These tailings are treated in berdans with extra quicksilver and ground up. The berdans now in use at the Thames ... are generally five feet in diameter ... At one time a couple of rotating balls were considered sufficient for the amount of crushing required; now, the general practice is to have a loose ball as well as a stationary one attached to a chain, and it is called a drag ball; this drag does more work than a loose ball ... for the drag grinds the bowl as much as the tailings.
Notes:  Goodall Thames Gold-fields

Date:  0/0/1935
Source:  Gold Mining Year Book
Author:  BLYTH
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Tailings</i>: Useless material discarded after most of the metal has been extracted by treatment plants.

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Tang of The Bush
Author:  KEENE1967
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  When we were about Waipiata, and pushing up to Hamilton's station Ethel became very excited, and exclaimed, `The Tailings!' We were pushing through heavy gravel at the time. I looked about for a heap of lambs tails, the only kind of `tailings' I knew. The language of gold mining was unknown to me, and Ethel had to explain that tailings were the heaps of gravel left after the soil had been sluiced away.
Notes:  (Robert McLatchie 1875-1963)

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
Author:  McARA
Vol / Page:  334
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Tailings</I>: The discarded portion of the ore after treatment, usually seen on the banks of the Ohinemuri River as fine, whitish, quartz sand or as muddy water in the river. The Ohinemuri River was an officially-declared sludge channel for tailings disposal.

Author:  HAAST
Vol / Page:  50
Edition:
Quote:  On the 11th of June we started from the cave, called by the natives Te-ana-o Matuku, respecting which they tell a very interesting tale of a large ngarara, a monster in the form of an enormous lizard, which formerly lived here, and devoured all who attempted to pass. Since they have become Christians, however, they have called it by another name, Te whare Taipo (the Devil's house), probably referring the formation of the cave, of which I shall speak more fully in the geological part of my report, to supernatural agency rather than to the hand of nature.

Notes:

taipo
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 5
Definition: usually from the primary Maori sense `devil; ghost' figuratively used, or transferred to `a fearsome person or thing' (e.g., a weta); thence in various weakened uses, as a nickname (possibly an `Old Nick' name) mainly for animals, in familiar address to (usually naughty) children pron [|taipou] spg occasionally typo

Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:   On the West Coast of the South Island, `taipo', or what is supposed to be the English translation of that word, `bush devil', is the name generally given to the common tree weta, Hemideina megacephala. `Weta' is the real Maori name for this and related species of large, long-horned wingless grasshoppers; `taipo' is a word of unknown origin and obscure meaning.

taipo
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a) evil spirit; devil. b) in weakened use, of a naughty child: `you little taipo'. [probable Maori taipo goblin] Maori <i>taipo</i>, goblin
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: HWO notes:8 not in Williams 3rd edn 1871, 4th edn of 1892 (or as taepo); nor in English-Maori of 1871 at goblin, etc; 1892 English-Maori: 269 <i>Goblin</i>, n. <i>tupua;</i> kehua.<i>First appears in 1917 5th edn </i>could <i>taipo</i> have been generated in English hearers by a mishearing of<i> tipua</i>, tupua `goblin, demon' etc - of same meaning.

Date:  0/0/1896
Source:  Letter
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Taipo</I>, for instance, of course one knows its meaning, though it has been adopted chiefly as a name as common as `Dash' or `Nero' for New Zealand dogs; all the same the writers upon Maori superstitions seem to have no knowledge of it. Polach [sic], Dieffenbach, Nicholas, Yates, call their evil spirits <I>whiros</I> or <I>atuas</I>. Tepo, the place of darkness, is the nearest they have come to it. I think myself it is South Island Maori, often differing a little in spelling and use; and so very much the larger proportion of New Zealand literature is the literature of the North.'
Notes:  1896. Modern. Private Letter (May): [Morris]

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  454
Edition:
Quote:  a New Zealand word for devil, often applied by settlers to a vicious horse or as a name for a dog. There is a dangerous river, the Taipo, on the west coast. There is considerable dispute as to whether the word is true Maori or not. The Rev. T. G. Hammond of Patea says -

-->`No such Maori word as taipo, meaning devil, exists. It would mean evening-tide - tai-po. Probably the early sailors introduced attached meaning of devil from the Maori saying, `Are you not afraid to travel at night?' referring to the danger of tidal rivers.' -->On the hand, Mr. Tregear says, in his `Maori Comparative Dictionary,' s.v. - -->`Taepo, a goblin, a spectre. C.f. <I>tae</I>, to arrive; <I>po</I>, night.' The Rev. W. Colenso says, in his pamphlet on `Nomenclature' (1883), p. 5 - -->`Taepo means to visit or come by night, - a night visitant, - a spectral thing seen in dreams, - a fancied and feared thing, or hobgoblin, of the night or darkness; and this the settlers have construed to mean the Devil! - and of course their own orthodox one.'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1930
Source:  Reminiscences
Author:  DOBSON
Vol / Page:  95
Edition:
Quote:  `Tae-po, the evil spirit, now comes. He comes in the form of a little pig. He often comes like that. ...' Terapuhi was still shaking with fear, but gradually he recovered and said, `Tae-po does sometimes come like that, and not do any harm, but I told you this is a bad place.' <I>Ibid.</I>96 Tae-po, an evil spirit, from the verb <I>tae</I>, to arrive, and <I>po</I>, night or darkness. An evil nocturnal visitor, incorrectly (as a rule), put as one word, Taipo, which is of course meaningless.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1937
Source:  Thomas
Author:  AYSON
Vol / Page:  53
Edition:
Quote:  That evening the boys held the floor, telling all sorts of Maori stories about Taipo.

Date:  0/0/1937
Source:  Dictionary of Slang
Author:  PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page:  861
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Taipo.</i> occ.<i> taepo.</i> A vicious horse; as name for a dog: New Zealand coll.: mid-C. 19-20. Perhaps ex Maori: but see Morris. -2. Among Maoris, a s. term for a theodolite, `because it is the `land-stealing devil' (Morris). Ex <i>taepo</i>, Maori for a goblin.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1939
Source:  First White Boy Born in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  <I>mangumangu taipo </I>If she [a Maori woman] stayed on till dark she was frightened to go home alone as she was afraid of the `taipo' ... <I>Ibid.</i>20 (as a nickname c1850s-1860s) We did not get very far with our Maori, but I used to go to Maori services with Taipo (Joe Benson) and picked up quite a lot of it.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1943
Source:  English as it is spoken in NZ
Author:  BENNETT
Vol / Page:  93
Edition:
Quote:  ... <I>taipo</I>, devil (from Maori <I>taepo</I> - if indeed this word was
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/150
Edition:
Quote:  <I>taipo,</I> supernatural being; goblin: used by the Maori believing it to be Pakeha, and by the Pakeha believing it to be Maori; often spelt taepo, which also is not a Maori word: so taipo is a word coined by no one knows whom... <I>taipo</I>, see the remarks following the word in list 2. There is a Maori remark that may be quoted here: Haere ra! E tama E! Mou te tai ata, moku te tai po (Farewell! O son! lit. Yours the morning tide, mine the evening tide, meaning You pass with the morning tide, as I will pass by the evening tide). The saying was often used in war, when a man saw a young relative or friend slain; and the words were often prophetic of his own fate. The meaning is quite destroyed if the last two words are run together - taipo instead of tai po: that results in the word under discussion, making the meaning: You pass on the morning tide, while I go to the devil! - naturally a modern interpretation. A Pakeha using the expression once confused that last words and made them taepa; when it meant: You pass on the morning tide, while I get over the fence. So near is the approach of the ridiculous to the sublime.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.
Author:
Vol / Page:  175
Edition:
Quote:  <I>taipo</I>: devil

Notes:

Date:  5/6/1840
Source:  Journal
Author:  JAMES WATKINS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The inhabitants of this Island [sc. southern South Island] in common with some savages are very superstitious, their faith in the power of their priests is slavish, and all sickness is ascribed to supernatural or perhaps infernal agency. Taipo being the supposed author of the disease whatever it may be. Taipo is a foreign word, its native place and etymology I cannot trace, but as it appears to mean the Devil and is of universal use I shall not disturb it.
Notes:  1840 June 5 James Watkins Journal in 1913 McNab O[ed fn 96: cites Watkin Journal 1840 June 5 QMS ATL; and Beattie's being told by aged Maori friends that it was `a whaler's word' (typhoid); Colenso Best JPS v30, 1921 p.48; Tregear]

taipo
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: [Ma.] 1. a saddle horse that is recalcitrant or badtempered, from the Maori ''devil.'' 2. an intimidating  natural feature such as a river. 3. a native weta found in caves and native bush. 4. a jagged hill of many near to the Wairarapa coast at Te Wharau and near Tinui.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Edition:
Quote:  <I>My first note refers to the</I> Notornis mantelli, <I>the rara avis</I> called by the Maoris the <I>`takahea'.</I> The name of this bird is spelled <I>`takahe'</I> in Buller's `Birds' ... The Maoris inform me that this is wrong; there should be a final <I>a,</I> as I have spelt it here.

and rare species of rail. = <I>moho.</I>

Quote:  &#65279;I'm going to..

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1944
Source:  Little Ships: NZ's Yachting Fleet
Author:  CARTER
Vol / Page:  127
Edition:
Quote:  Next to the X class. is the Z class, or

what are often referred to as the

Cornwall Cup boats. They owe their

existence to a small band of Takapuna

yachtsmen who planned the first boat,

with much the same idea in their minds as

did George Honour when he built the first

of the 14-foot square bilge boats,

namely, low first cost, ease of

construction, and an ever-watchful eye on

speed and performance under Auckland

harbour weather conditions.  The yachts

were originally designed for the Takapuna

Boating Club but owing to their

popularity from the outset the type was

quickly adopted by many other yacht clubs

throughout New Zealand... From small

beginnings the Takapuna one-design  class

rapidly expanded.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Little Ships of NZ
Author:  TITCHENER
Vol / Page:  64
Edition:
Quote:  A good example.. was the design of the

famous but ill-fated Z-class, which

became known as the Takapuna class

throughout New Zealand.


Notes:  [Specifications - 3.8 m yacht, designed by R B Brown of Northcote. 1.5m beam,m square chine vee-bottom principle. The whole of the sailing area carried on a gunter mainsail, on a short mast forward, no bowsprit or headsail]



Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  Kohimarama
Author:  DAVIS
Vol / Page:  113
Edition:
Quote:  The Z class, or "Zeddie" as it was

affectionately known, was another class

which was designed as a low cost sailing

boat to get the boys into something safer

than the tin canoes or derelict dinghies

in which they cruised Shoal Bay. Ibid.

114 The Takapuna Boating Club which was

then situated at Bayswater, was the

sponsoring club and the yachts were often

referred to as the "Takapuna Class".

Takapunas and come about the weather

mark, in a cloud of blossoming spinnakers

and fly away before the breeze in a surge

of foam was a roundabout which made up

for the swing.

take
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (muttonbirding)
Citations
Date:  0/8/1911
Source:  Gazette
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  ... but this presumption has been rebutted by the admission that he had no `take', therefore he has no right to this island.
Notes:  1911 Aug Gazette in 1979 Wilson Titi Heritage 41



Date:  0/0/1979
Source:  Titi Heritage
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  171
Edition:
Quote:  `Take', and all references thereto, include taking, catching, killing, or pursuing, by any means or device, ...
Notes:  1912 Regulations under Land Act in 1979 Wilson Titi Heritage 171



Date:  0/0/1979
Source:  Titi Heritage
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  25
Edition:
Quote:  Down the generations it had been observed that this happened about the same time each year, so the wise old chiefs set the season for the `take' for that certain time of the year which became known to the pakeha as half of March, all of April and May, allowing no trespassing on the island at any other time of the year lest the birds, refusing to nest on an island `touched' by human presence, should fly away and never return. <i>Ibid.</I> 27 Especially when the pakeha took a Maori wife; he could then share her journey to her island, and help her to `take' enough birds for their family needs. <i>Ibid.</I> 39 Some of these descendants actually visited the disputed islands and attempted to `take'. <.i>Ibid.</I> 55-56 Ever since the beginning, to `take' meant journeying to the islands and living there for the season and using hands or any device to catch the birds. ... to `take' also includes an `attempt to take'. During the torching season the birds run down the paths to the sea at night. Paths are used as boundaries by the [56] supervisors and in some cases the dividing line is the middle of the path. If one pursues a bird and grabs it over the other edge of the path one can be prosecuted, even although the bird came from the pursuer's manu. <i>Ibid.,</I> 66 In the season 1921 the Colac Bay and Riverton Maoris caught 24,000 birds, In 1922 the `take' was 14,000.
Notes:

take one's horse for a gallop

Date:  23/12/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The original occupier of country in the early days was said to have <i>taken it up</i>. `Who took up this station?' means `Who was the first occupier?' Nowadays people tell you that Mr Jones had just `taken up' 1000 acres of Brown's run. (C.) The old sense of the world was understood everywhere on stations up to about 1900.
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Both Sides of the River
Author:  ANDERSON

talk
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: (of a tree) to make sounds indicating it is about to fall
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1951 R. Gilberd Okaihau That means that a tree is about to fall and the weight of the top is breaking the fibres of wood. They crackle and squeak and groan - `talking'.

tally
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: [nf AND] spec. uses of OED vb ? (in the general sense of `counting a number of objects individually and entering the numbers up, or marking them off': e.g. tally cargo, etc) esp. by shearers, freezing workers, storemen; cf also EDD 7. A specified number or weight; in hop-picking, the number of bushels for which the picker receives a shilling. Glo Lon Sur Also vb.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (cf TALLY n1)

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Boss's Story, The
Author:  NEWTON
Vol / Page:  190
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Tally: </I>To tally is to count sheep. When counting big mobs, one man does the counting, and at each hundred he calls `Tally'. Another man keeps the tallies - at each call he may cut a notch in a stick or pick out a small pebble. The tally book contains a record of sheep counted during the year.

Notes: meat works; cf TALLY-SPEED
Citations
Date:  17/5/1951
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:  COLIN GORDON
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Tally</i>: You <i>cut tally</i> if you get 100 per man, and you drop so many off the

tally for stags (one-ball sheep) and rams (the penises and balls of both these are cut out, and this is how one counts them; <i>pizzles</i> (undeveloped penises) are cut off wethers.
Notes:  Feilding Freezing Works terms p.c.

Notes:  1890 Feb 8 in 1894 Wilson Land of the Tui 61-62

Date:  0/0/1949
Source:  High Country Days
Author:  NEWTON
Vol / Page:  197
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Tally</I>: To tally is to count sheep. When counting big mobs, one man does the counting, and at each hundred he calls `Tally.' Another man keeps the tallies - at each call he may cut cut a notch in a stick or pick out a small pebble. The tally book contains a record of sheep counted during the year.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1955
Source:  Wool Away!
Author:  BOWEN
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  Climatic conditions, the treatment sheep have had in the months before shearing, and the breeds of the sheep all play a big part in a shearer's tally. For this reason a shearer's tally can fluctuate considerably, depending on the type of sheep he is shearing. It is a mistake for young shearers to make `tally' paramount in their ambition to progress in shearing when quality of work would have to be the first point taken into account. <I>Ibid.</I> 157 TALLY. The number of sheep a shearer does in a day.
Notes:

Date:  26/2/1965
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Tally</i>: The number of sheep shorn during a run or other specified period. However, the general term is also used to describe a shearer's capacity to shear in a day. E.g. `He has a tally of 120.'
Notes:   (H.A.L. Laing)

tally
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:  a hundred sheep.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  1/3/1946
Source:  Ex-Pupils Budget
Author:
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  .. in the happy camaderie of shed life, where toil is plenty and the little rest doubly appreciated, the general remarks revealed ambitions for 'tallies' in the afternoon.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Loughnan Glossary
Author:  LOUGHNAN
Vol / Page:  83 (i)
Edition:
Quote:  a hundred sheep.
Notes:

Date:  23/12/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>(1) A hundred sheep.</I> When large mobs are counted the man counting calls out `T[ally].!' every time he gets to 100, and then starts again. Another man answers `T.' and cuts a notch in a stick. When the whole mob is counted the number of notches gives the hundreds and the odd number completes the total, which is also (2) called the t. 3. The total number of sheep shorn by each shearer in a day. 4. Hence <i>t.book,</i> in which the man who counts out, writes them down. 5. The <i>ts.</i> for the day before are written up each morning on a <i>tally board</i> kept in the shed. (C.)
Notes:  Acland Glossary

tally book
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  NZ English Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  3/28
Edition:
Quote:  <I>tally book</I>: The official record of what every man has shorn in each run of the day. It is made after the run by checking each shearer's counting out oen before clearing for the next session. Each shearer's tally for the day is then transferred to the tally book. In earlier times a `tally board' was used with the previous day's tallies chalked up. No matter whether the book or the board is used, the tallies must be displayed in the shed.
Notes:  Wallace Shearing Glossary

Date:  0/0/1935
Source:  Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author:  MEREDITH
Vol / Page:  144
Edition:
Quote:  I said nothing, put my tally-book in my pocket, and followed the boss. ... I told him I had docked a few sheep [from the tallies] for bad shearing and cutting. (station)

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Towards Taha Maori
Author:  HOWE
Vol / Page:  22
Edition:
Quote:  Tamariki, Tamarikitanga - children were traditionally openly cared for, and shared particularly by both parents and grandparents; they had the advantage of being able to expect similar care and protection from not just close kin, but other parents within the hapu (larger kinship group). They were encouraged to become independent and responsible as quickly as possible. One detrimental effect of urbanisation on the economic realities of today is the breakdown evident in such caring.
Notes:

Citations
tamarillo
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: (formerly in New Zealand called tree tomato) a bright red, subtropical fruit grown on a small tree.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: pl. -os
Citations
Date:  12/6/2004
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  E8
Edition:
Quote:  The tamarillo, it seems, is still a fruit New Zealand has largely to itself, for though it is grown in private gardens around the world in warm frost-free places like California, South Africa, Asia and Africa, only here is it cultivated systematically on a commercial scale... In the 1880s, Mr D Morris, director of the Botanbical Gardens in Jamaica, sent seeds to the hill districts of India and Sri Lanka, and it was from northern India that the first seeds were sent to New Zealand, to Hay and Sons, nurserymen of Parnell in Auckland. The Hay's 1891-1892 catalogue states that the nursery then had "plants of strong and healthy appearance" for sale... The name "tamarillo" officially came into being on January 31, 1967, after New Zealand exporters decided a more romantic, exotic name was needed than "tree tomato". The strategy worked, and today tamarillo seems to have become the accepted name internationally.
Notes:

Date:  0/6/1982
Source:  Orchardist NZ
Author:
Vol / Page:  143
Edition:
Quote:  He cites the economic potential of the pepino on a par with the tamarillo.

Notes:

Date:  0/4/1991
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  58
Edition:
Quote:  Although it sounds Spanish, the name ‘tamarillo' is another New Zealand invention. The former name ‘tree tomato', was considered inappropriate for use overseas where people buying the fruits for the first time might expect them to taste like tomatoes. In 1967, orchardist Bill Thomson took the Maori word ‘tama' added ‘tillo' (taken from tomatillo, a complete unrelated Mexican fruit) and then (just to make the sound more mellifluous) he replaced ‘t' with an ‘r'. Thus, ‘tamarillo' was born.

Date:  0/0/1982

Author:
Vol / Page:  31
Edition:
Quote:  Supplies of tropical fruits were curtailed because of the Japanese threats to the sea lanes, and tamarillo (or tree tomato as they were then known) growing began in earnest. [WWII] <i>Ibid.</I> 141 An uncultivated native of the Andes region of Peru, the tamarillo is also found wild in India, Sri Lanka and parts of South East Asia. It was from the hilly regions of northern India that New Zealand's first seeds came, introduced by the Auckland nursery of D. Hay and Sons in 1891. At first only the yellow and purple varieties were grown and it was not until the end of World War I that the now almost universal red variety was bred at Mangere, Auckland.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Verbatim
Author:
Vol / Page:  2/11
Edition:
Quote:  Two well-known New Zealand exports, neither of them native, are tree-tomatoes and Chinese gooseberries, but neither is called that by the exporters. The tomatoes are a South American fruit, a rich source of vitamin C and long popular in New Zealand. About twenty years ago, the name <i>tamarillo</i> was deliberately contrived, much as a brand name is. On the basis of <i>tomato</i>, a diminutive<i> -ill-</i> was added; then <i>tomatillo</i> was altered, in honor of a legendary Maori tribal hero, Tama-te-kapua, to <i>tamatillo</i>; and then a change to <i>tamarillo</i> was considered more euphonious. And so a new word was born.
Notes:  (G.W.Turner)

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page:  784
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tamarillo n.</i> (pl. <i>tamarillos</i>) subtropical tree with bright red fruit; this fruit. [invented word]
Notes:  [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 490]

Quote:  In the bays and tidal rivers are the mango or sharks - the most highly-prized food-fish - the tamure or schnapper, the whapuka or rock-cod, the kahawai or mackerel, the porahi or herring, the kanae or mullet, the patiki or sole, and many others. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. In the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga).

sawdust appear to be substantial and its risks so negligible, I would have no hesitation in digging it into my garden... Apart from tanalising, New Zealand timber may also be preserved with boron, or with pentachlorophenol - chemicals with quite different effects. Don't confuse these sawdusts with tanalised sawdust (stained green) or you will have a gardening disaster on your hands.

Date:  0/0/1960

Author:  McMEEKAN
Vol / Page:  149
Edition:
Quote:  The tandem shed consists of a set of bails which the cows stand in line, head to tail... on a platform 30 inches above the milker's level.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Grass to Milk
Author:  McMEEKAN
Vol / Page:  148,149,150
Edition:
Quote:  There are three commonly used types of milking shed in New Zealand - the walk-through, the tandem and the herringbone. ... [149] The walk-through shed is strictly a New Zealand invention. ... It was born of the ingenuity of farmers faced with the task of milking large herds on their own, or with little help. ... [150] The herringbone is a New Zealand development of the tandem type. ... In this type of shed the cows are angle-parked in two rows separated by the milking `well' which is thirty inches below the cow platforms.
Notes:

tanekaha

Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: <i>Phyllocladus trichomanoides</i> aka parsley leafed pine, parsley-leafed pine, parsley-leaved pine, parsley pine, celery pine, found in upper tip of South Island and in the North Island north of a line from Mokau to Mahia Peninsula - latitude 39 degrees.

Citations
Date:  12/10/1935
Source:  Christchurch Star-Sun
Author:
Vol / Page:  14
Edition:
Quote:  Not so many know the curious philocladus,

the tanekaha, or celery-pine, so odd in

details of growth, so shapely in whole,

brilliantly clothed in yellow and red,

with a bark that brings in a high price

for the tanning of ladies' gloves.

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/158
Edition:
Quote:  tangata, man; human being. In Hawaii dialect `t' becomes `k' and `n'" `n'" whence tangata becomes kanaka, the vulg. Pakeha for `man' in the Pacific, heavily accented on the second "a": ta'ata in Tahiti: all three `a's' are equally light in accent. (In OED under kanaka.)

tangata Maori
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a Maori person
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (Orsman)(Maori)... very frequently used to distinguish objects from others having special characteristics; thus, ... <i>tangata maaori, man, human being, </i>as opposed to a supernatural being: ... later, <i>man of the Polynesian race</i>, not a foreigner, the distinction not being confined to colour

Date:  0/0/1871
Source:  Dictionary of the Maori Language
Author:
Vol / Page:  75
Edition:
Quote:  I. <i>Maori,</i> a. 1. <i>native</i>. 2. He wai maori; <i>fresh water. </i>

-->A. The original Maori adjectival use is recorded in early English texts(as is the substantival), translated as `native' COPPER MAORI (q.v.) would fall within this use (contrast MAORI COPPER), as would PAKEHA MAORI. -->[J.C. Andersen Maori Names p.30 notes "<i>Korari Maori</i>: Here McCrae uses the word Maori in its usual sense signifying `normal, usual, ordinary. Not until long after this time did the word come to mean what Euopeans assume it actually means, and in which the natives themselves now aquiesce - that is the name of the people, the New Zealanders. It had no such meaning in the mind of the natives until a comparatively recent date, nor was it apparently so used by them to any extent until about 1850, though Wakefield [? which one ?] and some English writers had begun the use some years before. In earliest times <i>tangata maori</i>did not mean man of the Maori race but human being as opposed to supernatural being; <i>wai maori</i> was `fresh water'; <i>Whetu maori</i> `inferior stars' Cook spoke of the inhabitants of NZ as <i>Indians,</i> early Europeam writers as <i>natives</i> or New Zealanders. [Andersen is paraphrasing Williams Dictionary here.]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1826
Source:  Boultbee Journal
Author:
Vol / Page:  109
Edition:  1986
Quote:  New Zealander - ton|g|ata ma|u|ree [tangata maori]
Notes:  c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 109; ALSO 1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 282

Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: "people of the land", the indigenous people; the local people, the local residents of a particular place

Register:

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Towards Taha Maori
Author:  Howe
Vol / Page:  22
Edition:
Quote:  Tangata whenua - `whenua' (q.v.) is the placenta which was usually buried in a special place which would not be walked over and thus defiled by anyone. Thus a person's spiritual well being was linked with the land belonged to. `Tangata whenua' thus refers to the `people belonging to the land', who have therefore the right to live there according to their own traditions and values.

Quote:  All the old women turned out to `tangi' over him, according to the Maori fashion of saluting an old friend, ... [fn] The old native women always show affection by a sort of whimper, which is often prolonged for hours. This is called a `tangi'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1866
Source:  Polynesia
Author:  ANGAS
Vol / Page:  150
Edition:
Quote:  When friends meet, who have been separated for some time, a `tangi,' or crying, takes place, the parties sitting in silence opposite to each other for perhaps half an hour, exchanging no words, but uttering melancholy wailings; then, all of a sudden, they approach, press noses, and commence laughing and chatting in the most lively manner possible.

Source:  Dictionary of Slang
Author:  PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page:  1194
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Tangi</i>. n. and v. <i>Tangi,</i> a maori word for `a tribal gathering at a funeral: a dirge': `Now very commonly adopted here [New Zealand] by the upper classes, especially as an equivalent of the outmoded `beano'. E.g., Harold and I were on the tangi (or were tangi-ing) last night; or there is a big tangi on to-night,' Niall Alexander, letter of Oct. 22, 1939.

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Some Modern Maoris
Author:  BEAGLEHOLE
Vol / Page:  257
Edition:
Quote:  On the first day of the tangi kinsmen and tribal members, together with tribes related to that of the dead person, are notified of the death.<i>Ibid.</i> 258 The climax of the tangi is reached on the fourth day, the day of the burial. <i> Ibid. </i>  259 The abiding impression that one receives as one follows the course of a full-scale Maori tangi is that death is a very matter-of-fact event for the people.

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Towards Taha Maori
Author:  HOWE
Vol / Page:  22
Edition:
Quote:   Tangihanga - this word refers specifically to the ceremony which takes place when a person dies. It is closely linked with the idea of `whanaungatanga' (q.v.). People go to the tangi to share their grief with the bereaved family, to reaffirm family ties, to recall the living past.

Author:
Vol / Page:  6
Edition:
Quote:  Tangihanga leave [headline] The CSU is to lodge a claim for the recognition of tangihanga leave. The claim is based on the belief that tangihanga is a grieving process, and that as a consequence, extended bereavement leave should be granted those attending a tangi.

See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: [Ma. <b>tangihanga</b> mourning] cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 239.

tangiwai
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a translucent variety of greenstone.(bowenite
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1844
Source:  Notes of a Journey
Author:  MONRO
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  There are two kinds of greenstone, that which is commonly seen, and which is named the ponamoo, and another sort more glassy and transparent named tuggewai. The ponamoo is exceedingly hard, and has an irregular fracture. The tuggewai is much softer, of a more transparent green, and divides easily into plates.
Notes:  1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 261

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1929
Source:  Primitive Economics of NZ Maori
Author:  FIRTH
Vol / Page:  388
Edition:
Quote:  Among the Maori, considerations of aesthetic interest helped quite materially ... to decide

the relative worth of objects made of the <i>pounamu</i>, the nephrite so much prized for pendants, <i>mere</i>, and adzes. Most prized was the <i>kahurangi</i> stone, bright green, translucent, hard and clear; the <i>inanga</i> variety perhaps comes next, with its white milky-veined appearance, [389] followed by the <i>kawakawa</i>, dark olive-green, dull and opaque. ... <i>Tangiwai</i> (`tear drop'), <i>bowenite</i>, a softer stone of a clear pale green, with the appearance of drops of water in the texture, was less esteemed, though more beautiful in the European eyes, whilst <i>kahotea</i>, green, spotted or streaked with black, was an inferior type, and was used for small chisels, and for objects of subordinate interest.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1932
Source:  Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden
Author:  ELDER
Vol / Page:  432
Edition:
Quote:  Bowenite was used, but genuine specimens in this material are excessively rare.

Some pieces are quite translucent while others show the characteristic yellow-brown colouration. Bowenite is a softer material than greenstone.

tangle fern
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Gleichenia dicarpa  (formerly <i>alpina, circinata</i>), having thin, spidery pinnae.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (often preceded by a descriptive epithet)

Citations
Date:  0/0/2001
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 49/72
Edition:
Quote:  Umbrella ferns are quite unlike any other fern. Rather than producing a typically divided frond, the midrib divides repeatedly into two, producing a bud at the end of each branch, with two new branches arising immediately below it. Lateral branching of this sort can be finite, producing a distinctive shape, as in the umbrella fern (<i>Sticherus cunninghamii</i>), or it can continue almost indefinitely, with the frond forming extensive thickets, as in the tangle fern (<i>Gleichenia dicarpa</i>).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Stewart Island Plants
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  432
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Gleichenia dicarpa</i> TANGLE FERN ... Spider fern ... Swamp umbrella fern ... Fronds wiry, forked ... often forming tangled thickets or cushion-like springy masses ...


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1882

Author:  POTTS

taniwha
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a legendary water monster; a river guardian
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1820
Source:  Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ
Author:  LEE & KENDALL
Vol / Page:  207
Edition:
Quote:  T|aniwa,<i> s</i>. A sea monster so called.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1934
Source:  Marsden's Lieutenants
Author:  ELDER
Vol / Page:  255
Edition:
Quote:  `The taneewha (taniwha) whom the natives say upsets their canoes and drowns them, at other times takes them out of the canoe bodily, drowns, and eats them; ... they ascribe to their taking some old thatch from a house which was <i>tapu</i> or sacred into their canoe to sit upon. The taneewha or one of the sea-gods was angry, upset the canoe, etc.
Notes:  1822 Aug 15 John King in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 255

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/`158
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Taniwha</i>: fabulous monster; prodigy; incubus of the imagination: might take any shape, saurian, rock, log: might be stationary, or move from place to place in air, water or land, even through the land as a fish through the water or a bird through the air.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words [check spg saurian and commas???]

Date:  0/0/1979

Date:  25/1/2003
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  A1
Edition:
Quote:  If he had a niggle, it was around presentation and "MPs' use of emotive language such as the taniwha clause", which he believed many Maori would dislike.
Notes:

Date:  2/2/2003
Source:  Sunday Star Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  C5
Edition:
Quote:  The perfect symbol for all this is the Meremere taniwha. This one-eyed spirit stopped work on a new highway.. and gave National leader Bill English a new slogan. A reference to the Treaty in new legislation became the "taniwha clause" - a phrase coated in political poison... Historian Michael King says the issue "has nothing to do with the literal existence of non-existence of taniwha. Taniwha are a metaphorical way of saying that place is either dangerous or has special spiritual or historical significance. The way Maori signified  that was by talking about taniwha or guardian to make poeople respect it and to explain the fact that sometimes people disppeared or drown or whatever, in those places".
Notes:

Date:  28/12/2002
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  C5
Edition:
Quote:  A requirement [in the 2002 Local Government Act] labelled the "taniwha clause" by opponents also drew fire. The clause demands that council decisions have regard to the Treaty of Waitangi and allows separate council seats for Maori.

tank

Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  Old New Zealand
Author:  SALMOND
Vol / Page:  143
Edition:
Quote:  In the 1880s big corrugated iron tanks came on the market which were cheap enough for most households, and large enough to store water for the biggest of families. The round, corrugated tank became a characteristic of villa houses, sitting out the back on its high wooden stand hard up under the eaves, so that water would flow naturally through the outlet pipe in the bottom to the house.

tank water
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: household water supply collected originally from the roof by guttering and later pumped in from streams, wells etc.; usu. rainwater collected from a roof and fed into a holding tank for domestic use
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1960 Wellington (Pukerua Bay)

tao cooking

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author:  BURTON
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  There are countless ways of preparing food Maori style, but basically there were only three ways of cooking it. The first, which involves steaming in a subterranean oven called an<i> umu</i> or <i>hangi, </i>is known as<i> tao</i> cooking. It was the preferred method of cooking for groups of people, from family size up, in a village setting.

Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  Principles for Crown Action
Author:
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  The second article of the Treaty guarantees to iwi Maori the control and enjoyment of those resources and taonga which it is their wish to retain. The preservation of a resource base, restoration of iwi self management, and the active protection of taonga, both material and cultural, are necessary elements of the Crown's policy of recognising rangatiratanga.

Date:  0/0/1941
Source:  Valiant Love
Author:  MYERS
Vol / Page:  21
Edition:
Quote:  She was to be married tomorrow .. and the [Maori] children were laden with gifts. Each brought a little <i>taonga</i>; and into her apron, there fell the oddest assortment of things!
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  Te Maori
Author:
Vol / Page:  21
Edition:
Quote:  A lump of wood of little or no great significance is thus transformed through the art process, by building words (korero) into it and by contact with people, into ting Maoris class as a taonga, or in full, he taonga tuku iho. The dictionary describes taonga as 'property', or as 'anything highly prized' (Williams 1971: 381). Thus a taonga tuku iho is a highly prized object that has been handed down from the ancestors. <I>Ibid.</i> 22 In the popular sense a taonga is a highly prized possession to which is attached korero (text or story). An example is a whakapapa (genealogy) staff.
Notes:

Date:  13/6/1986
Source:  NewsVUW (Wellington)
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  The key element to the power of Te Maori [exhibition] has always been the presence of the elders, the supporters and the performers, that is, the people. We are moved by our taonga, by the ancestors represented in Te Maori.
Notes:  S.Mead

taonga species
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: treasured species
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: species taonga
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/2010
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Taonga species are native birds, plants and animals of special cultural significance and importance to Ngai Tahu that are found within the Ngai Tahu takiwa, defined by the Te Runanga o Ngai Tahu Act 1996 as being most of the South Island (excluding a northern segment) and the islands to the south including Stewart Island/Rakiura and others. There are 49 bird, 58 plant and 6 marine mammal taonga species - see full list below.




Notes:  http://www.doc.govt.nz/about-doc/role/maori/settlements/ngai-tahu/species/

Quote:  Taonga tuturu are a special category of protected objects. They have to be 50 years or older, but are also things that relate to Maori culture, history or society, or are believed to have been made, or used, by Maori.

tap
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to ask (a person) for a favour, esp. a loan; =(cold-)bite is as common in NZ as elsewhere


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1904
Source:  Kauri-Gum
Author:  PATTERSON
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  On arrival on a new field the nearest storekeeper is `tapped' as to his willingness or otherwise to give the newcomer a `start' - that is, to provide him with a few weeks' provisions while he digs the necessary gum.
Notes:

Date:  11/2/1911
Source:  NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page:  294/7/1
Edition:
Quote:  Rumor [sic] has it that before leaving Wellington this youthful nobleman `tapped' a Minister of the Crown for a pony, and soon after his arrival in the northern city he suddenly became short of the `needful'.

Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Transport Workers' Song Book
Author:
Vol / Page:  31
Edition:
Quote:  Some tap the boss before they join,/And their record clearly shows/ By this they make their marble good/

Vol / Page:  1009

Quote:  To ask for a loan. .in 4;`Perhaps you could get some help from your brother. Why don't you tap him for a loan - I think he'd very likely let you have the money.'

Homonym Number:

See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1863
Source:  Old New Zealand
Author:  MANING
Vol / Page:  (xii) 174
Edition:
Quote:  There was a kind of variation on the <i>tapu</i>, called <i>tapa</i>, of this nature. For instance, if a chief said, `That axe is my head', the axe became his to all intents and purposes, except, indeed, the owner of the axe was able to break his `head', in which case, I have reason to believe, the <i>tapa</i> would fall to the ground. It was, however, in a certain degree necessary to have some legal reason, or excuse, for making the <i>tapa</i>; but to give some idea of what constituted the circumstances under which a man could fairly <i>tapa</i> anything, I must needs quote a case in point.
Notes:

Unfortunately no one knows what causes this chronic fatigue. It has been called many names: Tapanui flu, myalgic encephalomyelitis and immune  dysfunction syndrome but it now seems that the medics in this country and Australia have settled on the term Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS).

Edition:

That particular kind of insult known as a tapatapa might cause such an action.

Quote:  In the afternoon we were told that a large party was on their way to this place, for the purpose of stripping us ... Tikoki had stripped an Englishman on the opposite side yesterday ... out of revenge for some property of his, which had been stolen out of a <i>tapu</i>ed house ...
Notes:  1827 Jan 29 H. Williams Early Journals (1961) 41

Date:  18/1/1832
Source:  Early Journals of Henry Williams, The
Author:  WILLIAMS
Vol / Page:
Edition:  1961
Quote:  The canoe was <i>Tapu'</i>d, having conveyed the body of Hengi ... to his former place.
Notes:  1832 Jan 18 H. Williams Early Journals (1961) 220



Date:  0/0/1835
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  YATE
Vol / Page:  85
Edition:
Quote:  A man who has touched a very young child, or has approached a corpse, or has rendered the last sad offices of friendship for a friend, is strictly tapued for several days; and is not allowed to touch food with his hands, nor in any way to feed himself, but by picking up his sustenance from the ground with his lips and teeth.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1838
Source:  New Zealand  (Polack)
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/52
Edition:
Quote:   ... such would have been Caddell's fate, had he not ran up to a chief ... who happened accidentally to be tapued at the time, and, catching hold of his garment, was saved in consequence; ... <i>Ibid.</I>1/67 She politely welcomed us, as we marched through her plantation of Indian corn and kumeras [a-acute], which were nearly ripe and in fine condition : unfortunately for us, the place was strictly tapued, or prohibited from being touched by any person, until the following harvest; ..<i>Ibid.</i>1/141 The whole of the prepared flax was tapued [a-acute], and of course safe from depredation.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1840
Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  2/276
Edition:
Quote:  When a place is to be <i>tapued</i>, the intimation is announced to all whom it may concern (or not) by a <i>raoui</i> or grotesque carving in wood, painted with the usual red earth, which is found in certain districts, and is baked after the native method.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1844
Source:  Travels in NZ
Author:  MAJORIBANKS
Vol / Page:  89
Edition:
Quote:  The `tapu' or tabboo is a ceremony common to New Zealand, along with all the other South Sea Islands. The power of `tapuing' seems to be vested in the principal chief alone, and may be considered the most important bulwark of his authority. This ceremony [90] renders every object, either animate or inanimate, sacred, or not to be approached, so that no person can enter tapued ground, nor touch a tapued person. Every girl promised in marriage is tapued, and married women also, until chastised by their husbands, when the `tapu' ceases, and they are then free to any one who can catch them, a remarkably good plan for securing the affections of the husband, and relieving the sex from some of those periodical chastisements in which some of the husbands in this country are so apt to indulge. Favourite pigs, canoes, and muskets are sometimes tabooed; burial ground is always tabbooed, and so is also a chief's head.
Notes:

Date:  17/5/1851
Source:  Lyttelton Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  6
Edition:
Quote:  ... a principal chief, who it seems was <i>tapued</i>, or rendered sacred for the time, was knocked down and beaten by one of the Maori police, ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1827
Source:  Boultbee Journal
Author:
Vol / Page:  204
Edition:
Quote:  Tiroa [205] returned the knife to me, after he had taken the taboo off, by rubbing it over with the gills of a fish. This strange custom of tabooing I do not understand, further than that it is a law strictly observed, & any wilful breach of it is considered a serious offense, & in severe instances punishable by death.
Notes:  1827 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 204-205

Vol / Page:  89

Quote:  The `tapu' or tabboo is a ceremony common to New Zealand, along with all the other South Sea Islands. The power of `tapuing' seems to be vested in the principal chief alone, and may be considered the most important bulwark of his authority. This ceremony [90] renders every object, either animate or inanimate, sacred, or not to be approached, so that no person can enter tapued ground, nor touch a tapued person. Every girl promised in marriage is tapued, and married women also, until chastised by their husbands, when the `tapu' ceases, and they are then free to any one who can catch them, a remarkably good plan for securing the affections of the husband, and relieving the sex from some of those periodical chastisements in which some of the husbands in this country are so apt to indulge. Favourite pigs, canoes, and muskets are sometimes tabooed; burial ground is always tabbooed, and so is also a chief's head.

Date:  0/0/1881
Source:  Poenamo
Author:  Campbell
Vol / Page:  4/6/293
Edition:
Quote:  When any article was fancied, the intending purchaser took a thrumb from the fringe of his or her mat, and fastened it on to the chosen article. If the selector happened to be wearing a blanket or shirt or mat without a fringe, or wearing nothing at all, as was sometimes the case, from which any tapu-ing mark could be detached, then a neighbouring flax bush, or piece of flax from a potato kit, supplied the wherewithal to affix the tapu.

Quote:  The committtee of runanga have (I hear) agreed to allow the sale of wheat, provided it never rules at a lower rate here than 5s. cash; but as they say we have been making a profitable spec. by sending timber to your market, they have stopped that branch of trade by tapuing the sale of all timber, firewood, &c., either for sale or home consumption.
Notes:  Reprinted from the <i>Hawke's Bay Herald</i>

Citations
Date:  25/12/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Tar</I>.- In the old days t. was always put on sheep cut by the shears. Nowadays some carbolic dip, kerosene, or Condy's is used; but it is always called t. When he cuts a sheep the shearer calls out `T., boy, t. on the leg', and a fleecepicker or broomie dabs the disinfectant on with a <I>t.stick</I> and puts it back in the <I>t. pot.</I> Patterson writes of `The tar boy, the cook, and the slushy, The sweeper that swept the board', but I do not think a tarboy was ever employed specially in New Zealand sheds. (C.)
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  0/0/1949
Source:  High Country Days
Author:  NEWTON
Vol / Page:  197
Edition:  1950
Quote:  TAR: In earlier days a pot of Stockholm tar was kept in shearing sheds. If sheep were cut during shearing, the cut was dabbed with tar. Today this has been mainly replaced by other antiseptics, but these are still referred to as `tar.' If a shearer cuts a sheep he calls: `Tar.'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1960
Source:  Memories of Maoriland
Author:  SCRYMGEOUR
Vol / Page:  49
Edition:
Quote:  exclam. (shearers') Proceeding just fair, but with their regularity that follows a shearer getting his back used to the arduous job, the advancement went on but with a different and a rougher cut than was usual. More frequently application of the loppies galloping down the board, to the ever increasing cry of `Tar'. The cut was becoming rougher and numbers spoilt good work, and slowly the gore of the classer, the shepherds, and certainly that of William Steuart, rose.
Notes:

Citations
Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  NZ English Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  3/28
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tar</i>: Stockholm tar was once used as an antiseptic sealer on cuts, and although this has been generally replaced by improved antiseptics and special powders against flies, these new substances are still referred to as `tar'. At one time in the big sheds when any shearer called `tar' there was a tarboy to dab the cut, but now this is usually by the nearest shedhand.
Notes:  (Wallace Shearing Glossary)

Author:  BUCK
Vol / Page:  2/96

Quote:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/158
Edition:
Quote:  <I>tara</I>, a sea-bird (Sterna stricta), white-fronted tern: several other birds are known as tara with suffix, as S. nereis, fairy tern, tara-iti; Hydroprogne caspia Caspian tern, tara-nui; Larus novae hollandiae, red-billed gull, and L. bulleri, black-billed gull, tara-punga; but these are not so definitely used in general as to be adopted.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Native Animals of NZ
Author:  POWELL
Vol / Page:  80
Edition:
Quote:  WHITE FRONTED TERN (<I>Sterna striata</I>), Tara of the Maoris, is abundant all around the New Zealand coasts and occurs in Tasmania and Eastern Australia as well. This is the graceful little `Kahawai-bird' or `Sea-swallow,' which pursues schools of small surface fish, wheeling, darting and dipping to the water, in its energetic quest of food. Since the Kahawai fish is predaceous on the small school fish also, the tern is an excellent indicator of the presence of Kahawai.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1952
Source:  Chambers Shorter English Dictionary Supp.
Author:
Vol / Page:  805/2
Edition:
Quote:
Notes:  [OEDS]

Date:  0/0/1952
Source:  Chatham Islands
Author:  RICHARDS
Vol / Page:  82
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Sterna ... frontalis [? striata]</I> ... It pursues schools of small fish close to the coasts of New Zealand, Tasmania and Australia, and as the kahawai fish also feed on the same class of food, the tern is a useful indicator to fishermen of their presence. Hence its name of kahawai bird. Kahawai Bird. Sea Swallow, Tom Noddy. TARA.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Birds of New Zealand
Author:  FALLA et al.
Vol / Page:  157
Edition:
Quote:  BLACK-FRONTED TERN <I>Chlidonias albostriatus Other names</I>: Tara, Sea Martin, Ploughboy, Inland Tern, Riverbed Tern. <i>Ibid.</I> 164 WHITE-FRONTED TERN <I>Sterna striata Other names</I>: Sea-swallow, Kahawai Bird, Tara, Blackcap, Grenadier, Swallowtail, Noddy (Chathams), Tikkitak (Stewart Is.)

taraire
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a native tree, <i>Beilschmiedia tarairi</i>, used in fencing and in some farm buildings (common north of Auckland).
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation: -
Notes: aka tarairi, taraide

The taste is particularly acrid. <i>Ibid.</I> 2/400 There are many other woods of much service to Europeans, differing in quality, among others: the 30 Warangai.. 36 Tarairi .. 45 Parekireki, &c. Of all these woods there are abundant quantities.

tarakihi
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a fine-eating fish common in New Zealand waters, the jackass fish of southern Australia. Dactylopagrus macropterus (formerly <i>Chilodactylus</i>), a fine food fish
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: incl terakihi, common spelling error

Quote:  The following fish were caught with hook and line: araara, maomao, moki, mango, ngoiro, pakirikiri, kahawai, tamure, tarakihi, and warehou. The kanae, kehe, kopipiro, moho, nanu and other species were taken by net.

Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  47
Edition:
Quote:  <i>TARAKIHI</i> (a) Scientific name: <i>Cheilodactylus macropterus</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Tarakihi. (c) Other common names: Tiki (Kaikoura); Porae (<i>Cheilodactylus douglasi</i>) is normally lumped with Tarakihi and is known as Morwong in Australia and also as Sea Bream. (d) Principal localities where taken: [all except far south]

Vol / Page:  167

Quote:  Of the sea-fishes that are used as food in New Zealand, we have among the constant residents on all parts of our coast the hapuku, tarakihi, trevally, moki, aua, rock-cod, wrasse, and patiki; and while the snapper, mullet, and gurnet are only met with in the north, the trumpeter, butterfish, and red-cod are donfined to the south.

taramea
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: speargrass (espec. Aciphylla squarrosa); also called spaniard, spear-grass, bayonet-grass the larger of two related varieties of spear-grass. [Maori]

Date:  0/0/1851
Source:  Southern Districts of NZ
Author:  SHORTLAND
Vol / Page:  313
Edition:
Quote:  TARAMEA, a small stemless plant, having fleshy triangular leaves, terminating in a sharp point, all growing in a tuft from the level of the ground. From them the natives procure a scent (vide p. 217).
Notes:

Date:  28/6/1851
Source:  Lyttelton Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  There are two plants, the karo (prickly thorn) and taramea (spear grass), whch are well worthy of their names, but are almost exclusively confined to the hilly regions. There generally grows near these a plant called the timuka, from the leaf of which the natives make mats and leggings, which are impervious to the sharp points of the former.
