Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  History of Children's Play
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  52
Edition:
Quote:  Occasionally unusual types of hiding games were played, for example All In or Taranaki. In this game there were two teams and a home base. One team, the `outs,' went and hid, while the home team, looked for the `outs.' As soon as an `in' player saw an `out,' he cried, `All in for Tommy Jones' (the `out' player who had been spotted). At that cry all the `in' players raced for home, and all the `out' players emerged from their hiding places and attempted to tag them. If all the `in' players could get home without being tagged, then the person seen (Tommy Jones), was considered captured, and he had to come and sit in the home base, And so the `in' team went on trying to sight players and [53] then get home without being tagged.
Notes:

Date:  31/10/1986
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  6
Edition:
Quote:  [Hdg] Preparing pillars and Maori mats The entrance to Government House, Wellington, will soon have a Taranaki flavour - carved pillars and woven mats made in the Te Atiawa (Taranaki) style Petone Technical Institute students carved pou out of a 100-year-old totara pile ... Te Atiawa women are still plaiting the mat to be laid at the main door.
Notes:

Vol / Page:  99
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Taranaki drive</i> a technique used in bush felling whereby one tree is felled on to another, in order to lay a group of trees down. Unlike many Taranaki references, this one is a skilled operation, a dangerous practice that is not encouraged, except when there is the need to knock down `hang ups'. <i>[G. Johnston] </i>

Taranaki
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number: 2
Definition: often connotes `makeshift; rough-rural; country-bumpkinish; uncouth' (cf. the way Irish is used in general English: ?many Irish-pedigreed farmers in Taranaki)
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Taranaki
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition:  [of objects or processes] makeshift, but showing ingenuity.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See: Taranaki gate; Taranaki huntaway; Taranaki drive
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  11/2/1977
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  Referring to the use of the word 'Taranaki', Mr Loughnan says that it always seems to have suffered at the hands of South Islanders, who have used it as an adjective to refer to something makeshift, but which implies a definite degree of usefulness and ingenuity. The most common use of Taranaki is, of course, for the makeshift gate of wires and battens, which is a nightmare for the novice to open and shut.

Taranaki exquisite
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1859
Source:  Story of New Zealand, The
Author:  THOMSON
Vol / Page:  2/188
Edition:
Quote:  .. it is worthy of notice, that the colonists, soon after the formation of all the settlements, acquired distinguishing epithets; thus there was an Auckland cove, a Wellington swell, a Nelson snob, a Taranaki exquisite, an Otago cockney, and a Canterbury pilgrim. These epithets, almost already forgotten, are too characteristic to be buried in oblivion, as each originated in some peculiarity of the leading colonists. The Otago settlers derived theirs from their ignorance of the country in which they lived; the Auckland people from their extensive Sydney connexions; and the origin of the other names are sufficiently obvious without explanation.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1941
Source:  NZ Slang
Author:  BAKER
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:
Quote:  `There was an Auckland cove, .. a Taranaki exquisite...

Quote:  Taranaki ironsand consists principally of magnetite (magnetic oxide of iron), ilmenite (titanate of iron), ferro- magnesian minerals such as augite and hornblende, some olivine and quartz.

Author:
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  The 'Taranaki method' of ensilage stacking - stacking grass, green oats or anything handy, and weighing it by earth excavated from the side of the stack, the earth being afterwards replaced when the silage was being used. The Taranaki method should become popular among New Zealand dairymen.

Source:  NZ Slang
Author:  BAKER

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1949
Source:  Dictionary of Slang Addenda
Author:  PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page:  1195
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Taranaki top-dressing</I>. Cattle dung: New Zealand (mostly the South Island): C. 20. Niall Alexander, letter of Oct. 22, 1939; B., 1941. Taranaki Province is famous for its dairy cattle. `Among the sheep-farming communities, Taranaki is usually referred to as a land of cows and cow cockies up to their knees in mud and cow dung' (N. Alexander, l.c.).

Taranaki wool
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the tree fungus Auricularia polytricha Hakeka; an old word for the edible jew's ear fungus collected for sale. [from its one-time commercial importance in a mainly dairy-farming area]
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: ear fungus
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1997
Source:  Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ
Author:  CROWE
Vol / Page:  126
Edition:
Quote:  Ear fungus <i>Auricularia polytricha</i> Hakeka This fungus has also been known as 'Taranaki wool' from the days when its collection provided a livelihood in Taranaki.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Tales of Pioneer Women
Author:
Vol / Page:  91
Edition:
Quote:  Often when household funds were low, a  few shillings were obtained by selling

fungus, otherwise known as "Taranaki Wool," which was exported to China for

culinary purposes.


Notes:  Writing of 1940

Date:  13/8/2003
Source:  Capital Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  "Chew Chong, based in Taranaki, exported Wood Ear fungus to China. In the mid-1800s there was a huge trade in fungus. It was at one stage larger than butter exports." The fungus attracted the popular name of "Taranaki wool", Yee says.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  Kauri & The Willow, The
Author:  LOCKE
Vol / Page:  91
Edition:
Quote:  In a single year, 1885, seventy-two thousand pounds worth of this "Taranaki wool" was sent away.


Notes:

Date:  0/7/1998
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 39/18
Edition:
Quote:  The box on fungi tells us that Chinese trader Chew Chong, one of New Zealand's early dairy exporting entrepreneurs, first made his name as an exporter of the edible wood ear fungus, then known locally as "Taranaki wool". In the 1880s the trade was worth thousands of pounds.

They were sent only to the volunteers, but we agreed to translate the word to civilian, so that every Taranakian had something of use and value.

taranakite
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a mineral
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/10/1982
Source:  Geological Society of NZ Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  58.71
Edition:
Quote:  A New Zealand mineralogist seeing the book is naturally interested in the minerals first described from this country, namely akatoreite, (Read and Reay), awaruite (Skey), huttonite (Palst), hydrogrossular (Hutton), motukoreaite (Rodgers, Chisholm, Davis and Nelson), taranakite (Hector and Skey), tuhualite (Marshall), wairakite (Steiner and Coombs),and wairauite (Challis and Long).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1883
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  15/385
Edition:
Quote:  This mineral, which is double hydrous phosphate of alumina and potash, part of the alumina being replaced by ferrous oxide, was first discovered by H. Richmond, Esq., at the Sugar Loaves, Taranaki, where it occurs as thin seams which occupy fissures in trachytic rocks. It is described by Dr. Hector (Juror's Rep. N. Z. Ex., 1865, p. 423) as of a yellowish-white colour; amorphous and soft; readily fusible before the blowpipe and in other respects resembling wavellite.
Notes:  (Cox)

Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2340
Edition:
Quote:  <i>taranakite n -s [Taranaki,</i> provincial district in New Zealand, its locality + E <i>-ite</i>] : a mineral ... ? consisting of a basic hydrous phosphate of aluminium and potassium in compact clayey masses
Notes:  [In OEDS in this quotation]

Date:  0/11/1990
Source:  Geological Society of NZ Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  90/44
Edition:
Quote:  This included the first description of the new mineral taranakite, discovered near New Plymouth.
Notes:

Date:  19/9/1866
Source:  Daily Southern Cross
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  I have much pleasure in acknowledging the receipt from E.B. Dickson, Esq., of New Plymouth of three interesting geological specimens:- No.1, a specimen of granite from the Sugar Loaves, showing the formation of the newly described mineral, "Taranakite;" No.2, a larger one from an outlying reef; and No.3, a smaller specimen of the Taranikte by itself. It is probable that this substance will prove to be of some commercial value, as it evidently contains much phosphate of lime, which, for agricultural purposes, is highly esteemed.
Notes:

Notes:

Date:  29/1/2002
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Thousands of people are expected to visit Waitakere City’s Te Rangi Hiroa Park on March 3 for Tarara Day 2002.

A celebration of the joining of Maori and Croatian cultures on the gumfields more than 100 years ago, Tarara Day provides an opportunity for people of Croatian-Maori descent to celebrate their cultures and learn more about their heritage.

‘Tarara’ was the name given to Croatians by Northland Maori to distinguish them from the English.


Notes:  Waitakere City Council Media Release www.waitakere.govt.nz

Date:  8/9/2004

Date:  0/0/1987

Author:  BATISTICH
Vol / Page:  35
Edition:
Quote:  We Dalmatians got on well with the Maoris from the start. It was almost as if we were related, maybe somewhere back in time. The Maoris had a name of their own for us: tarara, from the sound of our speech, not unlike their own; the same broad vowels and rolled 'r's, the musical inflexion that belongs naturally to song.
Notes:

Date:  0/7/2004
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  In the 1860's the first Dalmatian gum diggers arrived fleeing  hard times back in their Adriatic homeland. As the diggers were exclusively men, they found wives among the Maori community who called the newcomers Tarara, a reference to the sound of their speech.

Homonym Number:

Source:  Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author:  BURTON
Vol / Page:  152

Edition:
Quote:  [Title] Tararua Biscuits. A New Zealand mountaineers' staple, one of these biscuits lies buried in the Himalayas, on the summit or Yerupaja Norte. The gesture was the brainchild of Graeme Dingle, who was the first to conquer the mountain in 1968.
Notes:

Date:  4/6/1983
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  55
Edition:
Quote:  Among the authentic local baking-terms the one I find most evocative is the Tararua biscuit. It comes in high-fibre high- calorie slabs... Two generations of Wellington dentists must have made a tidy income from its inroads. I must be one of the few of my old Mt Holdsworth gang with my own teeth, since I only once tackled a Tararua biscuit and I must confess I did not take it straight.
Notes:  [I.A. Gordon]

Date:  0/0/1985

Vol / Page:  492
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Tararua biscuit inf. </i>tramper's home-made biscuit
Notes:  [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; nf. 1986 NZPOD]

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Hills, The
Author:  PICKERING
Vol / Page:  71
Edition:
Quote:  A classic lunch food is the Tararua biscuit. This is any sort of home-baked biscuit baked out of a mixture of rolled oats, flour, golden syrup and other ingredients, and formed into a hard flat biscuit that acts as a base for butter and spreads. The principle of Tararua biscuits is that they serve as a replacement for bread on long trips. ... The taste is not a crucial matter, but they must be firm and filling - and all of the same size, otherwise bickering will develop over who's got the biggest.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  200 Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author:  BURTON
Vol / Page:  152
Edition:
Quote:  Tararua biscuits must be baked hard to withstand jostling about in a pack.

I peered over their shoulders and noted that their lunches included good old Tararua biscuits and one person had boiled eggs ...

Tararua dishmop
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Raoulia tenuicaulis creeping mat plant, one of the scabweeds


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1952 May R. Mason fide N. Elder May 1952 From its being used by trampers as a dishcloth. Originating among Wellington trampers, but long obs in Wellington. Survives in Hawkes Bay.

Citations
Date:  0/9/1958
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:  30
Edition:
Quote:  It is unnecessary to write at length in general of New Zealand plant names, but mention may be made of the <I>Tararua dishmop</I> and the mountain mop</I>. Apparently the first is given to<I> Raoulia tenuicaulis</I>, one of the scabweeds, by Heretaunga Tramping Club. No doubt plenty of Tararuas have used it with sand or ashes to clean out a billy, little thinking that their actions might inspire a new plant name, given to it by Canterbury mountaineers apparently, from the tufts of leaves at the ends of the branches.
Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  112
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Tararua dishmop Raouli tenuicaulis</I> plant, used by trampers to clean out pots and billies. (Cf mountain mop.)

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  194
Edition:  1940 p. 202
Quote:  <i>Pittosporum eugenioides (The Lemonwood) </i>... Maori name <i>Tarata.</i> (Name from <i>Eugenia,</i> a genus of myrtles)... [<i>Pittosporum eugenioides</i>] it is often cultivated for its beauty, and is sometimes - though not so often as<i> P. [195] tenuifolium </i>- used to form an ornamental hedge. It is known by a variety of names amongst the colonists, such as <i>Mapau, White Mapau</i>, and even <i>Maple</i>, and <i>Lemon-tree.</i> The Maori name seems to have been <i>Tarata</i>, but it is also called the <i>Mapau. </i>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/146
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tarata</i>, a tree (Pittosporun Eugenioides), lemonwood; gum used by the Maori for scenting oil.

Date:  0/10/2000
Source:  Growing Today
Author:
Vol / Page:  69
Edition:
Quote:  Tarata, the larger leafed <i>Pittosporum eugenioides</i>), does well in deeper and good soils... Tarata has sweet fragrant flowers and the crushed leaves give off a lemon-carrot scent. Both

tarata and kohuhu were used by Maori, mixed with kereru fat to make a body lotion or, using gum bled form vertical slits in the trunk, mixed with oil from crushed titoki berries to make a scented body oil.

tar-boy

Sense Number:  1
Definition: a shed-hand who applies tar to a cut on a sheep being shorn.

Notes:

Date:  23/12/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Tar.</i>- In the old days<i> t.</i> was always put on sheep cut by the shears. Nowadays some carbolic dip, kerosene, or Condy's is used; but it is always called<i> t</i>. When he cuts a sheep the shearer calls out `<i>T</i>., boy,<i>t</i>. on the leg', and a fleecepicker or broomie dabs the disinfectant on with a <i>t.stick</i> and puts it back in the <i>t. pot.</i> Patterson writes of `The tar boy, the cook, and the slushy, The sweeper that swept the board', but I do not think a tarboy was ever employed specially in New Zealand sheds. (C.)
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Author:  BOWEN

Edition:

Source:  Off the Sheep's Back
Author:  RICHARDS
Vol / Page:  55
Edition:
Quote:  ... I was allowed to miss school to help in the shed by picking up the bellywool and removing the pizzle stains from the wether bellywool. I was also `tar-boy', which meant putting dabs of Stockholm tar on any cuts inflicted by the shearers.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  NZ English Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  3/28
Edition:
Quote:  tar: Stockholm tar was once used as an antiseptic sealer on cuts, and although this has been generally replaced by improved antiseptics and special powders against flies, these new substances are still referred to as `tar'. At one time in the big sheds when any shearer called `tar' there was a tarboy to dab the cut, but now this is usually by the nearest shedhand.




Notes:  (Wallace Shearing Glossary)

Date:  20/10/1887
Source:  Timaru Herald
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  But the shearer is up and busy two or three minutes before the time, has taken his shears from the tar-boy, or “picker up,” who has been practicing a little through the leisure, has given the blades a final touch with the stone, thrown the coat off his shoulders, and stripped and eager as a wrestler at the call of “time,” stands at the door of his pen.
Notes:

Notes:

tar-boy
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a person who walks the board where sheep are prone to fly strike and puts a smear of tar on the shearing cuts made in response to the shearers' call `tar!' (Tar is now replaced by modern antiseptics and fly repellants.)


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

tar-brand

Sense Number:
Definition: tar-mark, sc. of sheep, or occas. cattle
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Citations
Date:  0/0/1878

Author:  ELWELL

Source:  Hawera & Normanby Star
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  Mr Heslop said he had had cattle in his possession which had been tar-branded for weeks, and the brand was quite plain; and, more than that, he used to tar-brand all the cattle he sent to the Witaraa works, and there would be no difficulty about it at all.
Notes:

Date:  21/6/1889
Source:  Poverty Bay Herald
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  No doubt, the sheepfarmers of the South were compelled to tar-brand immediately after shearing, and in the case of merinos this would be generally sufficient for a twelvemonths, but long-wool sheep would have to be branded at frequent intervals to keep the brand legible.

Notes:

Date:  20/10/1894
Source:  Tuapeka Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  This discovery (I mean of the bone, for the living bird never materialised, although explorers found plenty of caves) was made on the east coast, where the natives called the bird the "tarepo." Four years later, on the west coast, he found a perfect cemetery of these bones and heard the bird called for the first time the "moa" - the natives, very singularly, never having heard the name used by their brethren on the other side of the island.

taro
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: OED : a. A food-plant, Colocasia antiquorum, N.O. Araceæ, cultivated in many

varieties (C. esculenta, macrorhiza, etc.) in most tropical countries for its starchy

root-stocks, or its succulent leaves or stems, which in a raw state are acrid, but lose

their acridity by boiling.

1769 S. PARKINSON Jrnl. 1 Oct. in Jrnl. Voy. South Seas (1773) II. 97 Adjoining to their

houses are plantations of Koomarra and Taro.
Origin:
Register:

Region: [none]

taro Maori
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a cultivar of taro, Colocasia esculenta.


Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1925
Source:  Maori Agriculture
Author:  BEST
Vol / Page:  127
Edition:
Quote:  The great labour of growing taro maori (the old pre-European variety) caused it to be abandoned when the taro Merekena was introduced. The latter is hardy, prolific, runs wild in fact, and easily cultivated, but it is very inferior in flavour and flouriness to taro maori. I don't think I have seen taro maori for thirty years.

Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  In the old days <I>tar</I> was always used to put on sheep cut by the shears. Nowadays some carbolic dip, kerosene, or Condy's is used; but it is always called <I>tar</I>. When he cuts a sheep the shearer calls out `Tar, boy, tar on the leg,' and a fleecepicker or broomie dabs the disinfectant on with a <I>tar-stick</I> and puts it back in the<I> tar-pot</I>. .

Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  Muvver Tongue, The
Author:  BARLTROP
Vol / Page:  82
Edition:
Quote:  A prostitute is not called a tart by Cockneys, because `tart' has always meant a girl. It is a street word, not used indoors, but it is not coarse or unpleasant. It conveys a well made up, attractive girl. One might say `Who's that ginger-haired tart,' or `Harry was talking to a tart', or even `your tart' - though the last shows a poor vocabulary and would be said only by children. The term has been going strong for at least seventy [83] years, and probably derives from something like `jam tart'; given that, why should a reference to colourfulness and sweetness be offensive?

I real meaning of the name, both from a confectionary [sic] and social point of view, is a thing with a great deal of puff, but with very little in it.

Date:  6/2/1907
Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  25
Edition:
Quote:  Of the so-called pines there were many varieties, perhaps the most common being the bog pine, or tarwood (Dacrydium Colensoi) a tree remarkable on account of its exhibiting leaves of the most opposite appearance, as even on the same branch the young leaves will be found spreading in shape and half-an-inch in length, while the older ones are so closely placed that the branchlets seem to resemble strings of whipcord.

Date:  0/0/1868
Source:  Contributions to NZ Botany
Author:  LINDSAY
Vol / Page:  54
Edition:
Quote:  In this condition [<i>Rubus australis</i>, Forst.] forms one of the most ... troublesome `Lawyers,' or `Supple-Jacks,' of the forest. It is known to the settler also as the `Wild Irishman,' and to the North Island Maori as `Tataramoa'. [fn] A term defined by Dieffenbach as `Thorns, Blackberry,' - a description at least partly applicable, and with greater propriety, to <i>Discaria Toumatou. </I>

[17] <I>Bush-lawyer</I> - Native name, Tataramoa - A disagreeable bramble, very tenacious of grasp.

The<i> tatata</i>[as-acute] is similar in size to the former, having pending from every part, an infinity of small cords six inches long, of no use or ornament; its origin must be ascribed to the arbitrary taste of fashion,

tattoo
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: .
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: moko
Pronunciation:
Notes: aka tatu, tatto; derived from Polynesian dialects, was introduced to general English after the publication of Cook's Voyages (so Morris), and used by English speakers in New Zealand as the usual word for (applying) the Maori <i>moko</i> n `tattooing (on face or body)'
Citations
Date:  0/7/1769
Source:  Cook's Journals
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/125
Edition:  1955
Quote:  Both sexes paint their bodys. <i>Tattow </i>as it is called in their language. [check context and reference: ??Maori]
Notes:

Date:  0/11/1769
Source:  Cook's Journals
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/213
Edition:
Quote:  ... in each of the Canoes were two or three Cheifs [sic] and the habits of these were superior to any we had yet seen, the Cloth they were made on was of the best sort and cover'd on the out side with Dog skins put on in such a manner as to look agreeable to the Eye. Few of these people were tattow'd or mark'd in the face like those we have seen farther to the south, but several had their Backsides tattou'd much in the same manner as the Inhabitants of the Islands within the Tropics.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1773

Author:
Vol / Page:  2/191
Edition:
Quote:  `They have a custom of staining their bodies ... which they call <i>Tattowing</i>. They prick the skin, so as just not to fetch blood, with a small instrument, something in the form of a hoe. ...
Notes:  >1773. `Hawkesworth's Voyages' (Cook's First Voyage; at Tahiti, 1769), vol. ii. p. 191:

Author:  MARSDEN
Vol / Page:  171
Edition:  1932
Quote:  The chisel was constantly dipped in a [172] liquid made of soot from a particular tree, and afterwards mixed with water, which communicates the blackness or, as they call it, the amoko

(<i>moko</i>). I observed proud flesh rising in some part of the breech which had been cut almost one month before. The operation is too painful to bear the whole tattooing at one time. They appear to be several years before they are perfectly tattooed.

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  461
Edition:
Quote:   ...<i> and to mark the human body with indelible pigments. The word is Polynesian; its first occurrence in English is in Cook's account of Tahiti. The Tahitian word is Tatau </i>which means tattoo marks on the human skin, from <i>Ta</i>, which means a mark or design. (Littre.) The Maori verb, <i>ta</i>, means to cut, to tattoo, to strike. See <i>Moko. </i>
Notes:

Date:  18/2/1886
Source:  Grey River Argus
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  TATTOO BETRAYED HIM. A native named Mohi Te Kati was arrested at daylight at Petane Pah in August 1884 ... The prisoner was discovered through his having his name tattooed [sic] on his breast.

Quote:  Moko is the art of latter-day tattooing amongst the Maori. The older style was called Mokokuri, and was practised by the demigod Mani, who used to tattoo the muzzle of a dog - whence dogs went with black muzzles as we see them now.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author:  TURNER
Vol / Page:  175
Edition:
Quote:  The Golden Kiwi established partly to prevent sent money being sent out of New Zealand for tickets in Tatt's, a Tasmanian lottery with a name abbreviated from Tattersall's and quite unconnected with the English cant word <i>tatts></i> `dice'. It was illegal to sell tickets in Tatts' in New Zealand but many barbers' shops displayed a notice, `We communicate with Hobart', which was universally understood. . . .It was clear that in the context of a barber's shop window the notice meant `we sell tickets in Tatt's', but legally a man can announce that he writes to Tasmania. Newspapers might report the good fortune of winners but the illegal source of the winnings would not be specified. The money came from `an overseas consultation'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1968
Source:  NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins)

Vol / Page:  20
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Tatt's ... n. </i>shortened form of Tattersall's, formerly Tasmanian, now a Victorian lottery.

tau tau

Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1962
Source:  Pound of Saffron, A
Author:  JOSEPH
Vol / Page:  113
Edition:
Quote:  `The jade, the pounamu ... It's a beautiful stone ... Look,' he said, holding up a long hooked ear-drop of pearly translucence, `that's tau tau and the stone is called inanga. And this, the pekapeka - they say the shape comes from the bat. This is for the ear, too - the mako, like a shark's tooth ... And these,' - he ran his fingers along a row of ... nephrite adzes - `toki. See this one' - he held the heavy red-mottled adze in his palm - `that's the red kind, totoweka, woodhen's blood. The deep green, that's kawakawa.'
Notes:

taua
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: war party
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (Frequent in early North Island missionary journals and letters, and among those living among or dealing with Maoris. It is perhaps part of early missionary English (?jargon).) [check discards]

See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Tawini, tawhine, tawhina, et al; the main application in NZ English is to the <i>Cassinia</i> sp., a troublesome weed of central New Zealand. Its eradication generates word-combinations: <i>tauhinu-contract, tauhinu-pulling, tauhinu-rash, to pull tauhinu</i>. =yellow scrub (?Golden tauhinu)

The grey-leaved <i>C. leptophylla </i>so invaded neglected hill pastures (as about Wellington) that it, along with the golden tauhinu <i>C. fulvida,</i> was designated a`scheduled noxious weed'.

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/158
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tauhinu,</i> a troublesome scrub (Pomaderris Phylicaefolia), densely growing and persistently regenerating. C. leptophylla is tauhinu-korokia or tauhinu-koromiko, but these names are not in general use as is tauhinu, or tawhini as some miscall it.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

tauhou
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: [Maori, stranger: the bird arrived from Australia in the mid-19th century] Zosterops lateralis, silvereye, white-eye, wax-eye, blight bird
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: silvereye

Citations
Date:  0/0/1870
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  2/61
Edition:
Quote:  ZOSTEROPS LATERALIS, Lath. Tauhou. Blight-bird. We first noticed this bird ... in the Rockwood Valley, Malvern Hills, July 28th, 1856. ... It very soon obtained the name of Blight-bird ... from its habit of feeding on the American blight, with which apple trees in this colony are so generally infested ...
Notes:  (Potts Birds)

Quote:  Coming to our little white-eye, or tauhou, `the stranger', who came from Australia in 1856 ... is now as rare as he was common.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/159
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tauhou</i>, a wandering bird (Zosterops halmaturina), blight-bird; twinkie; button-eye; wax-eye; ring-eye. Tauhou means stranger and this name was given by the Maori when the bird appeared, in 1856, in the central part of Newzealand, gradually spreading north and south till the islands were occupied. It is an Australian bird, and was blown across the Tasman sea in the year mentioned.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Vol / Page:  176

Notes:

Date:  6/6/1988
Source:  Dominion Sunday Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  `Pakeha' is a word that seems to be bugging many New Zealanders. Perhaps this is the reason why the Royal Commission on Social Policy in its booklet dealing with the Treaty of Waitangi uses the word `Tauiwi' instead of `Pakeha'. For example a section of the booklet is headed `Partnership between Maori and Tauiwi'. Tauiwi, according to the booklet's glossary, means `later settlers from another country'. A Dictionary of the Maori Language ... gives `strange tribe, foreign race' as the meaning of Tauiwi. As a New Zealander born and bred in this country I was disturbed at the unceremonious use of a word which seems to make me some sort of foreigner in my own land. ... On phoning the commission's office I was informed that despite considerable unease over the use of Tauiwi in the treaty booklet staff were told that it had to be used. I was also informed that the use of Tauiwi instead of Pakeha had been discontinued.
Notes:

Crawford, who presented a sample of ground coffee made from these seeds to the Wellington Philosophical Society in 1877. 'The beans .. 'he wrote,' when roasted and ground have a splendid coffee aroma and when made into coffee the results seem to be thoroughly satisfactory.'

taura here
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: urban grouping within an iwi
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: -
Pronunciation:
Notes: (from tpk.govt.nz) Due to the large population and land area, TRAION has implemented Takiwa (natural geographical groupings) to assist with the management of issues relating to the population and the marae that fall into the Ngâpuhi catchment area. There are also two Taurahere (urban groupings) since 80% of the tribe live outside the traditional Ngâpuhi boundaries (40% in Auckland alone). The TRAION structure is grassroots focussed with the marae and all who whakapapa to these marae being the main drivers for the vision, and for the tribal immortality of Ngâpuhi.

Citations
Date:  3/11/2005
Source:  Horowhenua Mail
Author:
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:

Date:  0/0/1899
Source:  Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  VII/87
Edition:
Quote:  [Hdg] "Tauranga" or "Bush Disease". This peculiar wasting disease, which is confined to the tract of land lying in the vicinity of Tauranga, and extending from there to Rotorua and Lichfield, was made the subject of an investigation by Mr. Park three years ago... It appears that both sheep and cattle will do well and put on condition for the first few months after being placed on this diseased country, but as time goes on a gradual wasting sets in, which ends in death if they are not removed to another district.
Notes:

Date:  15/4/1891
Source:  Bay of Plenty Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  It would seem that to deal thoroughly with the matter much more time and research will have to be given to it, than the examination of a few sheep or lambs can accomplish, though done by as able an expert as Professor Thomas; whose instructions, as to parasitical disease, seem to have been carried out as well as opportunity allowed, and yet disclosed nothing specially distinct in the Tauranga disease.

Date:  0/0/1951
Source:  Witch's Thorn, The
Author:  PARK
Vol / Page:  176
Edition:
Quote:  ... a mob of little boys had their tails up over a marble game. ... they fired their taws, green and blue and brilliant yellow, at the squares richly lined with the weatherbeaten old clay soldiers which sold at twelve a penny and were known as dakes. thought to be spelled <i>tor</i> [common G. Kennedy]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  174
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at.<i>Ibid.</I> 176 [Waitara, Taranaki, 1899]

A `taw' was usually an `alley' or `blood alley' made of agate. We used to take them home and burn them in a fire to convert them into `blood alleys'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1951
Source:  Witch's Thorn, The
Author:  PARK
Vol / Page:  176
Edition:
Quote:  Some of them spat in the pathway of an opposing taw and cried 'Mississippi!' while others chanted, with deadly unselfconsciousness: 'Shut up, button yer lip, cork yer eye with a juniper pip! If you listen to this, you are bound to miss, miss, miss!'


Notes:

Quote:  With red faces and eyes bulging with an afternoon of stooping, they fired their taws, green and blue and brilliant yellow, at the squares richly lined with the weatherbeaten old clay soldiers which sold at twelve a penny and were known as dakes.

tawa
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a general name for various species  [Maori] <i>Beilschmiedia tawa</i>, a forest tree, its timber, and its fruit (tawa-berry)


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: aka tower.   [?d] Ed. Fairburn Maharatanga 47f. ... his bunch of towers.

Date:  0/0/1848
Source:  Handbook for New Zealand, The
Author:  WAKEFIELD
Vol / Page:  142
Edition:
Quote:  9. Tawai, (<i>Leiospermum racemosum</i>.) This tree has a rough, dark-brown bark, and a small round leaf, in shape like that of an elm. The wood is particularly well adapted for ship-building, and for the staves of barrels, and is commonly called `black birch' by the sailors and other Europeans acquainted with it.

Date:  0/0/1872
Source:  Edible Fishes
Author:  SHERRIN
Vol / Page:  112
Edition:
Quote:  MACKEREL ... This valuable fish (<i>Scomber australasicus</i>) is only known to me from ... Wellington Harbour about the 15th December, 1870, but it appears to be the fish that is called by the natives Tawa-tawa. In colour, size, and form it closely approaches the common Mackerel of England, and is very superior in delicacy to the Scad or Horse Mackerel, which is commonly called the Mackerel in New Zealand.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1886
Source:  Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author:  SHERRIN
Vol / Page:  61
Edition:
Quote:  MACKEREL (<I>Scomber Australasicus</I>). ... This valuable fish is well known as an occasional visitant in Wellington Harbour, being called by the Natives tawatawa. In colour, size, and form it closely approaches the common mackerel of England, and is very superior in delicacy to the scad or horse-mackerel, which is commonly called the mackerel in New Zealand.

Date:  0/0/1883
Source:  Handbook of New Zealand
Author:  HECTOR
Vol / Page:  125
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Nothofagus fusca,</i> Hook. Tawhai Tawhairaunui, Black-birch of Auckland and Otago (from colour of bark), Red-birch of Wellington and Nelson (from colour of timber). --This is a noble tree 60-90 feet high the trunk 5-8 feet in diameter. The timber is excessively tough and hard to cut. It is highly valued in Nelson and Wellington. ... <i>Nothofagus menziesii</i>, Hook. Tawhai, Red-birch (from the colour of the bark). --A handsome tree, 80-100 feet high; trunk 2-3 feet in diameter. The timber is chiefly used in the lake district of the South Island.

Author:
Vol / Page:  262
Edition:
Quote:  The formation is chiefly Upper Palaeozoic and Upper Mesozoic rocks. 244,000 acres, mainly in the back country, are covered with bush, chiefly tawhai, tawhai rauriki, and tawhai raunui, the last being found along the shores of Lake Sumner and the banks of the Hurunui River, and, with the exception of the tawhai raunui, is of little value for timber purposes.

Date:  0/0/1906
Source:  Manual NZ Flora
Author:  CHEESEMAN
Vol / Page:  640
Edition:
Quote:  <i>F. Menziesii, Hook.f.</i> ... A tall forest-tree 60-80 ft. ... high; ... bark white or silvery, expecially in young trees; ... [641] <i>Tawhai; Tawai; Silver-birch; Red-birch</i>. ... The wood is dark-red ... but is not durable when exposed to the weather. <i>Ibid.</I> 643 <i>F. Solandri, Hook.f.</i> ... A lofty forest-tree 40-60 ft. high; ... bark black ... in old trees ... pale and smooth on young ones; ... Leaves ... clothed with an appressed greyish-white pubescence beneath ... usually in hilly or mountain districts. ... <i>Tawhai; Tawhai-rauriki; Black-birch; White-birch.</i> ... Wood pale-red, often streaked with black, not durable ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Popular Names
Author:  ANDERSEN
Vol / Page:  57/905
Edition:
Quote:   ... In my introductory essay ... T.W. Kirk was quoted on the singular exception in the case of the beeches, which the Maori seemed to class together as tawhai adding, perhaps, in our own manner, a descriptive modifying word or words, as tawhairaunui for the large-leaved beech. The recent studies of Dr. L. Cockayne (NZ State Forest Service, Bulletin No4, 1926), show that in this, too, the Maori was right ; the rigid specific distinction did not exist: As in Hebe (Veronica) there is much hybridization. ... and as the Veronicas were all Koromiko to the Maori, so the varieties of Nothofagus were all tawhai.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/146
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tawai</i> (as tawhai), a tree (Nothofagus spp.), beech; wrongly called birch; Tawai-raunui and tawai rauriki recognized as species by Maori and Pakeha alike: there are also hybrids: Also called tawhai.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in

Edition:  1963
Quote:   ... a kind of Lily a sort of Parasitical Plant ... [Blank space left for drawing with caption `Tawara Astilia Angustifolia'] <I>IbidD.</I> 91 [1963 fn 39 p 35] The drawing shows a large tree ... bearing, on the branches clumps of Astelia which Markham, following Yate, has erroneously labelled `Tawara Astilia Angustifolia'. `Tawara' is a rendering of <i>`tawhara',</i> the Maori name for the fruit of ... <i>Freycinetia banksii (kiekie) </i>..

Quote:  We went out into the bush after <i>tawharas</i> this week. This is the fruit of the <i>kia kia</i>, a parasite which climbs and adheres to the dead trees. The Maoris make excellent hats resembling the celebrated `cabbage-tree' hats, from the fibre of the leaves.
Notes:  c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 135

Date:  0/0/1905
Source:  Where the White Man Treads
Author:  BAUCKE
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  Aye, and kie kie also, with its two kinds of sweetmeats, both on the same vine - the first at, and before Christmas, when the plant distills its nectar juices, and collects them in that bunch of tender succulence of fleshly leaflets the Maori called tawhara - the very name is maddening to think of! - and later, in winter, when its fruits, shaped like a corncob studded with the heads of translucent amber! Ah me!
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1906

Vol / Page:  135

Quote:  in error for the TOWAI (W silvicola) WEINMANNIA SILVICOLA (<i>Banks & Sol</i>.) ... The `TOWAI'.- ... The wood is similar in quality to its ally <i>W. racemosa</i>, but is denser, and of finer grain; ... [136] This tree is sometimes called Tawhero, or Kamai, and is not unusually confounded with <i>W. racemosa</i>, the Tawhero or Kamai proper. In the same manner the tawhero is confused with this species by the uninitiated.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/146
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tawhiri,</i> a tree (Pittosporum tenuifolium); so called because small branches were broken off to wave welcome while calling out haeremai to approaching visitors: tawhiri means to beckon. The tree has smallish chocolate-coloured flowers very fragrant in summer evenings and nights, when the bowers of the trees too are a-flutter with the visiting lady-moths: also called ko[o]hu[u]hu[u] and tawhiwhi.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1966

Quote:  The Telecommunications Carriers’ Forum (TCF) plays a vital role in the New Zealand telecommunications industry by working collaboratively on the development of key industry standards and codes of practice that underpin the digital economy.



The TCF works with a wide variety of industry participants and government agencies to promote competition and investment in the sector, accelerate the introduction of new generation services, and encourage excellence in customer service.

Quote:  <I>Chatham Island Taiko Pterodroma magentae</I> (GIGLIOLI & SALVADORI, 1868) ... However, this extremely rare bird is hardly ever seen. ... OTHER NAMES: <I>Magenta petrel, tchaik of the Moriori. </I>

Vol / Page:  Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 358

Quote:  ... the most important [Chatham Island] edible sea-birds: AS WRITTEN AS PRONOUNCED ENGLISH hopo ho[macron]p' albatross hakoakoa ha[macron]ko[macron]k' mutton bird taiko tchai[macron]k' pied shear water tupoupou tchu[macron]poup' pied blue billie reoreo ro[macron]ro[macron] Mother Carys chicken turiwati tchu[macron]riwat' dottrel [sic] kuaka ku[macron]k' snipe Notes 1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs 358

tchakat Mai-hor-r
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: the form used frequently by Baucke for Moriori
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1928
Source:  BP Bishop Memoirs
Author:  SKINNER & BAUCKE
Vol / Page:  9(5):357
Edition:
Quote:  Unlike the Maori, the Moriori had no name for his race. When questioned, he answered: `tchakat Mai-hor-r.' This not having the assonance of Maori speech, this purist changed it to `tangata Moriori' (Moriori man); by which name the race became known to common use.
Notes:  1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 357

Author:
Vol / Page:  A2
Edition:
Quote:  But there was concern at how a finding in the High Court of a Territorial Customary Right (TCR) would be given effect, and Government MPs were looking at ways to give the courts some guidelines. A TCR is a collection of customary rights that would have amounted to full customary  and fee simple title if the new law had not asserted Crown ownership.

Region: [none]

Pronunciation:
Notes: (from glossary at educationcounts.edcentre.govt.nz) Te Aho Matua is a philosophy specifically developed for 'kura' schools. Te Aho Matua describes the principles for operation and for teaching in kura. (literally 'the main line'?)

Te Ika a Maui
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the traditional Maori name for the North Island (occasionally in former use for New Zealand as a whole), literally ‘the fish of Maui.
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/10/2000
Source:  NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page:  4 : 2
Edition:
Quote:  In present-day use <i>Aotearoa</i> is the accepted Maori name of the whole country and the North Island is <i>Te Ika a Maui</i> (Maui's fish). However, just as <i>Aotearoa</i> was used in the past of the North Island, so <i>Te Ika a Maui</i> has occasionally referred to the whole country. When Maori activist Titewhai Harawira went to the Netherlands in 1990.. she was reportedly advocating <i>Te Ika a Maui</i> and not <i>Aotearoa</i> as an indigenous replacement.
Notes:

Date:  31/3/1770
Source:  Cook's Journals
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/288
Edition:  1955
Quote:  There are some small difference [sic] in the Language spoke by the <I>Aehei-no mouweans</i> and those of <I>Tovy poe nammu </i>but this difference seem'd to me to be only in the pronunciation and is no more than what we find between one part of England and other: ...
Notes:  (Te Ika a Maui-an);North Island(er) 1773 Cook Journal 2/68 -->[see kumara]

Quote:  Chants that emphasized the points of a weighty speech in the runanga-house, short ditties that maidens carolled forth about the pa, war songs that fired the hearts of warriors on the march—these were heard through the length and breadth of Te Ika-a-Maui, Maori poets vieing one with another to compose songs suitable for the occasion.
Notes:  Royal Tour number

Quote:  In the Ngati Toa <i>pa</i> there was great indignation, and Te Rauparaha, their fighting chief, gathering together a war party, surprised and killed Te Uira and anothee Waikato chief, Te Aomarama. <i>Ibid.</i> 18 The acquisition of firearms from the whalers and flax-traders at Kapiti encouraged Te Rauparaha to embark on the conquest of the South Island. The story of these raids constitutes a perfect Iliad.

Te Reinga
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:

Tea plant Manuka <i>L. scoparium </I> <i>Ibid.</I> 2/138 The Tea Plant is a shruby tree which grows on dry soil near the shores, it bears a small leafe of which this [...] is the natural size, small white flowers and small [cones] which contain the seeds ... . [It is also] a substitute for tea, this we found out last voyage ... .

Date:  0/0/1883
Source:  Ranolf and Amohia
Author:  DOMETT
Vol / Page:  1/303
Edition:
Quote:  Ma'nuka .... <i>O</i>. Myrtaceae; <i>G</i>. Leptospermum; <i>S</i>. or L. ericoides. `A large shrub or small tree; leaves used as tea in Tasmania and Australia, where the plant is equally abundant.' In the poem it is called indiscriminately manuka, broom, broom-like myrtle, or leptosperm. The settlers often call it `tea-broom.'

Quote:  <I>Teak, n.</I> The original Teak is an East Indian timber-tree, <i>Tectina grandis</i>, but the name has been trasferred to other trees in different parts of the world, from a similarity in the hardness of their wood. ... In New Zealand, it is <I>Vitex littoralis</I>; Maori name, <i>Puriri</i> (q.v.).

team
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: sc of sheep-dogs
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Team:</I> Each shepherd's dogs. He may have anything from two to eight. Usually in large teams only three are much use. The rest are for sale or being broken in.

The distinction between<i> team</i> and <i>pack</i> (rabbit pack q.v.) was general in Canterbury until a few years ago [from 1933]; but several North Canterbury correspondents have told me that many of the younger shepherds now speak of their sheepdogs as a

<i>pack. </i>
Notes:   Acland

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Wayleggo
Author:  NEWTON
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  [gloss.] A shepherd refers to his dogs as his team. An ideal high-country team would be one heading dog, two handy dogs, and two huntaways. Or alternatively, two heading dogs, one handy dog and two huntaways. <I>Ibid.</I> 23 I loosened my `team' of two dogs.

team
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: [farming in general] a group of dogs owned by a single owner, or working in a group e.g. a rabbiting team of dogs, a mustering team etc.

teaser
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a steer kept on a bull-farm to stimulate the bulls into ejaculation to collect semen for artificial insemination; an animal which cannot get a female pregnant, used to test which females are on heat: either an entire male animal prevented by various means, such as vasectomy, tieing on an apron, etc., or a female treated with male sex hormone to make her act like a male
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Source:  MAF Agricultural Glossary

Vol / Page:  13

Treating a female with male hormone to sexually activate her and make her act like a male ...Tie an apron on an entire male which prevents his penis entering the female when he mounts ... .

tea-tree
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a scrubby bush, manuka (Leptospernum spp), often used to add flavour to billy tea.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]

tea-tree jack
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: stick insect


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1902
Source:  Land of the Lost
Author:  SATCHELL
Vol / Page:  215
Edition:
Quote:  [note] `Animated straws'. Sometimes the Straw or Teatree Straw Insect, usually the New Zealand Stick Insect or (formerly) Walking Stick Insect also known as the Teatree Jack, <i>Acanthodemus horridus </i>of Hudson (1892). Thin, segmented, attenuated fine legs; capable of camouflage by colour change. Satchell refers to this at the end of the paragraph.
Notes:  1971 Smithyman in 1902 Satchell Land of the Lost 215

Quote:  now we had realised that the Italian name for Germans was Tedeschi, so of course we had nicknamed them `The Teds'. Our nickname had absolutely no reference to Tedeschi at all, but merely was a shortening of `shitheads'. We derived great pleasure from looking at one another and saying, `Well, the Teds have cleared off,' or `The Teds have done this' or whatever had happened.

tee
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a fence-post
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1951 R. Gilberd (Okaihau) [?definition] 2. <i>`Swinging T' </i>- a foot with a length of wire attached which is either stapled to the post above the ground or twisted onto the bottom wire. 3. <i>`Anchored T' -</i> similar to a `swinging T', but no post is used. The anchor wire is twisted around each wire in turn, holding them at correct elevation. It is used where posts have to be packed to the fence-line, e.g. in the Gisborne district.

Edition:
Quote:  To sum up briefly, a male is tuakana to all his younger brothers and teina to all his older brothers. ... If there are any daughters in the family, they follow the same principle, being tuakana to all their younger sisters and teina to their older sisters.

telegraph pole
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a pole supporting telegraph or electric power lines or wires
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim writes: This is defined in Chambers and Macquarie in the literal sense of a pole supporting telegraph wires. There is not entry in Collins. NSOD refers to "telegraph or telephone wires". In NZ the term was widely used informally also in relation to electric power lines (=<i>power pole</i>) (I cannot remember ever having seen telegraph lines in the strict sense). Does this loose use persist?

Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  Shock of '31, The

Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  Multi-storey commercial buildings at Napier and Hastings view with telegraph poles in swaying to the extremes.

Vol / Page:  52

This <i>teletangi</i> was the first to be done by the Maori but I think it will become crucial to keeping families connected in death and life.

tena koe
Homonym Number:
Word Class: exclamation
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
tena koe
Homonym Number:
Word Class: exclamation
Sense Number:
Definition: tena koe	1	23	1	a common form of Maori greeting (to one person) various early spg the [a[a]] has given rise to the usual anglicisation [te|naakwe; to greet with <i>tena koe </i>, sometimes used as a greeting by Pakeha, becoming (with KIA ORA) more frequent from c1975-1980 after about 50-60 years of infrequent use.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Compare tena koutou katoa. [Maori tena[e,a-macron] koe]

Vol / Page:  3/4/162
Edition:
Quote:  But inasmuch as we only knew Maori enough to the extent of being able to say, <i>`Tena koe?</i>' (`How do you do?'), and as that terminated our conversational powers in their vernacular, nothing then was left us but to stare at each other.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  466
Edition:
Quote:  <i>a Maori salutation used in North Island of New Zealand. Lit. `That is you,' and meaning `How do you do?' Tena</i> and <i>Tera</i> both mean <i>`that'</i>; but <i>tena</i> implies the idea of nearness, `that near you,' <i>tera</i> the idea of distance, `that (or there) away younder.' Hence, while Tena koe is a welcome, Tera koe would be an insult.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1906
Source:  Treasury of NZ Verse
Author:  ALEXANDER & CURRIE
Vol / Page:  289
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Tenakoe</i>: a word of greeting.

ten-acre block
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a hobby farm, or a semi-rural lifestyle property where emphasis may be on lifestyle rather than land production. [In some local body areas, a ten acre block represented the minimum area for optimal small-property production.]

tennikoit
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a game of catching and returning quoits across a tennis net or taut wire at waist height
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim writes This word (and the game it signifies, although one can guess its nature, are new to me. It is not in any dictionary I have seen... Possibly proprietary, possibly of brief currency (cf<I>taipo</I> as the name of a game from about the same period, possibly distinctive NZE. DEH notes : I know this from St Pat's Silverstream where it was played in the quadrangle on areas marked out as in tennis with doubles and singles lines; it is probably still played there today.

tens
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:

Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  History of Children's Play
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  273
Edition:
Quote:  Ball-bouncing games have come into their own on the asphalt playgrounds of modern schools and are played in many schools throughout the country. There is no evidence of such games before 1900, but a number of instances between 1900 and 1920 are recorded. The games were known as Fives, Tens, Sevens, and Walls and have been recorded more often since under the names O'Leary or Sevens. Before 1920 there is only one report of the game being played with a rhyme, and this was a rhyme more often used in skipping.

Notes:

Date:  0/7/1986
Source:  New Outlook
Author:
Vol / Page:  28
Edition:
Quote:  The Whakarewa Grant was part of what was called the `tenth', a term coined by the New Zealand Company for land it reserved for Maori people. The principle of the tenths was conveyed in the instructions from the New Zealand Company in 1839 to its principal agent, Colonel William Wakefield, before he set out for New Zealand. In `every purchase of land from the natives ... a proportion of the territory ceded will be reserved by the Company and held in trust by them for the future benefit of the chief families of the tribe ... `You will explain that after English immigration and settlement a tenth of the land will be far more valuable than the whole was before'. ... To Alexander MacKay, commissioner of Native Lands, writing in 1872, the tenths `guarded the natives that common failing of all Aboriginal races, want of foresight, and it secured them from the dangers to which colonisation exposed them'. In short, land was a better asset for the Maoris than cash. In Nelson, the `tenth' comprised a total of 15,000 acres of land, involving a mix of urban and rural land in Nelson, Motueka, and Golden Bay. Most of that land remains in Maori ownership and today is managed by an incorporation. The Whakarewa land - the most valuable area of the tenth - has however been subverted from the control of the ...


Notes:

Date:  0/6/2003
Source:  Wel-com (Wellington)
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  [Colonel William Wakefield] set about negotiating the purchase of some 160,000 acres and in Septmeber 1839 a deed of purpose, written in English, was signed by 16 local chiefs. It provided that one tenth of the land purchased would be reserved for the Maori owners of the Land... No proper explanation was given to Maori of the 'tenths' reserve scheme, nor were they made aware that the deed of purchase made no provision for the retention by Maori of their pa, cultivations, and burial grounds.
Notes:

Date:  6/9/1899

Vol / Page:  5

tenure review
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an exchange of some Crown-leased land for conservation purposes, for freehold title to the remainder of a leased property.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  12/7/2003
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  It's called "tenure review", an unremarkable term for a remarkable transformation now taking place in our legendary South Island high country. In exchange for giving up the scenic and uneconomic parts of their land for a massive conservation estate, pastoral lease holders get freehold title to the rest of their property. [18] Currently, the main way of achieving it [sc. taking land for the conservation estate]is known as tenure review; a huge land swap inside the pastoral leases that make up 20 percent of the South Island and 10 percent of New Zealand.
Notes:

Date:  0/6/2007
Source:  Conservation Action

Author:
Vol / Page:  6
Edition:
Quote:  High-country farmers are quietly opting for tenure review because many are likely to become wealthy from what is [7] one of the best real estate deals in New Zealand in the last 50 years... I suspect that history will judge tenure review as not such a great idea for farmning or the public... What should have happened is a careful review of the pastoral lease system to maintain this unique form of land tenure, with adjustments to assist farmers to diversify and to protect uneconomic land.

This is a well-known arrangement in the colonies, under the name of `keeping stock on terms', and is very general, and ... the most advisable [230] plan for persons who cannot conveniently reside on a station of their own at a distance from a town
Notes:

Date:  2/10/1860
Source:  First Year in Canterbury Settlement
Author:  BUTLER
Vol / Page:  4/36
Edition:
Quote:  Everyone suggests different investments. One says buy sheep and put them out on terms. I will explain to you what this means. I can buy a thousand ewes ..., these I should place in charge of a squatter whose run is not fully stocked ... This person would take my sheep for either three, ... or more years, ... and would allow me yearly <I>2s. 6d.</I> per head in lieu of wool. This would give me <i>2s. 6d</i>. as the yearly interest on <I>25s. Besides this he would allow me 40 per cent. per annum of increase, ...; moreover, the increase would return me 2s. 6d.</I> per head wool money as soon a they became sheep. At the end of the term, my sheep would be returned to me as per agreement, ... sheep of the same age as [any who have died] would have been will be returned in their place.
Notes:

Date:  25/3/1865
Source:  Chudleigh Diary
Author:
Vol / Page:  170
Edition:  1950
Quote:  [My sheep] are on for one year less 40% less 3% deaths, 2/6 wool money. ... Sheep on terms are not what they used to be ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1888
Source:  Wakatipians
Author:  DUNCAN
Vol / Page:  64
Edition:
Quote:  [In 1862] Mr Switzer bought some few hundred sheep ... which were `running on terms' with Mr Rees.
Notes:

Date:  25/11/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Sheep on terms</i>. A favourite investment in the fifties and sixties. A man bought ewes and handed them over to a runholder whose run was understocked and who had not money to buy sheep. The runholder allowed the owner of the ewes 2s 6d a head a year for their wool and marked 40 per cent. of lambs for the owner as well; or they shared the increase equally. When the ewe lambs became old enough they were bred from as well, so that by the end of the time arranged (anything from three to seven years) the owner had a much larger mob to sell than he had started with. The practice was so much in vogue that in 1863 C.M. Ollivier published a pamphlet computing the interest and profit of <i>s. o. t.</i> at the various lengths of time. The last of such agreements at Horsley Down ran out in 1870 (H. D. letter book) and these are the latest I have found any record of. `I must confess to be fairly puzzled to know what to do with the money you have sent me. Everyone suggests different investments. One says buy sheep put them out on terms.' --[Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 37, where there is a good description of the business too long to quote.
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  25/11/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Sheep on terms</i>. A favourite investment in the fifties and sixties. A man bought ewes and handed them over to a runholder whose run was understocked and who had not money to buy sheep. The runholder allowed the owner of the ewes 2s 6d a head a year for their wool and marked 40 per cent. of lambs for the owner as well; or they shared the increase equally. When the ewe lambs became old enough they were bred from as well, so that by the end of the time arranged (anything from three to seven years) the owner had a much larger mob to sell than he had started with. The practice was so much in vogue that in 1863 C.M. Ollivier published a pamphlet computing the interest and profit of <i>s. o. t.</i> at the various lengths of time. The last of such agreements at Horsley Down ran out in 1870 (H. D. letter book) and these are the latest I have found any record of. `I must confess to be fairly puzzled to know what to do with the money you have sent me. Everyone suggests different investments. One says buy sheep put them out on terms.' --[Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 37, where there is a good description of the business too long to quote.

Notes: the requirement of attendance and satisfactory completion of set work as a pre-requisite to sitting final degree examinations; usu in phr 'keep terms' or 'fail terms'; transferred from 'term' as division of academic year.

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Animals of NZ, The
Author:  NATUSCH
Vol / Page:  267
Edition:
Quote:  Family STERNIDAE (terns). The graceful white-fronted tern <i>(Sterna striata, ... )</i> is seen in all New Zealand bays ... The somewhat stumpier black-fronted tern (<i>Chlidonias hybrida albostriatus, </i>... ) is common on South Island shingle flats ... The large Caspian tern (<i>Hydroprogne caspia</i>, ... ) is a large tern that includes New Zealand ... in its world-wide breeding range ... The rarest tern breeding in New Zealand is the fairy tern <i>(Sterna nereis,) </i>reported from Lake Ellesmere in 1944, and breeding also, sparingly, in Northland and a few other places.
Notes:

Vol / Page:  13

Date:  0/3/1860

Author:  BUTLER
Vol / Page:  v/62
Edition:
Quote:  I had to cross the Waimakiriri just after a fresh, ... and I assure you I did not like it. I crossed it first on the plains, where it flows between two very high terraces ... of which the most northern must be ... 300 feet high. <i>Ibid.</I> vii/96 The terraces, which are so abundant all over the back country, and which rise, one behind another, to the number, it may be, of twenty or thirty, with the most unpicturesque regularity (on my run there are fully twenty), are supposed to be elevated sea-beaches. They are to be seen even as high as four or five thousand feet above the level of the sea, and I doubt not that a geologist might find traces of them higher still.

A flat means a plain, but it is a rare thing to gallop along a flat for more than a mile without coming across a terrace, which terrace may be only six feet high, or it may be a hundred ... [and] is certain to be as regular as if it formed part of some ornamental ground.

Homonym Number:

Sense Number:

Origin: [none]

Quote:  Those of us who had received training as Territorials were asked to-day whether we would care for stripes.

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author:  McLINTOCK
Vol / Page:  1/384
Edition:
Quote:  The Defence Act of 1909 created The <I>Territorial Force; ... </I>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A
Author:  LELAND
Vol / Page:  102
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Territorials</I>: The army RESERVES, weekend warriors, not to mention a fortnight in January.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  Gallipoli: the New Zealand Story
Author:  PUGSLEY
Vol / Page:  38
Edition:
Quote:  The organisation had been outlined by Field Marshal Lord Kitchener on a visit to New Zealand in 1910. All New Zealanders from the ages of 14 to 30 years were liable for part-time military training. Boys from 14 to 18 years served in the senior cadets, and young men from 18 to 25 years served as Territorial soldiers with the regionally affiliated regiments and battalions - hence the name `Territorial'. Service in the reserve was a requirement from the age of 25 to 30, but legislation allowed for this service to be extended up to the age of 55 years in the case of a national emergency. The same legislation allowed the Territorial Force to be mobilised by proclamation for service in New Zealand, and Section 26 (1) of the 1909 Defence Act made provision for members of the Territorial Force to volunteer for special service outside New Zealand.
Notes:

tewhatewha
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a long axe-like Maori weapon, usually of wood and having both blade and sharpened handle.


Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/159
Edition:
Quote:  <I>tewhatewha,</I> a weapon with a terminal broad semi-crescent of one side, the other end sharpened for thrusting, the lower side of the crescent pierced with a hole for attachment of a small tuft of feathers, such as pigeon-feathers, the weapon being largely used in oratory.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

that'll be the day
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: expressing doubt, disapproval, etc., of a statement or request; used ironically for something most unlikely to happen.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: also that will be the day; (cf. 1867 Lady Barker Station Life (1874) 113 [a cockie speaks] `Ah but it'll be a far day first [before I'll believe that].) ca1935 at least e.g. `I thought you were at church.' `That'll be the day.' `That'll be the day when you see me there.'

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author:  TURNER
Vol / Page:  177
Edition:
Quote:  <i>That'll be the day,</i> a way of expressing a strong disinclination to do something, was unknown to visiting Americans during the war, one of whom thought it expressed gay anticipation and answered `That'll be the day' when asked to visit a New Zealand family. The expression was worked to death and in its dying agonies produced some contortions as <i>That'll be the frosty Friday</i> etc.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  112
Edition:
Quote:  <i>That'll be the day</i> c/p expressing doubt or incredulity; NZ since 1930s, widespread elsewhere; also, <i>that'll be the bloody day, boy! </I>

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author:  TURNER
Vol / Page:  177
Edition:
Quote:  <i>That'll be the day</i>, a way of expressing a strong disinclination to do something, was unknown to visiting Americans during the war, one of whom thought it expressed gay anticipation and answered `That'll be the day' when asked to visit a New Zealand family. The expression was worked to death and in its dying agonies produced some contortions as <i>That'll be the frosty Friday </i>etc.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  112
Edition:
Quote:  <i>that'll be the frosty Friday/frozen fortnight </I> Kiwi variants of `that'll be the day', which Partridge thinks derives from WWI officer usage.

they're off, Mr Cutts
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author:  McLINTOCK
Vol / Page:  3/58
Edition:
Quote:  In 1875 G.G.Stead (1841-1908), the famous race-horse owner, bought a half-share in Redwood's racing stud. Under the partnership agreement Stead managed the business side while the training was put in the hands of E. Cutts. The horses were raced in the name of one or other of the partners. This arrangement, which proved immensely successful, lasted into the 1890s and was terminated when Stead bought out Redwood's share of the stud. During his lifetime Henry Redwood was known as `the Father of the New Zealand Turf.'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1960
Source:  Memories of Maoriland
Author:  SCRYMGEOUR
Vol / Page:  60
Edition:
Quote:  One student [of Canterbury Agricultural College], ... the son of a sporting and well-known racing baronet of North Canterbury, would take Jim into the stables at `Cutts' to see the horses in training; ...
Notes:

Date:  4/11/1911
Source:  NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page:  332/6/4
Edition:
Quote:  They're off, Mr Cutts!' At least, they will be about three o'clock today (Saturday), and in less than four minutes afterwards, you will all know whether you have lost your money or not.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1943
Source:  English as it is spoken in NZ
Author:  BENNETT
Vol / Page:  90
Edition:
Quote:  Horse-racing, another popular pastime (including trotting races, or <i>the trots</i>) provides two colloquialisms which need explanation. The exclamation `They're off, Mr Cutts!', announcing that any contest or affair has begun, contains the name of a one-time popular starter at the Auckland races.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author:  McLINTOCK
Vol / Page:  2/680
Edition:
Quote:  Examples of slang and colloquial expressions of local origin are ... <i>they're off Mr Cutts,</i> for `the performance is about to start',...
Notes:  Wall NZ Speech

Date:  0/0/1941
Source:  NZ Slang
Author:  BAKER
Vol / Page:  50
Edition:
Quote:  ...they're off Mr Cutts!, meaning `things have started!' and or `now we're getting down to business!'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1949
Source:  Dictionary of Slang Addenda
Author:  PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page:  1200
Edition:
Quote:  <i>They're off, Mr Cutts</i>. is a C. 20 New Zealand shape (B., 1941) cf:- [monkey]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  112
Edition:
Quote:  <i>they're off, Mr Cutts!</i> the race has begun; Partridge identifies as a variant of `they're off', said the monkey', usually indicating start of a horse race, hence as something that has come loose; often with addition: `when he looked into the lawnmower and carelessly lost his testicles.' This addition may explain Mr Cutts. NZA.
Notes:

Date:  25/1/1908
Source:  NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  “They’re off, Mr Cutts!”   Heaven only knows where the expression originated, but elderly Ted Cutts, Clifford’s trainer, who is the person mentioned, was at Trentham, with his white hair trailing in the breeze.
Notes:

Date:  4/5/1921
Source:  Ashburton Guardian
Author:
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  THEY’RE OFF, MR CUTTS!!   What’s that left?   Kennaquhair?   No, that’s Kennaquhair out in front, with Poitrel!
Notes:

they're off...

Edition:
Quote:  <I>Thickeners</I>: The vacuum thickeners were canvas-covered frames which allowed the water to be drawn off by reduced pressure inside the frames, thus thickening the pulp and requiring less cyanide to treat it. They worked in a similar manner to the vacuum filter-baskets.

think one is Christmas
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: to have a high (sometimes undeserved) opinion of oneself
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1938 at least, in Havelock: used by older women. She thinks she's Christmas in her new hat. 1922 Heard then in Pukekoke from one who came from the Hutt Valley. Was quite a new expression to us then and I do not recollect hearing it in Auckland.

See:

Citations
Date:  13/5/2004
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  C2
Edition:
Quote:  Over at National Party Central they have developed a code for those, ahem, awkward issues. They call them "third rail policies"... National's "third rail" is not a new policy alternative but a warning to its own politicians. The third rail on a railway track is the live one, the dangerous one. Touch its political equivalent and you risk a nasty electoral shock from the voting public... The politics of the third rail are simple: avoid, downplay or defuse issues for which the majority of the public has no stomach, even if the party and its MPs think they are desirable.
Notes:

Source:  Dominion Post

this side
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: sc. of the Tasman; New Zealand (a response to THE OTHER SIDE, Australia)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  Australian aborigine words which were new to this side. In 1851 a number of Australian `squatters' came over and took up runholding in Canterbury, but, generally speaking, their advent was some years later in Otago. ... They brought over a number of Australian aborigine words that were new to this side, and which were used a certain amount, usually in a joking manner as far as I know. I have heard some of them fairly frequently used by the `old hands,' sometimes oracularly and sometimes as a semi-humorous quotation. When I was a boy I heard sheep called `jumbucks,' an Australian aborigine term for them, but with the decease of ex-Australian stockmen the word has gone out of use now. Another term brought over from Australia was `maimai,' for a rough shelter from the weather. It was said to be a name for a blackfellow's camp, which I have always seen spelt `miamia,' and which is called `gunyah' or `wurley,' etc., by some tribes. We now apply the name to shooting shelters.
Notes:

thistle
Homonym Number:  1

thistle

Sense Number: 2

Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (R. Mason) Hilgendorf - at Akaroa
Citations
Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HILGENDORF
Vol / Page:  192
Edition:  1967
Quote:  MILK THISTLE (<i>Silybum marianum</i>), sometimes called St. Mary's thistle, variegated or spotted thistle, and, near Akaroa, French thistle ... It is abundant in scattered localities in both islands, sometimes forming dense masses. It is an annual or biennial, grows up to 6 ft. in height, and has large leaves without wings.

Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:

Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1968
Source:  Turn of the Tide, The
Author:  JOHNSON
Vol / Page:  74
Edition:
Quote:  On making New Zealand, Cook was pleased to find wild celery growing in profusion as well as `scurvy grass' of the cress family and the native sowthistle, <i>puwha. </i>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HILGENDORF
Vol / Page:  210
Edition:  1967
Quote:  PRICKLY SOUR THISTLE [SOWTHISTLE] (<i>Sonchus asper</i>) is also called rough sour thistle [sowthistle,] and also by its Maori name of Puwha. This is very similar to the former [S.oleraceus, sowthistle] in all respects, except that the margins of the leaves are much more prickly, ... This form seems scarcely as common as the former, though it was found in New Zealand when Cook arrived here.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1969
Source:  Standard Common Names for Weeds
Author:
Vol / Page:  61
Edition:
Quote:  <i>prickly sow thistle</i> [s]<i> Sonchus asper</i> (L.) Hill
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  Weeds of Crops
Author:  TAYLOR
Vol / Page:  90
Edition:
Quote:  PRICKLY SOW THISTLE (<i>Sonchus asper</i>) Annual, like sow thistle, growing in similar places and almost as common. It grows a little taller than sow thistle and has leaves more prickly with a saw-tooth edge.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HILGENDORF
Vol / Page:  210
Edition:  1967
Quote:  PRICKLY SOUR THISTLE [SOWTHISTLE] (<i>Sonchus asper</i>) is also called rough sour thistle [sowthistle,] and also by its Maori name of Puwha. This is very similar to the former [S.oleraceus, sowthistle] in all respects, except that the margins of the leaves are much more prickly, ... This form seems scarcely as common as the former, though it was found in New Zealand when Cook arrived here.

thistle grubber
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:  1

thistle money
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: [1800s] a development entitlement payment available to bush settlers.

Edition:
Quote:   I write to know whether you wish any claim made in respect of your clearing at Hurworth. You would probably be allowed, thistle money at 30/- per acre and rent at 20/- per acre per annum or perhaps less ...
Notes:  Letter in Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers II

thongs
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
