Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  299
Edition:
Quote:  THORNFISH or HORNY <i>Bovichtus variegatus roseopictus</i> Hutton This beautifully marked and coloured fish is sometimes called Horny by boys. Both the common names are derived from the sharp spines which puncture the flesh of one's hands when taking the Thornfish from a net.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Guide
Author:  AYLING
Vol / Page:  274
Edition:  1984
Quote:  <i>THORNFISH </i>(Horny, dragonet) <i>Bovichtus variegatus (Bovichthys variegatus) </i>... The thornfish is a small, cylindrical fish with scaleless body ... There is a distinctive strong spine directed upward and backward on each gill cover behind the eyes. ... Thornfish are common in tidepools ... from the Wellington area southwards ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  PAUL
Vol / Page:
Edition:  117
Quote:  <i>Thornfish Bovichthys variegatus</i> Family Bovichthyidae (thornfishes). Sometimes called horny, or dragonet (which is the name of a similar but unrelated fish). Also occurs off south-east Australia.

thorough brace
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:
Definition:

Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1965
Source:  Otakeho District & School 80th Jubilee 1884-1964
Author:
Vol / Page:  18
Edition:
Quote:  The coach used at the time was a type

known as a "Thorough Brace," which meant

that instead of steel springs the coach

was suspended on several thicknesses of

buffalo leather, which ran from the front

under the body to the back of the coach.

These coaches were in common use

throughout Australia and New Zealand in

the early days of mail coaches. Leather

suspension was used because steel springs

would not stand up to the rough roads.

Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to overwork (anything mechanical, espec. an engine or vehicle) excessively; to work or drive at an excessive pace hence, to overwork or overexploit soil, country, a trapping block, a fishery, etc.; to take more than a sustained yield espec. as a ppl aj <i>thrashed,</i> `overexploited; ruined, done in (mechanically)'

thread fern
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/2001
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 49/76
Edition:
Quote:  Climbing ferns are much less dominant in New Zealand bush than in tropical rainforest, but mokimoki (<i>Microsorum scandens</i>), <i>Rumohra adiantiformis</i> and thread fern (<i>Blechnum filiforme</i>) are common throughout, while jointed fern (<i>Arthropteris tenella</i>) and mangemange (<i>Lygopodium articulatum</i>) are characteristic of the warmer northern forest. The thread fern is an unusual plant, beginning life on the ground where it scrambles around until it finds a trunk to climb.

Register:
Register 2:

See:

Citations
Date:  0/0/1911
Source:  Records of the Canterbury Museum
Author:  WAITE
Vol / Page:  1/197
Edition:
Quote:  Sand Flounder New Zealand Flounder, Patiki, Three corner, Tinplate <i>Rhombosolea plebeia</i>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  191
Edition:
Quote:  NEW ZEALAND SAND-FLOUNDER (PATIKI)  <i>Rhombosolea plebeia</i> (Richardson) ... The common Sand-flounder is known from one end of New Zealand to the other, sometimes by other names in different localities. In Auckland it is known as the Dab.../ Some refer to it as Tinplate or Three Corner; the latter name is derived from its fancied trangular shape but why Tinplate I am at a loss to know. To other than fishermen and those intimately connected with the fishing industry it is just a Flounder. Some say it is Tinplate because when cooked it fills a plate.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:
Quote:  <i>FLOUNDER</i> (four species) (a) Scientific name: (i)  <i>Rhombosolea plebeia</i> (ii) <i>Rhombosolea retiaria</i> (iii) <i>Rhombosolea  tapirina</i> (iv) <i>Rhombosolea  leporina</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Flounder (ii) Freshwater Flounder (iii) Flounder (iv) Yellowbelly Flounder. (c) Other common names: (i) Square, Dab, Plaice, Diamond or Diamond-back, Tin-plate, Three Corners. (ii) Blacks, Black Flounder (iii) Greenback [25 `Not common but occasionally taken in southern waters.'] (iv) Yellow Flounder.
Notes:

Date:  23/7/1986
Source:  Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Author:
Vol / Page:

Vol / Page:  326
Edition:
Quote:  THREEPENNY <I>Gilloblennius tripennis</I>(Bloch and Schneider) THREEPENNY is a small fish and a close relative to the well known Cockabully but is less abundant though often taken for the latter fish.

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Animals of NZ, The
Author:  NATUSCH
Vol / Page:  229
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Gilloblennius tripennis</I>... is exceptional [among cockabully] in being evenly coloured. Its popular name - `threepenny' - looks like a broken-down version of `tripennis', i.e. three-winged, a reference to the dorsal fin.

Quote:  He was up about Waimate working fairly night and day, / He'd forked in eighty bushels wheat - that wasn't no child's play - / He'd wallabied right into town to save his blooming fare, / and now if he'd a thrummer left he says he wouldn't care.

thunderplump
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  18/11/1977
Source:  Otago Daily Times
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  DELUGED [heading] I am beginning to think that I must be the only ignoramus in Dunedin who has never heard of a thunderplump. Everyone else has known the word since childhood and, as a Buccleugh Street reader neatly put it, I was fairly deluged with thunderplumps yesterday. Other readers wanted to explain that `plumps' were to be found in many dictionaries, but I was aware of that anyway. Most of the people who knew of thunderplump claimed a Scottish origin for it, but it still took me quite a time to locate it in my range of dictionaries. Finally I ran it to earth in a seven-volume Century, published back in 1891, which gave it as `A short violent downpour of rain in connection with a thunder-storm (Rare),' and produced a 19th century quotation. Perhaps we didn't hear it much in Invercargill in my younger days because thunderplumps are pretty uncommon there; but a colleague who came from Winton certainly knew of it; and it was even noised abroad by the Canterbury English. ...


Notes:  (Griffiths Collection)

ti
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: cabbage tree
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also ti palm
Pronunciation:
Notes: The form <i>ti-tree </i> often leads to confusion with TEA-TREE (=MANUKA) and possibly underlies the spellings <i>ti-tree, titri </i> for <i>tea-tree </i>. (But see TI-SHRUB for distinction from MANUKA
Citations
Date:  0/0/1945
Source:  Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin)
Author:
Vol / Page:  III/1 : 13
Edition:
Quote:  The name "cabbage" tree seems to have been applied to the ti because the leaf buds provided for the early settlers a substance that could be cooked and eaten in the place of green vegetables.


Notes:

Date:  19/1/1847
Source:  Diary
Author:  BRUNNER
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  (19 January 1847) Collected a quantity of the roots of the ti, or cabbage tree, which we placed in a humu or native oven, for the night.
Notes:  quoted in 1982 Burton Two Hundred Years of NZ Food 19

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2032
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Ti</I> (t&emacr.), <I>n</I>. [Polynesian.]<I> (Bot.) </I>A liliaceous tree of the genus <I>Cordyline</I>, common in the Polynesian islands and in New Zealand; especially <I>Cordyline ti</I>; - called also <I>titi, ti-tree</I>, and <I>ti-tri.</I> The genus <I>Cordyline</I> comprises twelve species, distributed in the West Indies, the Malay Archipelago, the Pacific Islands, and Brazil. Four species are found in Australia, and six in New Zealand. The name ti is usually confined to <I>C. ti. C. indivisa </I>and <I>C. australis</I> are more commonly called cabbage tree.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1963
Source:  O Te Raki
Author:  KEENE
Vol / Page:  195
Edition:
Quote:  <I>ti</I>: cabbage tree; grows to height of about 30 ft.

Tay, it is useless, it only grows eight to twelve feet and the bark rough, and does not change. It seems very often Solitary. Away from every other Tree.

Edition:
Quote:   Of our shrubs and smaller timber trees, several are of strikingly beautiful growth ... (e.g.) the Houhere, <i>Hoheria populnea</i>; ..the Ti, <i>Cordyline australis;</i>.. and, on the sea-coast, ... the Karo, <i>Pittosporum crassifolium</i>; and the truly evergreen Ngaio, <i>Myoporum laetum</i> ... <I>Ibid.</I> Besides which the following roots and plants were often eaten, viz., the roots (cooked) of the Panahi (<i>Calystegia sepium</i>); of the Maikaika (<i>Arthropodium cirrhatum</i>); ... the roots of the little sugary Ti-koraha (<i>Cordyline stricta</i>), of the large Ti, or `Cabbage Tree' (<i>C. australis</i>), and of the large Fern, Para, (<i>Marattia salicina</i>). <I>Ibid.</I> 32  The young inner blanched leaves and heart of the Ti, or `Cabbage-tree' (<i>Cordyline australis</i>), and of the Nikau, or New Zealand Palm, (<i>Areca sapida</i>), were eaten both raw and cooked. <I>Ibid.</I> 36 ... the roots of the Tikoraha (<i>Cordyline stricta</i>), were tied separately for baking ... for their Kao, or prepared sweet potatoes, they used the leaves of the Parataniwha (<i>Elatostemma rugosum</i>); ...
Notes:  (Colenso Botany North Isd)

Date:  0/0/1946

Author:
Vol / Page:  55/146
Edition:
Quote:  <I>ti[i]</I>, a tree (Cordyline spp.), cabbage-tree, palm-lily, the various species being in Maori denoted by the adding of a descriptive suffix: .br;ti[i]-kouka, C. australis (kouka the chief of several suffixes for this species. ti[i]-kapu, C. indivisa. ti[i]-rauriki, C. pumilo (also ti[i]-koraka). ti[i]-ngahere, C. Banksii. ti[i]-parae, C. stricta. ti[i] is the only term in common use, and it has been wonderfully maltreated. see <I>manuka. </I>
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  469
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Ti, N.</I> the name of various species of trees of the genus <i>Cordyline, N.O. Liliaceae</i>. It exists in the Pacific Islands as<i> C. Ti,</i> and in New Zealand the species are <i>C. australis</i> and <i>C. indivisa</i>. Is is called in New Zealand the <i>Cabbage-tree </i>(q.v.), and the heart used to be eaten by the settlers. The word is Polynesian. In Hawaiian, the form is<i> Ki</i>; in Maori, <i>Ti</i>. Compare <i>Kanaka</i> (q.v.) and <i>Tangata</i>. By confusion, <i>Tea,</i> in Tea-tree <i>(q.v.)</i>, is frequently  spelt <i>Ti</i>, and <i>Tea-tree</i> is sometimes spelt <i>Ti-tri</i> (q.v.).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1905
Source:  Where the White Man Treads
Author:  BAUCKE
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  For in their season he could supplement his dry fare with berries and nuts, with the tender bulbous shoots of the tii (cabbage tree), at heart white and delicate, baked in a haangi; the tender leaves of the nikau - that part between the last ring and where the leaf stems separate, below which there is a huge bulge, clasped firmly, clasp on clasp, with the grip of steel bands.
Notes:

Author:
Vol / Page:  14
Edition:
Quote:  Kawakawa (pepper tree) leaves for aching joints, bruises and eczema, ti kauka (cabbage tree) leaves for cuts, sores and abrasions, pohutukawa bark for toothache and harakeke (flax) for wounds and skin ulcers are just a few of the huge number of native plants that were used by Maori and early European settlers for treatment of ailments.

ti mi
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: ?tainui Pomaderris apetala


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:

Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Wild West Coast
Author:  PAULIN
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Among the trees Mr. Traill pointed out [on Stewart Island], was what he called a `Ti Mi' tree, and which he said was only found growing in one place in New Zealand, that being Mokai, on the west coast of the North Island. He stated that the Maori tradition about it was this - that the first Maoris who visited New Zealand came in a large canoe built of `Ti Mi' wood, and they landed at Mokaia, where there is a good harbour. canoe got broken up, and some of the planks took root and grew.' Paulin WWC, pp. 33-4. [Andersen notes:] The canoe referred to was the `Tainui', and the tree is said to be the karaka or kopi. White Ancient History Maori (1890), vol. 4, p. 38. Ti Mi is probably intended for tainui: this tree is said to have sprung from the skids of the `Tainui' canoe. Cheeseman Manual NZ Flora (1906), p. 100.
Notes:  (And)

Date:  0/1/1992
Source:  NZ Gardener
Author:
Vol / Page:  48
Edition:
Quote:  Among the varieties of Cordyline grown by Maoris was one, variously known as ti tawhiti, ti kowhiti and ti para by tribes of the Taranaki, Wanganui and east coast regions respectively... The lack of a documented history, the unusual dwarf suckering habit, and the observation that it had never been  recorded to flower suggested to us that Cordyline 'Thomas Kirk' could be the forgotten ti tawhiti... <i>Ibid.</i> 49 The name ti tawhiti is translated as "the ti from a distant place" or alternatively "the ti from Tahiti".

tick tack
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  History of Children's Play
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  90
Edition:
Quote:  One common prank was Knick Knock. In this game, children knocked on someone's door, then ran away, but it could be played more elaborately: In Tick Tack we stuck a pin into the middle sash of a window; a button was suspended from this on a piece of cotton. Then a long length of cotton was attached to the smaller piece and led away to the gate. The cotton was pulled every now and then and the button tapped against the window. It was nighttime, and folks would pull up the blind and peer out. Some more adventurous spirits would come out and investigate and would maybe get entangled with the cotton. Then the culprit would run away to some other house. (1900; Moeraki)
Notes:

tick tick
Homonym Number:
Word Class: exclamation
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1951
Source:  Letter
Author:  WATT
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  A warning like the English schoolboys' `cave!'. From J. M. Barrie's <i>Peter Pan</i> where Hook was always warned of the approach of the crocodile because of the ticks of the alarm clock it had swallowed. If a master approaches, the boys warn the rest with `tick tick!'. Also used in the expression `to go tick' - that is, to go on watch for masters and prefects while the rest get into mischief.


Notes:  1951 Dilworth School (McWatt letter)

Date:  17/5/1951
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:  COLIN GORDON
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The carcases are washed and wiped by a <i>wiper</i>, then a <i>stringer</i>, generally a boy, puts strings on the front legs and necks, and they go over to <i>the clock</i> which counts them. The carcases then go to the <i>pusher-up</i> who pushes them along to the scales to be weighed and graded. A <i>stamper</i> stamps the carcases and a <i>ticket-boy </i>puts a grade ticket on them out at the scales after the <i>grader</i> has graded them for weight and size.
Notes:

tide
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: often used in NZ colloquial (espec. in children's) for `the sea' as in English dialect `without reference to ebb or flow', espec. in localities where low tide leaves mudflats, sandbanks etc. exposed
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1935 Havelock Where the same mudflat tidal conditions applied.

Edition:
Quote:  CREADION CARUNCULATUS. (THE SADDLE-BACK.) ... <i>Native names.</i> Tieke, Tiraweke, \{Tirauweke,\} and Purourou. [151] It is naturally a noisy bird, and when excited or alarmed becomes very clamorous, hurrying through the woods with cries of `tiaki-rere', quickly repeated.

Vol / Page:  1/14
Edition:
Quote:   ... to say nothing of Korimako and Pitoitoi ..., we never saw or heard the notes of either the Piopio, the Tieke, or the Hihi, all of which birds were at one time more numerous even than the Huia. The <i>Zosterops</i> was everywhere abundant, also the Grey Warbler and Rifleman, and ... we found the Tomtit comparatively plentiful; the Parakeet chased its mate through the tree-tops with sharp cries of `twenty-eight'; ... and among the tangle of the underwood the ever-present Flycatcher displayed its pretty fan-like tail.

tier

[Apr 12] put in clay in eaves and put tier on gable and chimney, [14] put tier on gable and chimney & tier of small stove,

Citations
tier-pole
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a rack of parallel bars upon which curing-sticks rest in the curing of tobacco.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  21/11/1927
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  340
Edition:
Quote:  They [curing-sticks] usually carry from eight to ten plants, and are hung in the shed by resting the ends of the sticks on tier-poles. These are strong squared timber, 2in by 4in., lying horizontally, and held in position by bolting them to uprights .. If the distance between curing-sticks on the tier-poles is reckoned at 8 in., it is now possible to work out the accommodation required for curing the crop.
Notes:

Date:  21/1/1929
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  59
Edition:
Quote:  The stick is placed on tier poles, which run like parallel bars in the curing-shed.

Date:  0/0/1886
Source:  Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author:
Vol / Page:  115
Edition:
Quote:   <I>Lamna glauca .. Tiger shark. </I><i>Ibid.</I> 117 to 119 TIGER SHARK (<I>Lamna glauca</I>). ... In New South Wales it is called the blue pointer, and, as Mr. Hill tells us, is `not only a very powerful, but perhaps the most bold of any of the large sharks visiting our shores. ... <i>Ibid.</i>118 Although there is some doubt on the subject, <I>Lamna glauca</I> is considered to be the mako of the Maoris, which is mainly found in the neighbourhood of Mayor Island. ... Mango, it should be remembered, seems [119] almost a generic name for shark in the North, as there is the mango-taniwha, a large variety; the mango-pare, the hammerheaded shark; the mango-reremai, the common dog-fish; the mango-pekepeke, and the mango-aruroa.
Notes:

Author:
Vol / Page:  74
Edition:
Quote:  I was at a Sunday night concert given by the Derwent Infantry Band recently, and one of the items was Mozart's "Gloria," rendered in what I think fine style, and as the last note died away there was but one solitary attempt at applause, and that was drowned by the shouts of the "dear" children (who are always prominent at our open-air concerts nowadays), playing "Tiggy touchwood," or some other Sabbath pastime, which must be in great favour with the police, for they never seem to interfere, although to the person who goes to hear the music such amusements are rather annoying.

tight as...
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: very mean (espec. with money), often further elaborated by adding `and that's watertight'; very drunk; (in various expressions of comparison with TIGHT in the senses: (1) close-fisted (P: mostly US: 1828; so WF); and (2) drunk (where NZ English would perhaps prefer FULL AS))
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1948 Wellington (Douglas Gray) cf. P: tight as a drum, tick, etc., which are also frequent in NZ.

Quote:  As a teamster, Pop was required (when working the team) to have 'tight chains' from 8am until 5.30pm. That means that the harness chains had to be tight (horses working), and prior to 8am the horses had to be caught, fed, prepared - and after 5.30pm the opposite applied, so I am not sure just how long his day was.

Sense Number:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Journal of Ensign Best
Author:
Vol / Page:  421
Edition:
Quote:  [On the attack on the Ngati Paoa at Whakatiwai.] The object of this attack was to balance an `utu' account. ... [sic] Ngati Paoa say this account had been previously squared, and the killings which happened at this attack were murders. The other side deny this and say that the balance was against them previously, but the deaths of the three men who fell wound up the account and the whole proceeding was `tika'(correct).
Notes:  1879 J.D. Fenton Important Judgments Delivered in the Compensation Court and Native Land Court, pp. 75-80 in 1966 Best Journal (ed. Taylor) 421

Date:  21/3/1858

Author:
Vol / Page:  1/367
Edition:  1960
Quote:  The greatest reception the Governor has had from natives, the most loyal reverence for the Queen's name and `mana', the most intelligent acquaintance with the English tikanga [fn. Policy.], ... are to be found in the Ngapuhi ...
Notes:  (F.D. Bell)

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Towards Taha Maori
Author:  HOWE
Vol / Page:  23
Edition:
Quote:  . This term refers to the customs, rules, habits and accepted ways of behaving in each tribal area, and as such may differ from marae to marae. Even within marae. one cannot know all the `tikianga' of that tribe, since aspects of life may only be known by specialists. To find out the tikianga of each marae, one should ask connected tangata whenua or knowledgeable people of the right way to enter and speak and act on that marae. To break `nga tikanga' is to invite (polite) scorn and this means a lowering of `mana'. Tikanga - see `kawa'.
Notes:

In New South Wales it is often caught by trawlers in one hundred and fifty fathoms and is known as King Barracouta. It is a favoured food fish. In Tasmania it is referred to as Tasmanian Kingfish.

tiki
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: .
Origin: initialism
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: a flat carving, often in greenstone, of a grotesque figure representing the first man; short for heitiki. In English contexts used where possibly <i>heitiki</i> more correct, and now (at least in Australian English) for `a lucky charm worn from the neck' [get reference].
Citations
Date:  24/2/1777
Source:  Cook's Journals
Author:
Vol / Page:  3/1001
Edition:

Notes:  1777 Feb 24 Samwell Account in Cook Journals (1967) 3/1001

Vol / Page:  2/120

Date:  0/0/1847

Author:  ANGAS
Vol / Page:  1/267

Quote:   ... she was dressed in the European fashion, ... but retained the <i>mako</i>, or shark's teeth, in her ears, and wore suspended round her neck the <i>tiki</i>i, or household god of green jade, which passes as an heir-loom amongst families. <I>Ibid.</I> 1/308 We can trace in the carvings of the New Zealanders - in their huge <i>tikis</i> or <i>wakapokokos</i>, and in their ornamental houses - a strong analogy to the architectural ornaments of the Mexicans.

Quote:
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/150
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tiki</i>, flat carved greenstone image worn on a cord round the neck, particularly by women: a charm for fertility, being a rough representation of the human embryo. The name in full is heitiki, hei signifying anything worn round the neck; and the tiki being the chief object so worn the hei has been dropped. The tiki is highly valued, and genuine ones can rarely be obtained; fakes are plentiful.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.
Author:
Vol / Page:  176
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tiki</i>: grotesque fiqure of greenstone, etc., used as neck ornament.

Quote:  <i>tiki n</i> -s [Maori & Marquesan] <i>1 usu cap</i> : an embodiment of the male principle in Polynesian mythology often depicted as the first man or the superhuman creator of mankind <i>2 a</i> : a Polynesian wood or stone image set up as a temporary abode or embodiment of a god or other supernatural power but not worshiped [sic] as an idol <i>b</i> : a Maori image representing an ancestor that is usu. either large and of wood or small, often in the form of a pendant, and of greenstone <i>Auckland (New Zealand) Star)</i> - compare <i>hei-tiki </I>

tikihemi
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1855
Source:  Te Ika a Maui
Author:  TAYLOR
Vol / Page:  499
Edition:
Quote:  ...the tikihemi corresponds with our trout; in shape and appearance it is much like an eel, hence it is named the eel-trout;...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1925
Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page:  8/291
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Vernacular Name</I>.- Powell [TrNZI 2/84] was the first to point out that two fish were referred to as `smelt' in north Canterbury. These were <I>Galaxias attenuatus </I>and <I>Retropinna retropinna</I>. At present Canterbury residents refer to<I> R. retropinna</I> as `silvery,' on account of the silver line running along the side of the half-grown fish. Maoris refer to this `silvery' as `tikihemi,' and to the adult as `paraki.'


Notes:  (Phillipps)

Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  Fishes NZ
Author:  PHILLIPPS
Vol / Page:  54
Edition:
Quote:  In some other localities these young [smelt, <i>Retropinna</i>] are called tuarenga. The half-grown fish is termed tikihemi and the adult paraki. Certain races of fish have a broad silvery band running along the side; hence the term `silvery.' It is to be regretted that in Canterbury the term smelt is still used to apply to the minnow, <i>Galaxias attenuatus. </i>

Sense Number:

Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Vol / Page:  44
Edition:
Quote:  All these travellers found the going hard, the rough tussock and fern and matagouri and spaniard tearing their clothing and spiking their legs in spite of leggings made of the stripped leaves of tikumu, the cotton plant.

Date:  0/0/1867

Edition:

Vol / Page:  80
Edition:
Quote:  <i>NOTHOFAGUS MENZIESII, silver beech</i>. A hardy tree, growing from sea level to timber line and often forming pure forests, especially in Nelson and Southland. ...Some stems become malformed through infestations of mistletoe, <i>Elytranthe colensoi</i>, and it is the only known host for our three species of <i>Cyttaria</i>, strawberry fungi which cause large galls.

Citations
Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
Author:  McARA
Vol / Page:  335
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Timber rearing</i>: Usually a wall at the end of a stope partitioning off the ladderway and consisting of 5 ft slabs nailed vertically to stulls wedged between the walls. Also used to make the central `box' in a three-compartment rise. Sometimes cribbing was used instead of building a rearing.

timberbelt
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a long and narrow plantation of trees grown for both timber and shelter.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1999
Source:  NZ Pasture and Crop Science
Author:  WHITE & HODGSON
Vol / Page:  275
Edition:
Quote:  Timberbelt is a term coined in New Zealand to describe a belt of trees designed to emphasise the production of timber; they may also have some sheltering function. Utilisation of timberbelts is not yet widespread but they are increasingly evident in regions where they are being promoted (eg Wairarapa and Canterbury.)
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1999
Source:  NZ Pasture and Crop Science
Author:  WHITE & HODGSON
Vol / Page:  276
Edition:
Quote:  Shelter belts and timberbelts should be removed before they become over-mature.

timber-jack
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: aka timber jack

Citations
Date:  0/4/2003
Source:  NZ Memories
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 41/50
Edition:
Quote:  On country too steep for bullocks the bushmen themselves moved the logs with tools called 'timber jacks' that they cranked by hand.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1874
Source:  Edward Crewe
Author:  BAINES
Vol / Page:  171
Edition:
Quote:  The principal tools required [by the kauri bushman] were Yankee axes, cross-cut saws, and timber (not screw) jacks. <i>Ibid.</I> 173 (Northland) Timer jacks [are] better than scew -jacks ... The timber-jacks consist of a toothed spear, two pinions, a cogged wheel, all of wrought iron, and properly arranged in a strong piece of wood. A double handle puts in motion the gear, and the spear can be ground out about two feet with power, one man being able to lift at the handle a ton easily.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1894
Source:  NZ Official Yearbook
Author:
Vol / Page:  131
Edition:
Quote:  Flotation is the method most commonly used in the kauri districts ... After the trunks are cut into lengths a `rolling-road' is formed to the nearest creek. All the scrub is closely cut down for a width of from twenty-five to thirty feet ... to obtain an approximately even surface, inclined towards the creek. The logs are forced along this road by timber-jacks, which the bushmen use with remarkable skill, and are impelled with a rapidity which is simply astonishing to persons unused to the process. If the creek contains plenty of water the logs float to the nearest booms without further trouble ...
Notes:  (T. Kirk)

Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Forest Flora
Author:  KIRK
Vol / Page:  150
Edition:
Quote:  The [kauri] logs are propelled along these roads by `timber-jacks' until they reach the water.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1969
Source:  From Forest to Farm
Author:  MOORE
Vol / Page:  38
Edition:
Quote:  The bushmen that did this work were a tough capable lot - a race apart - whom no difficulty could deter, and who performed amazing feats with a few quite primitive tools. These were axes, maul, and wedges, crosscut saws, mattocks for earth work, pinching bars or crowbars, and the versatile New Zealand-made timber jack. These jacks weighed about 80 pounds and by geared cogs multiplied the man power applied to the revolving handles so that the `spear' with its two chisel points, when applied to a log, could exert a lifting pressure of 5 tons.
Notes:

Date:  24/3/1869
Source:  Daily Southern Cross
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  We may also mention that Mr. Masefield has on hand a quantity of saw-mill machinery, timber-jacks, &c.

Date:  14/8/1941
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  8
Edition:
Quote:  Re the timber-jack:  To the best of my knowledge this wonderful instrument of the bushman is solely a New Zealand tool made in the sixties of the last century by that well-known firm of engineers, A. and G. Price, Ltd., of Thames, and later still by Messrs. Judd Bros., also of Thames, for the use of the sawmillers in the Coromandel and North Auckland kauri forests.
Notes:

Date:  28/6/1851
Source:  Lyttelton Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:
Notes:  There are two plants, the karo (prickly thorn) and taramea (spear grass), which are well worthy of their names, but are almost exclusively confined to the hilly regions. There generally grows near these a plant called the timuka, from the leaf of which the natives make mats and leggings, which are impervious to the sharp points of the former.

tin dog
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: stones in tin to rattle behind herd of sheep in absence of a dog
Citations
Date:  25/6/2003
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:  BARRY DOYLE
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  "... when we got home from school we would get a tin dog and drive the sheep to wherever dad said." What is a "tin dog" I asked. "Motorists, he replied carried petrol in 4 gallon cans in the boot of their car and when they were empty they would throw them in the ditch by the roadside. We would find one, put a fistful of gravel in it and drive the sheep. They were called 'tin dogs'".
Notes:  original from Ewan McGregor of Hawkes Bay ewan-mac@xtra.co.nz

Homonym Number:

See:

Notes:
Citations
Date:  1/11/1918
Source:  Quick March
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  `Tin Hat.' - `Thicknut' asks: Can anyone tell me why the `Heads' are called `Tinhats'? Are they any relation to the beings known in mythology as `tin gods'? [The terms `Tin Hat' and `Brass Hat' were current years before the war began, especially `Tin Hat.' Probably the expression had its origin in the metallic headgear worn by some of the military units in pre-war days. There is no evidence (at least no etymological evidence) that `tin-hat' is a corruption of `tin-head,' as one cynic has suggested.]

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1987
Source:  People, Places & Paddocks
Author:  GORDON
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  The direct descendant of the tin mill is the combine harvester, or header, of today, the only real difference between the two being that the mill lacks an engine, cutter bar and self-motivation. Jim's got four tin mills but uses only two, one on each farm.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1971
Source:  Moonshine County
Author:  OGILVIE
Vol / Page:  158
Edition:
Quote:  Next to the header harvester, the `tin' mill did the mill [sc. threshing] men most disservice. This smaller style of mill came in with the tractor by which it was drawn and driven. The `tin' mill only needed seven or eight men to operate it, and its output was no more than half that of the `big' mill. But within a short time these small mills became so popular that many farmers bought their own and could thresh their grain exactly when it suited them and their crops. The `tin' mill and the `Sunshine' header thus put an effective end to the era of the mill men [in South Canterbury].
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  Land of Munros, The
Author:  NEAVE
Vol / Page:  90
Edition:
Quote:  Then the tin mill and tractor came in, ... and [threshing] work was reduced to a few days only.
Notes:

Vol / Page:  2(7) : 10
Edition:
Quote:  The tin mill is smaller, slower but more portable [sc. than the threshing mill].

Date:  0/0/1975
Source:  Men of the Milford Road
Author:  ANDERSON
Vol / Page:  56
Edition:
Quote:  One of our calls was on a chap who had recently had a good win in the Art Union, and Dan took the opportunity to congratulate him. The result had appeared in the Invercargill paper and the nom-de-plume published was `Tinburn'. Dan of course wanted to know what prompted him to use such a curious nom-de-plume, and the proud winner said that he hadn't used that nom-de-plume at all. `Well what did you use?' asked Dan [57] `Tinbum.' Obviously the press in those days was a little more prudish than it is today.

I gave a jump that nearly sent Norah sprawling. `They must be tin-canning us.' `And what, I'd like to know, is tin-canning?' `Oh, it's a thing they always do round here when a newly married couple comes home.'

After a brief parley ... the giggling boys departed, and the bridegroom returned to explain to his wife that `It was just a custom - you know. They always do it in this part of the country. The men will be here a bit later, and I'll have to give them something to go and drink our health.

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Tang of The Bush
Author:  KEENE
Vol / Page:  55
Edition:
Quote:  In the evening [of our wedding day: ca1898] we prepared for visitors. The number who came to the tin canning was the measure of a couple's popularity. The usual plan was for the guests to approach silently, wait until all were gathered, then to smite their tins with might and main, making a din which could be heard for miles.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1964
Source:  Stamper Battery
Author:  HOWE
Vol / Page:  116
Edition:
Quote:  ... I suppose our [children's wedding] celebrations [c1880] were rather childish. ... We called them `tin-canning'. We [117] usually started rather late because by then the guests were fairly drunk and their reactions more amusing. Our drums were empty kerosene tins beaten with copper-sticks and the din could be heard for miles. ... Tradition decreed that red-hot pennies be thrown to us when the tin-canning started.
Notes:

There stood Ned and Maggie in the centre, while round marched the rest of the people armed with kerosine tins, billies half filled with stones, and tin dishes, shouting, yelling, and singing ...

tin-kettler
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  23/9/1905
Source:  NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page:  14/8/3
Edition:
Quote:  <i>A Tin-kettling Episode</i>: The detestable practice of tin-kettling a newly-married couple [with kerosine tins] doesn't seem to die out like other barbarities in this country; it is a relic of by-gone days. ... The origin of the custom has never been authoritatively determined and whether it is an English or purely Colonial custom ... doesn't appear to be known. However, the tin-kettlers expect the happy bridegroom to stop the din by handing them cakes and ale. ... It is only the idiotic low-class class of people who would go banging tin-cans opposite a man's house after dark ... .
Notes:

Source:  Memories (Mainly Merry)

Quote:  I was married in Greymouth in 1937 ... a crowd of children and young adults arrived, armed with noisemakers ... But, six months ago, here in Rotorua, my young neighbour remarried and I was surprised and delighted to see and hear the `tin-kettlers' arrive when the young couple returned from their honeymoon.
Notes:  1988 Feb 13 Letter from Rotorua in Russell J. Stone folder (ATB MS)



Date:  8/2/1988
Source:  Letter
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  `The local farmers put their heads together and planned a tin-kettling party. In the hands of people were carried an assortment of pots and kettles, wooden and metal spoons, kerosene tins containing stones as a rattle, old-fashioned car horns ... The tin-kettling was not complete until the house was circled by the tin-kettlers.'
Notes:  1988 Feb 8 Letter from Christchurch [re Alford Forest] in Russell J. Stone folder (ATB MS)



Date:  26/6/1876
Source:  North Otago Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  The “tin-kettlers” are made up by the male friends of those just married, amounting sometimes, if the bridegroom is popular, to fifty persons, the “tin-kettles” used being generally kerosene tins, which are beaten with sticks, sometimes small stones are put in the tin, and the thing is shaken, drums are beaten, pipes played, and everything done which can tend to make a noise.
Notes:

Notes:

tin-kettling
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: (formerly) a custom whereby a newly-wed couple are welcomed to their marriage home by noisy banging of kerosene (etc.) tins until they provide the tin-kettlers with refreshments.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: also called tin-canning
Citations
Date:  25/3/1943
Source:  NZ Farmers' Weekly
Author:
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  This was called "tin-canning" or "tin-kettling," and newly married couples were

those who suffered.


Notes:

Date:  23/9/1905
Source:  NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page:  14/8/3
Edition:
Quote:  <i>A Tin-kettling Episode</i>: The detestable practice of tin-kettling a newly-married couple [with kerosine tins] doesn't seem to die out like other barbarities in this country; it is a relic of by-gone days. ... The origin of the custom has never been authoritatively determined and whether it is an English or purely Colonial custom ... doesn't appear to be known. However, the tin-kettlers expect the happy bridegroom to stop the din by handing them cakes and ale. ... It is only the idiotic low-class class of people who would go banging tin-cans opposite a man's house after dark ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1905
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:  R. MASON
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  `Term must date back 60 years at least judging by the people who are familiar with it as an old expression. A custom (in country districts mostly) of visiting a newly settled-in just married couple in the evening and banging tins and making other noise, etc., outside their house.

tin-kettling
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: TIN-KETTLE, TIN-PAN [kettle ?= cauldro, boiler, billy] OED(S <i>tin-kettle</i>: to serenade roughly or opprobriously ... by beating a tin-kettle, [1898 sc an inn-keeper who had beaten his wife; 1900 Lawson diggers for newlyweds; OEDS 1881 Bathgate] also, to (cause swarming bees) to settle [1900 H. Lawson]; also<i> tin pan</i> 1885 English Dialect Dictionary Tin 1 (7) tin-kettle</i> to punish a notorious offender by means of `rough music', i.e., the beating of tin kettles, etc. Hmp; also (10) <i>Tin-pan</i> s.Not. -->SHIVAREE/CHARIVARI cf OED(S<i> charivari <>/i>the tin-kettling of incongruous marriages. W3 [=Third Webst. Int]<i>Brit</i>. a mock serenade; esp.<i> shivaree </i> cf. Mencken Amer. Lang. Supp 1/232-3 <i>shivaree </i>`... a rowdy serenade of a newly-married couple ...' for a list of US (near-)synonyms and discussion W3 <i>shivaree</i> [f F charivari] A noisy mock serenade to a newly married couple who are expected to furnish refreshments to silence the serenaders.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

tinned
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number:
Definition: preferred in NZ to CANNED until about WW2; thence canned (can) became more common in collocations as <I>tinned (canned) food,</i> etc. sc canned (Davin an old-fashioned writer) see also <i>can, canned </I>
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1935 Havelock general store tinned peaches, salmon, etc. usual; canned seldom or never heard

tinny
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number:  1
Definition: lucky
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: 1953 18 M A40 Thames DHS 1 TINNY -->1960 16C F B5 Wellington Girls C. 32 TINNY 1984 16-17 F E10 Pakuranga Coll. 32 TINNY [lucky] [M6 F3] -->1984 14 F E125 Wgton Girls C. 32 TINNY -->1984 14 F E127 Wgton Girls C. 32 TINNY [5] ca1935 Havelock `Tinny eh?' was a common remark among children after someone had made a good or lucky shot at marbles.

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  113
Edition:
Quote:  <I>tinny</I> lucky, possibly by association with English `tinny', rich; eg `The bail just hit his racket abd dobbed over the net. How tinny can you get!' NZA. -not very impressive; from tin being regarded as as inferior metal to iron or steel; eg `I tell you that horse is tinny, it'll never amount to anything.'

tinny house/tinnie house
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: retail outlet for tinnies
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Chris Fowlie (6/10/1999) says these are usually rented by gangs (so they can't be seized under the Proceeds of Crimes Act), are run by teen-agers (they can't be arrested) and are often open for business 24 hours a day with sales often taking place through a hole in a wall or window - the equivalent of the US "crack house".

tino rangatiratanga
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: full (Maori) sovereignty or self-determination.




Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Politics
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: from the Maori text of the Treaty of Waitangi (tino indicating a superlative degree, RANGATIRATANGA)

tinplate
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: sand flounder
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1911
Source:  Records of the Canterbury Museum
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/197
Edition:
Quote:  Sand Flounder New Zealand Flounder, Patiki, Three corner, Tinplate <i>Rhombosolea plebeia. </I>
Notes:  Waite

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  191
Edition:  2nd edn
Quote:  NEW ZEALAND SAND-FLOUNDER (PATIKI) <i>Rhombosolea plebeia</i> (Richardson) ... The common Sand-flounder is known from one end of New Zealand to the other, sometimes by other names in different localities. In Auckland it is known as the Dab.../ Some refer to it as Tinplate or Three Corner; the latter name is derived from its fancied trangular shape but why Tinplate I am at a loss to know. To other than fishermen and those intimately connected with the fishing industry it is just a Flounder. Some say it is Tinplate because when cooked it fills a plate.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
Author:  DOOGUE & MORELAND
Vol / Page:  216
Edition:
Quote:  SAND FLOUNDER ... <i>Other names: Rhombosolea plebeia</i>; diamond, tinplate, dab, square; patiki (Maori).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Marine Fishes
Author:  MORELAND
Vol / Page:  32
Edition:
Quote:  SAND FLOUNDER [<i>Rhombosolea plebeia</i>] ... Other names are dab, diamond, tinplate, and square. The Maori name patiki, originally generic, is now loosely used for most flounders.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:
Quote:  <I>FLOUNDER</I> (four species) (a) Scientific name: (i) <i>Rhombosolea plebeia</i> (ii)<i> Rhombosolea retiaria</i> (iii) <i>Rhombosolea tapirina </i>(iv) <i>Rhombosolea leporina</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Flounder (ii) Freshwater Flounder (iii) Flounder (iv) Yellowbelly Flounder. (c) Other common names: (i) Square, Dab, Plaice, Diamond or Diamond-back, Tin-plate, Three Corners. (ii) Blacks, Black Flounder (iii) Greenback [25 `Not common but occasionally taken in southern waters.'] (iv) Yellow Flounder.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  71
Edition:
Quote:  FLOUNDER SAND ... Other names are `dab', tinplate, square flounder. The Maori name `patiki' is used for all flounder except the sole which is the `patiki rori'. <I>Ibid.</i> 200 TINPLATE <i>see</i> Flounder, sand

He is the man who will, as long as he has a mob of his mates to back him, smash up a store, jump a claim, rob a church, ... with equal zest.

tip it
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a guessing game


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1895
Source:  Diary of Jonathan Roberts
Author:
Vol / Page:  32
Edition:
Quote:  [In the Lyttelton Gaol]"Tip it' is something after the style of eggs in the bush. You have one button and some two or three fellows play another two or three. One side guesses which hand of the others contains the button. If they don't guess right it scores one against them. If they do, they take the button and the others guess.

Quote:  J.A.Lee in his <i>Children of the Poor</i> (1939) mentions the game of knocking on doors. It was known also as Tip Tap (1885; Waikouaiti). Another widely known trick was Jingle the Penny: `We tied a string to a penny with a hole in it, then hid behind a hedge or on top of a verandah. As a person stooped to pick it up, we would whisk it away' (1895; Ngakawau).

Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/91
Edition:
Quote:   A long lane was formed on an extensive level plain, fifty feet in width, by two high walls, formed by perhaps upwards of ten thousand baskets of potatoes, kumeras, Indian corn

(<i>Holcus indicus</i>), tarro (<i>arum</i>), water melons, turnips preserved, (<i>kou</i>) steamed kernels of the native fruit, (<i>karaka</i>[as-acute]) baked roots of the <i>ti</i> palm tree, (<i>korou</i>) a quantity of dried cod, eels and other fish, also of shell-fish, bundles of fern-root, onions, peaches, grapes, &c.

Date:  4/3/1849
Source:  Torlesse Papers
Author:
Vol / Page:  64
Edition:  1958
Quote:  Country undeviating grass and ti-palm.
Notes:

Date:  12/4/1851
Source:  Lyttelton Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  The appearance of Ti palms on the Canterbury plains is very remarkable. They rise amidst the short rich grass with their thick stalks and graceful crest; often when one looks up suddenly from the ground, startling with their likeness to men. One of our wags remarked of these plants, that they looked `like men as trees walking'. A less observant youth having lost his way a few nights ago, in the neighbourhood of the capital, was cheered in the loneliness of the prairie, by the appearance of a man approaching. He took off his hat, (not having yet forgotten the courteous address of the old country,) and accosted the stranger, `I beg your pardon, sir, but can you tell me which is the way to Christchurch.' It was a Ti palm.
Notes:

tip-cat
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: 1930-35 West Coast children's game (R. B. McLuskie) A piece of wood with squared sides numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, but tapering to bevelled points at each end, is struck on the bevelled end with a batten so that it spins and lands with one numbered side uppermost. From that number a sequence of ? tasks is given.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  13/6/1885
Source:  Wairarapa Daily
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  Tommy Packer was playing tip  cat on the pavement, and he hit the cat with his stick, and tipped it, all muddy, straight into the masher's face.

Sense Number:

Quote:  The sloping surface which gives a slide in from the side of a bath, the tipping pen in which the floor moves from the horizontal to a steep angle, and the turntable pen, all have the common purpose of getting the sheep into the bath with a minimum of effort and with little risk of injury to the sheep.
Notes:

tippy
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number:  1
Definition: [of fleece-wool staple] the projection of thick fibres beyond the fine ones at the tip end.

Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]

Date:  0/0/1843
Source:  Travels in NZ
Author:  DIEFFENBACH
Vol / Page:  1/147
Edition:
Quote:  Another bird, the tierawaki (Jeterus rufisater, Less.), is very common. It is as large as a blackbird, of a jet-black plumage, with red-brown coverlets of the wings and tail. It has two small orange-coloured appendages at the base of the beak. This bird is seen on the lower branches of trees, is very lively, and has a loud penetrating note. It always screams when anything attracts its attention - huei, huei, tierawak, tierawak. It feeds principally on fleshy berries, but also on coleopterous insects.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1873
Source:  Birds of New Zealand
Author:  BULLER
Vol / Page:  150
Edition:   {1888 2nd edn 1/18}
Quote:  CREADION CARUNCULATUS. (THE SADDLE-BACK.) ... <I>Native names</I>. Tieke, Tiraweke, \{Tirauweke,\} and Purourou. [151] It is naturally a noisy bird, and when excited or alarmed becomes very clamorous, hurrying through the woods with cries of `tiaki-rere', quickly repeated.

PUFFINUS TRISTIS \{GRISEUS\}. (SOMBRE SHEARWATER.) ...<i>Native names</i>.- Titi, Hakoakoa, and Totorore: `Mutton-bird' of the colonists. ... when hovering overhead at night [Titi] utter a frequent call-note, like <i>tee-tee-tee</i>, from which the Maori name is derived. [Check that some of this may be 1888 edn only.]

Vol / Page:  188
Edition:
Quote:  `Taiko' is the name for any large muttonbird, once abundant on all mountain ranges from the Waitakeres to the Rimutakas of the North Island. In the `good old days', each Maori village had it own taiko colony, which was visited in the autumn to collect the fat `titi' (young birds).

Author:  BURTON
Vol / Page:  9

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Author:
Vol / Page:  76
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mottled Petrel Pterodroma inexpectata</i> (FORSTER, 1844) ... OTHER NAMES:<i> Scaled

petrel, Peale's petrel, rainbird, korure, titi. </I> <i>Ibid.</I> 80 <i>Cook's Petrel Pterodroma cookii</i> GRAY, 1843) ... OTHER NAME: <i>Titi.</i> ... [81] Many years ago, adult and young Cook's petrels were taken for food by Maoris. <i>Ibid.</I> 96 <i>Sooty Shearwater Puffinus griseus</i> (GMELIN, 1789) ... [97] OTHER NAMES: <i>Titi, New Zealand muttonbird.</i> ... Of all the various petrels serving as `muttonbirds' in New Zealand this is the most important. <i>Ibid.</I> 99 <i>Hutton's Shearwater Puffinus huttoni </i>MATHEWS, 1912 ... OTHER NAMES: <i>Titi, pakaha, muttonbird</i>. ... Hutton's shearwater breeds only on the South Island.

Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  Rakiura
Author:  HOWARD
Vol / Page:  205
Edition:
Quote:  These are the names used by the southern Maori; in the North Id. Kuaka, Parara and Titi are applied to other birds. Kuaka: <i>Pelicanoides Urinatrix</i>, or Diving Petrel. Black Bill. Wing 4.7 inches. Titi Wainui: <i>Prion Turtur</i> or Dove Petrel. Parara: <i>Prion vittatus</i>, or Broad-billed Petrel. Bill very wide. Wing, 9.5 inches. Titi: <i>Puffinus Griseus</i> or Mutton-Bird. Sooty brown. Bill horn colour. Wing, 12 inches.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/159
Edition:
Quote:  <i>ti[i]ti[i],</i> a sea-bird (Puffinus griseus and other spp.), mutton-bird; appear in great numbers and nest in peaty holes on cliffs on unfrequented shores, when great numbers of the young are taken and preserved in their own fat. The tuatara lizard often occupies the same burrow; but the terms of partnership are not known.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Native Animals of NZ
Author:  POWELL
Vol / Page:  79
Edition:
Quote:  MUTTON BIRD (<i>Puffinus griseus</i>), Titi or Oi of the Maoris, was and still is in the South an important item in the diet of the Maori people.

Vol / Page:  154
Edition:
Quote:  In the house, big fire of dead tete-a-weka wood going. Two witch's pots (small edition of a whaler's try-pot) and a camp oven swinging above the fire. Titis sizzling in their own kato fat (fat from insides). Piro fat, the fine fat from the intestines, is more precious.
Notes:  1952 Apr 20 in 1982 Sansom In the Grip of an Island 154

Of the above names, Korimako is most generally used by northern and Makomako by southern tribes. The Ngatiawas call this bird Rearea; and the natives of the Bay of Plenty distinguish the male and female as Kokorohimako and Titapu.

Date:  9/12/2003
Source:  BLANK ENTRY
Author:
Vol / Page:  A11
Edition:
Quote:  The titiwai (stars in wet places) of Waitomo, which means water entering a shaft, have been celebrated since 1887, when they were first explored by local Maori chief Tane Tinorau. The insects feed ravenously as larvae, then briefly emerge as adult fungus gnats to mate, lay eggs and die within three days.

title
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an abbreviation of certificate of title, a copy of the entry in the land titles register recording the identity and ownership of a piece of land and any legal encumbrances on it.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes : The English equivalent in relation to registered land there is <i>land certificate</i>. The term <i>title deeds</i> is sledom used in NZ. The attached clippings illustrate an aspect of its general use e.g. <i>on separate titles, titles pending</i>.

Citations
Date:  0/1/1999
Source:  NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  Some New Zealand land law terms are uncommon  or  unknown  in  England. (Conversely the term title deeds is not much used here either by lawyers or laymen.  Instead we talk of the title or certificate of title, in the concrete sense of a document which is a copy of the registry entry in the Land Transfer Office.
Notes:

Source:  NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  The land transfer system contrasted with the older deeds system, introduced in 1841 as a reformed version of traditional English real property law whereby rights to ownership depended on  the existence and validity of a chain of documents. The term title deeds derives from this.

Date:  13/12/1847
Source:  Sketches in NZ
Author:  POWER
Vol / Page:  145
Edition:
Quote:  It is a pity [the Maories] do not extend the same condemnation to lying, which is an almost universal failing, and is considered no disgrace whatsoever ... [146] The consequence is, that the natives are generally distrustful and incredulous; and `toe' and `teto', lie and liar, are the words most frequently heard in their conversation, and which they apply to one another and to white men of all ranks without the least hesitation or compunction.

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/146
Edition:
Quote:  <i>titoki</i>, a tree (Alectryon excelsum), scarlet fruit with shiny black seed at tip, whence the tree (or fruit) is called crayfish-eyes: they fruit yields a scent used with the oil with which chiefs anoint themselves, apparently plentifully once every three years or so, whence the proverb applied to an upstart: "Chief of the titoki year," since anyone can use the scent that year.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Quote:  There are many natural productions of the country ... One of these is the oil of the

<i>Pitoku</i> berry, which is of very fine quality, and much used by the natives in anointing their hair. It is a sweet and pleasantly-tasting oil ... The berry is small, of a brown colour, and very unctuous, with but little taste as a fruit. The tree is wild in every part of New Zealand.

ti-tree
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: ti-tree oneself, be ti-treed, to be in a shelter (that is, to take to the scrub)
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1935
Source:  Slang Today
Author:  PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page:  286
Edition:
Quote:  [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... <i>ti-tree oneself,</i> to take shelter from artillery, the ti-tree being very common in N.Z., where during the Maori War, the natives had an exasperating habit of retreating to `the bush', wooded country;
Notes:  1935 Mitchell and Strong in Partridge Slang Today 286

Date:  0/0/1937
Source:  Dictionary of Slang
Author:  PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page:  881
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Ti-tree oneself; be ti-treed.</i> To take shelter from artillery fire: New Zealand soldiers': in G.W. Ex Maori custom of retreating to the bush at time of the Maori War. See preceding entry.
Notes:

Date:  2/4/1938
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  18
Edition:
Quote:  [Slang of the N.Z.E.F.] ... `to be ti-treed' meant to be in shelter.

Notes:  (Bill Henderson)

tiver
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: potato
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also taewa, tawai
Pronunciation:
Notes: NOTE: In view of the meanings and varieties in spelling above, it is not improbable that the word represents the name of one<I> Stivers</I>, who is said to have visited the Bay of Islands before Cook. [See] Lee and Kendall's Grammar p. 107

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author:  TURNER
Vol / Page:  133
Edition:
Quote:  The word <I>tray</I> and its variants for `threepence' and zack fpr `sixpence' are said to be common Australianisms but are not known to me in New Zealand. <I>Tizzie</I>, perhaps from<I> tester</I>, is said to have been current in New Zealand, but again I do not know it. On the other hand, a word which Baker says is not current in New Zealand is one I have long known, <I>razoo</I>. ... The word <I>razoo</I> refers to no particular amount of money but is used in the negative `I haven't got a razoo', or, more often, `I haven't got a brass razoo'.
Notes:

Source:  From Beads to Banknotes
Author:  HARGREAVES

toatoa
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: indigenous pine distinctive for large leathery leaves.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: <i>Phyllocladus toatoa</i>, formerly <i>P. glaucus</i>: the 'celery' pine which grows in lower habitats than <i>P.alpinus</i>, the mountain toatoa.

Origin:
Register:

Domain: [none]

Notes:
Citations
toatoa
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an indigenous pine, the mountain toatoa.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: aka toa toa; <i>Phyllocladus alpinus</i> aka mountain toatoa; as one of NZ's three Phyllocladus genera it is sometimes referred to as celery pine, but c.f. celery pine <i>Phyllocladus trichomanoides</i>.   See also toatoa <i>Phyllocladus toatoa</i>.

toby
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a raddle stick
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  8/11/1983
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:  PROF. DARCY WALKER
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  He did not hear it till c1955 when he came to Wellington cf Macquarie: <I>toby</I> = stick used by owner to raddle badly-shorn sheep with.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  NZ English Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  3.26
Edition:
Quote:  <i>raddled:</i> This word means `robbed' in the sense of being deprived of one's proper payment. It is an extension of `raddling', carried out by unscrupulous farmers before the Shearers' Union looked after shearers' interests. Any sheep considered unsatisfactorily shorn was marked with red or blue raddle and such a sheep would not be counted in the shearer's tally. The raddle stick was also called a `Toby'. This must not be confused with [27] marking a sheep for other purposes, such as identification of certain sheep for easy selection later.
Notes:  (Wallace Shearing Glossary)



toby
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: A stop-cock or valve in a water- or gas-main, gen. in a roadway at which the supply may be turned off, also applied to the covering, lid or box protecting it
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Frequently toby box or toby-box; ca1954 Upper Hutt (Val Kiddie)(This was the first time I had heard the word used: I had always called it the `stopcock'. HWO) ; 1955 occas. seen (but not recorded) in the Evening Post --->ca1960 Karori, Wellington

Quote:  I must correct you as to the origin of 'toby'. It's not Irish for road. It is Gaelic for 'spring'. My ancestors built the navigation canals in the UK. That's why they were called 'navvies' and they took the word toby with them. I'm fluent in the Gaelic, so trust me!

Notes:

Date:  6/11/1989
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:  JAMES M DERMODY, WARKWORTH
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  My parents, and I as a four-year-old, came out from Ireland in 1921. My father became involved in a new water-supply scheme for Blenheim. In the later 1920s the `toby-box' was an item of daily reference: my father had a small supply in his shed at home. They were a cast-iron cylinder of about four inches diameter and not much greater length.
Notes:

Date:  11/6/1983
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  56
Edition:
Quote:  What is the origin of the "toby". the tap that turns off water at the street frontage of a house?... I am prepared to wager that it is derived from "toby", which was the gypsy-tinker slang term for "street. There is an early link between tinkers and plumbers, both being experts with the soldering-iron, and I think the plumbers took over "toby" from the tinkers. Consequently, when they turned water off "at the toby" they were turning it off at the street.
Notes:  Ian Gordon

Quote:  <i>MONKFISH</i> (a) Scientific name: (i) <i>Geniagnus monopterygius</i> (ii) <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (both) Whitefish. (c) Other common names: (both) Monkfish, Monks, Stargazer, Flathead (also applied at times to export gurnard); Churchills, Toebiters, Bulldogs, Spotted Stargazer, Maori Chief (Dunedin); Muddies. (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Cook Strait, Nelson, Banks Peninsula, Bluff-Stewart Island. ... Monkfish is a general term for species of the Families Uranoscopidae and Leptoscopidiae.

This larva is called the `black creper,' or sometimes the `toe-biter'.

toe-ragger
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  472
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Toe-ragger, n.</i> In the bush a term of abuse; though curiously in one or two parts of New South Wales the word `toey,' which is derived from it, is a term of praise, a `swell.' The word has been explained as of convict origin, that the rags were used to soothe the galling of fetters; but the explanation is not satisfactory, for the part galled by the irons would not be the toe, but the ankle. A writer in `Truth' has cleared up the word (see quotation). It is of Maori origin. Away from Maoriland "toe-rigger' had no meaning, and a false meaning and origin were given by the change of vowel.
Notes:

Date:  12/1/1896
Source:  Truth (Sydney)
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  `The bushie's favorite term of opprobrium `a toe-ragger' is also probably from the Maori. Amongst whom the nastiest term of contempt was that of <i>tau rika rika</i>, or slave. The old whalers on the Maoriland coast in their anger called each other toe-riggers, and to-day the word in the form of toe-ragger has spread through-out the whole of the South Seas.'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1929

Vol / Page:  893

Quote:  <i>Toe-ragger, rigger</i>. A term of opprobrium: Australia and New Zealand resp., as in <i>Truth</i> (the Sydney one), Jan. 12, 1896, `"A toe-ragger' is Maori... The nastiest term of contempt was

<i>tua rika rika,</i> or slave. The old whalers on the Maoriland coast in their anger called each other <i>toe-riggers</i>, and to-day the word in the form <i>toe-ragger</i> has spead throughout the whole of the South Seas.' Morris.

Date:  0/0/1941
Source:  NZ Slang
Author:  BAKER
Vol / Page:  14
Edition:
Quote:  Another old whaling term - this time a pejorative - is toe-rigger, which is the original of the still-current slang expression in Australia, <i>toe-ragger.</i> Here is what the Sydney Truth, January 12, 1896 had to say on the subject: "The bushie's favourite term of opprobrium, a toe-ragger, is...probably from the Maori, amongst whom the nastiest term of contempt was that of tau rika rika, or slave. The old whalers on the Maoriland coast in their anger called each other toe-riggers and to-day the word in the form of toe-ragger has spread throughout the whole of the South Seas.' Morris also declares: `It is of Maori origin. Away from Maoriland toe-rigger had no meaning, and a false meaning and origin were given by the change of vowel.'

Citations
toetoe
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a tall showy plumed reed similar in appearance to the South American pampas grass. [Maori] <i>Arundo</i> spp., esp. <i>A. conspicua (kakao)</i>, a pampas grass; cuttygrass
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: English spellings (and to some extent, pron.) vary around two modes, usually, but not always, reduplicated, and with or without an <i>h</i>. (1)<i> toetoe, tohetohe, tohe </i>(2) <i>toi-toi, to"ito"i</i> [dieresis-o], <i>tohi-tohi, towi-towi, towy-towy;</i> and (?from pron [t it i])<i> tortor</i> (1842) <i>totitoti</i> (1937) is a mistake or misprint. English pron [|toui:toui:], [|touwi:touwi:], [t it I] The form is occasionally found unreduplicated, espec in combination with <i>-grass</i> (cf. <i>tui-grass</i>, probably an analogous Canterbury hearing influenced by <i>tui</i>: cf.<i>poe</i>, pui)<i> plurals usu. with</i> -s

Sword-grass (Toe-toe) [es-dieresis] .... <I>O.</I> Gramineae;<I> G</I>. Arundo; <I>S.</I> A. conspicua. "The largest New Zealand grass; confined to these islands; culms three to eight (ten) feet high; used for thatch and lining houses with reed-work. Flowers very like those of Panama grass.'

Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  They dwelt in whares [11] (huts) built in the traditional shape of an inverted V, roofed with grass, and lined inside with the reeds of the toetoe or New Zealand pampas grass. The orthodox Maori name for these reeds is pukakaho, but the white men called them `bukaka'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  Sir Donald Maclean
Author:  COWAN
Vol / Page:  146
Edition:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1942
Source:  Maori Place Names
Author:  ANDERSEN
Vol / Page:  277
Edition:
Quote:  Earp spells the word tohitohi, and even to the present day it is spelt toi toi as often as the correct toe toe.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/146
Edition:
Quote:  <I>toetoe</I>, giant ornamental grass (Arundo conspicua), the flower-culms used for reed-work between the carved slabs of house-walls, cross-laced in a variety of patterns with narrow strips of flax [147] or pingao, white and black or bright orange (the tukutuku-work): very often mis-spelt toitoi or toi toi, or tohi tohi. Though the name toetoe is by the Pakeha confined to Arundo, by the Maori it is applied to various species of rush and grass with a qualifying suffix: Arundo is toetoe-kakaho, the latter word referring to the valued culms. Some people object to the reed tukutuku-work as being flimsy and perishable: in reality it is as durable as galvanized-iron and far more handome and artistic: the interior of a good Maori house is a thing of beauty.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/11/2006
Source:  Footnotes
Author:
Vol / Page:  26 / 7
Edition:
Quote:  Coastal shrub species such as flax, toetoe, hebe and manuka were planted.
Notes:

Date:  0/7/2006
Source:  Air New Zealand inflight magazine
Author:

toheroa stakes
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Way Up North
Author:  THOMAS
Vol / Page:  100
Edition:
Quote:  But my friends in the far north tell tales of parties going to the beach to fish, and spending their time engrossed in a game known as the Toheroa Stakes. The game is based on the shellfish's remarkable ability to bury itself and disappear in the solid sand of the wet beach. ... The game is, or was, played by drawing a circle on the beach. Each player selects a toheroa. The bets are made. On the word go each toheroa is placed on its side within the circle. The first to disappear is the winner.
Notes:

Quote:  Tawhiao, who appeared, as did the other natives present, greatly impressed with the method adopted, said if the Pakeha "Tohunga" had proposed to rectify the cast in his eye, or to change his hair from grey to a dark color, he would not have agreed, as people knew him by these signs, but that it was good for the "Tohunga" to take away the pains of his limbs.
Notes:

tohunga
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a (Maori) priest or gifted or learned person; a teacher,  faith-healer, doctor, or wise man (often in English contexts, `medicine man')
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also priest, wizard
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1804
Source:  English Colony in NSW
Author:  COLLINS

Edition:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1905
Source:  Where the White Man Treads
Author:  BAUCKE
Vol / Page:  14, 63
Edition:
Quote:  attrib ... directly [the Maori] enters the domain of witchcraft, `tipau' (ghouls), `patupaiarahe' (fairy demons), dreams, or tohunga imbecilities, he becomes a fear-haunted, helpless perverter of truth! <I>Ibid.</I> 130 When the next measle, or other epidemics, come along, you send for that hideous monstrosity, your tohunga, who knows no more of treatment than that shag in the river there, who brings his stinking lotions and baths, his idiotic prescriptions, ... until the sufferer dies, and then stalks away to do murder elsewhere. <I>Ibid.</I> 262 In my recent outback explorations I have met with scenes which horrified ... and brought home to me ... the imperative necessity ... that it be a criminal offence, punishable with hard labour imprisonment, to practise tohungaism, boast of tohungaistic reputation, apply to a tohunga for illegal operations, and learning the incantations, ...


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  NZ Statutes
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 13
Edition:
Quote:  Preamble WHEREAS designing persons, commonly known as <i>tohungas</i>, practise on the superstition and credulity of the Maori people by pretending to possess supernatural powers in the treatment and cure of disease, the foretelling of future events, and otherwise, and thereby induce the Maoris to neglect their proper occupations and gather into meetings where their substance is consumed and their minds unsettled, to the injury of themselves and to the evil example of the Maori people generally: ...[check if cap initial req for tohungas???]
Notes:  1907, No. 13 <i>Title</i> An Act to suppress <i>Tohungas</i> (24th September, 1907)

Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  From casual enquiries I find that a young woman, believing that the makutu spell had been laid upon her, came in to consult a noted tohungaess to have a malison removed, but recrimination ensuing the hocus pocus ended in the afflicted fiercely attacking the diviner and becoming insane, which insanity then spread to the remainder of the family of four, including the father and son-in-law.
Notes:

tohungaism
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: sorcery or faith healing as formerly practised by (or alleged against) tohunga.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: also as tohunga-ism; apparently a cause for concern among Pakeha c.1900, the word being frequently used in newspapers, etc.; a Tohunga Suppression Act was passed in 1908.

Author:  HOOKER
Vol / Page:  768
Edition:
Quote:  Toi, <i>Col[enso]. Barbarea vulgaris. </I>

Date:  0/0/1869
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/III/31
Edition:
Quote:  Also, the cooked leaves and herbaceous tops of [32] the Toi <i>(Barbarea Australis)</i>, and of the Poroporo, or Raupeti <i>(Solanum nigrum)</i>; and the baked inner stems and sago-like pith of the large black fern tree, Korau, or Mamaku <i>(Cyathea medullaris). </I>
Notes:  (Colenso Botany North Isd)

Date:  0/0/1882
Source:  Brighter Britain
Author:  HAY
Vol / Page:  2/192
Edition:
Quote:  The Toi (<i>Cordyline indivisa</i>) is a more ornamental, rarer, and smaller species of `cabbage-tree'; ... The name of Toi likewise belongs to a herb (<i>Barbarea vulgaris</i>), the leaves of which are eaten like cabbage or spinach. <i>Ibid.</I>2/211 To them [greens] may be added the Toi (<i>Barbarea vulgaris</i>), a herb which served the ancient Maori as cabbage.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Art Album NZ Flora
Author:  FEATON
Vol / Page:  17
Edition:
Quote:  BARBAREA VULGARIS (<i>Linn</i>.) The Common Herb of St. Barbara. ... This herb is indigenous to the Northern Island, and was formerly used by the natives as food. Upon the authority of Mr. Collenso, the native name of this plant is `Toii'. <i>Ibid.</I> 178 Toii [Maori name] .. Cress [Settlers' name] .. Barbarea Australis .. Herb
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  472
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Toe-toe</I> and <I>Toi-toi</I>, Maori name of several species of native grass of the genus <I>Arundo,</I> especially <I>Arundo conspicua</I>, A. Cunn. <I>Toe-toe</I> is the right spelling in Maori, given in Williams' `Maori Dictionary.' In English, however, the word is frequently spelt <I>toi-toi</I>. It is also called<I> Prince of Wales feather. </I>

Date:  25/3/1851
Source:  Richmond-Atkinson Papers
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/80
Edition:
Quote:  [The Waikato] runs through ... deep fern fringed with raupo (a bullrush) ...[sic] and the magnificent toi-toi, a gigantic grass whose flower stalk is from 8 to 12 feet and has an exquisite feather of two feet long playing in every air. This grass is ... with the phormium tenax the most remarkable of the open country vegetable products. ... You see many native dwellings & many canoes for they are a most locomotive people, few as ignorant of all but their own kainga as our British Hodge. There are troops of wild ducks & shags, some hawks of large size, bitterns & smaller waterfowl unknown to me.
Notes:  (J.C. Richmond)

Date:  0/0/1903
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  35/319
Edition:
Quote:  <i> ... large numbers of aua or kataha</i> (Agonostoma forsteri); <i>about 60 lb. ... weight of pilchard or mohimohi (Clupea sagax)</i>, two varieties; ... hundreds of young red-cod, rarii <i>(Lotella bacchus)</i>, and what I believe are young rock-cod, or kokopu or rawaru<i> (Percis colias).</i> The red-cod were from 3 in. to 4 in. in length, and the rawaru, or, as the natives here call them, `toitoi' or `panepane', from 2 in. to 6 in. long
Notes:  Mair Fish in Piako River

Vol / Page:  362
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Cockabully.</i> Often shortened to <i>bully</i>, especially by fishermen; <i>Gobiomorphus gobioides,</i> a small freshwater fish. The word is probably derived from kokopu, one of the Maori names for it. Another Maori name is toitoi.

toki
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 3
Definition: by transference from an iron axe (head), iron or an object of iron or steel, such as a nail or fish-hook (note that most early trade `axes' or `tomahawks' were the iron heads only without the handles
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: aka tochee, toghee, tokee, tokey

toki
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the Maori adze or axe, originally of stone; an axe or tomahawk. [Maori]


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Author:  JOSEPH
Vol / Page:  113
Edition:
Quote:  `The jade, the pounamu ... It's a beautiful stone ... Look,' he said, holding up a long hooked ear-drop of pearly translucence, `that's tau tau and the stone is called inanga. And this, the pekapeka - they say the shape comes from the bat. This is for the ear, too - the mako, like a shark's tooth ... And these,' - he ran his fingers along a row of ... nephrite adzes - `toki. See this one' - he held the heavy red-mottled adze in his palm - `that's the red kind, totoweka, woodhen's blood. The deep green, that's kawakawa.'

tokoeka
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: South Island brown kiwi or the Stewart Island kiwi
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Difference is unclear between these two headwords except that this one is more general and used before the specific naming of the newly defined species of the other headword.  Also tokoweka.
