toll call
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a telephone call to a place beyond the free-calling area for residential subscribers.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes: DNZE refers to this as <i>formerly</i>, but it remains in use. This dictionary refers to an OED entry, but Collins would suggest that any such British use is obsolete.  (R. Mason) NZ `collect': England `reverse charge call' NZ `toll': England `toll' =local charge call NZ `toll': England `trunk' =a distant toll call

tomahawk
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: in Australia and New Zealand, a small axe or hatchet
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: also tommyhawk; possibly the most quoted reference is in the verses often attributed to Southey but written By Thomas Campbell in the <i>Pleasures of Memory</i> (lines ...), with <i>Erie's </i>altered in c1839-1840 by persons unknown to <i>Zealand's</i>: [quote]. The words is still used for a small belt axe (DEH: 2004)

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  473
Edition:
Quote:   a word of North-American Indian origin, applied in English to the similarly shaped short one-handed axe or hatchet. The word is not frequent in England, but in Australia the word <i>hatchet</i> has practically disappeared, and the word <i>Tomahawk</i> to describe it is in to the stone hatchet of the Aboriginals. A popular corruption of it is <i>Tommy-axe</i>. [1802; NZ 1888]

Citations
Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  Islands
Author:
Vol / Page:  37/35
Edition:
Quote:  But they drew no laughter, all soldier eyes on female nakedness itself. The dark girl, much the younger, appeared to be Nubian, though with mix of European blood to leaven swart African, so giving to velvet skin a rich midnight bronze matching densely crimped black curls tinged with deepest red. In soldier dialect tomato blondes were tuppence a dozen in the Cairo melting pot. Here in startling relief Port Said offered all-over tomato brunette.
Notes:  WWII

tom-bobbler
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  174
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles had a language of its own... Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates,.. tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  NZ Yesterdays
Author:  KEITH & MAIN
Vol / Page:  288
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1916
Source:  Aloe, The
Author:  MANSFIELD
Vol / Page:  159
Edition:  (1982 O'Sullivan)
Quote:  ... all the men he phoned were fixd [sic] up except this young chap, just out from England who was staying at the Club. ... He seemed a decent sort of chap - quiet - a bit stand offish like most of these English `Tommies'. [This passage is crossed out.] [fn 164] `English Tommies": like the phrase `English Johnny' which Mansfield used in her story <i>Millie</i> in 1912, this is presumably a contemporary New Zealand expression for a recent immigrant.

Notes:

Date:  6/5/1911
Source:  NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page:  306/2/4
Edition:
Quote:  Wonder how bookmakers came to be known as `Tommies"? `Tommy [sic] is short for Tommy Rook, and probably it was owing to `rook' sounding something like "book' that caused some wag to term him as such. A rook would apply to some bookmakers, but where does the `Tommy' come in? The bookmakers were never named Tommies after soldiers, who are so dubbed, for when the latter lie on the field they've generally been shot at, whereas the bookie when he lays on the field, he's not been shot at, and, moreover, he never lays himself open to be shot at, either by marksmen or punters. Tommy is certainly a misnomer, and it should have been applied to a backer, who is ever the target for the unerring aim of the Bar Von.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Thoroughbreds Are My Life
Author:  TUCKER
Vol / Page:  167
Edition:
Quote:  By the same token some of the bookmakers that I have known have been fearless fielders. There is a fascinating story of one of New Zealand's `tommies' who went through a very bad patch.

Citations
Date:  13/10/1984
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  48
Edition:
Quote:  `The consensus seems to be that the object is a pit-candle holder. There are different names for them in Australia and New Zealand where they're known as pit spiders or in New Zealand only as tommy sticks,' Mrs Hall said. She said many old miners or children of miners had rung her to identify the object.

Pit-candle holders were used with carbide lamps in mines. The pointed part was put into the pit prop with the hook hanging down. The candle was put through the hoop.
Notes:

tomo
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a cave or hole;  a chute-like hole made by water in especially volcanic material. [Maori ?]; a water-worn hole; a sink-hole in limestone country f. ?Maori tomoau, abyss (Williams 435), or the noun f.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations

Source:  NZ Speleological Bulletin
Author:
Vol / Page:  I/5 : 10
Edition:
Quote:  A "tomo", for the benefit of novices and overseas readers, is from the Maori language, a generic term for any sort of pot-hole or sink-hole.

Quote:  The underlying caves are mainly horizontal, often with steep entrance shafts known as tomos (<i>wai</i> means water, <i>tomo</i> a hole in the ground).

Vol / Page:  79
Edition:
Quote:  At a 'tomo' (betrothal) ceremony, "Ratu's father then spoke... [later] the tomo proceedings had merged into that of the beer party."
Notes:  See Hohepa <i> A Maori Community in Northland</i> 1970, pp. 99-100

tomtit
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a small bird found in both the native bush and exotic forest, also called miromiro or ngirungiru; occas. used for esp Petroica toitoi, pied tit, white-breasted tit (tomtit preferred for euphemistic reasons to TIT simplex)
Origin: [none]

Register 2:
Domain: Environment
Region: [none]
See: tit

Tongue and Meat Club
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: Wellington Tramping AND Mountaineering Club


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1952 R. Mason A contemptuous nickname for this club which assumed the all-inclusive provincial title though only the fourth or fifth oldest in Wellington. Now (1952) used by W.T.M.C. members themselves. At a meeting of the Wellington Association of Mountain Clubs a member of the W.T.M.C. can be a `Tongue and Meat'.

Citations
Date:  0/9/1958
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:  30
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Tongue and Meat Club</I>, that name bestowed on the Wellington Tramping and Mountaineering Club by the scarcely sympathetic members of fellow clubs when it first adopted its present name, has become so established that a W.T.M.C member may now introduce himself by saying `I'm a Tongue and Meat'.

tonguer
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: the worker who takes out the tongue and weasands
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1951 May 17 Feilding freezing Works p.c. Colin Gordon <i>Tonguer</i>: one who cuts out tongue and who also `pulls the weasands'. [wiz ndz]
Citations
tonguer
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1941
Source:  NZ Slang
Author:  BAKER
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  The now obsolete term <i>tonguer</i> was also in use in the early 1830's, and very likely before it although I have discovered no written records of it prior to 1836. A tonguer was a native or white living in New Zealand who assisted a whaling crew to cut up whales and who also acted in the capacity of an interpreter. These men earned their name not from the act of interpreting, but from the fact that they were given the whale's carcase and tongue to dispose of as they wished.


Notes:

Date:  28/4/1835
Source:  Log of Mary Mitchell
Author:  CAPT JOY
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  ... it was told to me by our toungers [sic, at Cloudy Bay] that the cost [of a shore-hut] was trifling. ... I left them [sc Maoris] Came [sic] on board and despatched the boat the other side for a linguist our tounger. (The Ships all employ Tonguers [sic] and it is a general custom I have acceded on the same terms as others) On his arrival we opened the Subject but they [sc Maoris] were ashamed and finally settled that they would build the house. ...

I must not omit here Some mention of what are called tonguers. they [sic] are here 2 and 3 white people who have a boat and some natives on a ship arriving they repair on board to solicit the Job for the ship The terms are that they occasionally furnish a crew to help tow whales they furnish a boats crew to help cut the whale in and do any talking for the captain whose ignorance of the language requires their aid in any matters with the natives. When the whale is cut in they are entitled to the carcass and the tongue which in plentiful Whaling is always left on the carcass and they contrive to get for [sic] 6 to 8 barrels of oil from each carcass but they are in general Blackguards and no dependence can be put in them - Runaways from Ships Mostly. [McNab's ed. fn] The Americans had ... to rely to a great extent upon Maori labour and to be indebted to the services of interpreters. These men were locally [?Cloudy Bay] called `tonguers'. ... In `The Piraki Log' [1911] the word `tonguer' is suggested as a corruption of the Maori `tonga'. This is quite wrong. The tonguer was a man who interpreted and assisted in cutting up and who was paid with the tongue of the whale.[choose between this and following citation???]
Notes:  1836 Apr 28 Capt. Joy Log of Mary Mitchell in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 435, 436



Date:  28/4/1836
Source:  Log of Mary Mitchell
Author:  CAPT JOY
Vol / Page:  39
Edition:
Quote:  The Principal Chief (Te Rauparaha) is absent on one of his marauding traverses like the Ancient bands (of) Pirates and his authority delegated to 3 chiefs 1 on the western shore the other 2 here ... I despatched the boat the other side for a linguist or tonguer ...

I must not omit here Some[sic] mention of what are called touguers. They are here 2 or 3 white people who have a boat [40] and some natives. On a ship arriving they repair on board to solicit the Job for the ship. The terms are that they occasionally furnish a crew to help tow whales, they furnish a boats crew to help cut the whale in and do any talking for the Captain whose ignorance of the language requires their aid in any matters with the natives. When the whale is cut in they are entitled to the carcass & the tongue which in plentiful Whaling is always left on the carcass and they contrive to get from 6 to 8 barrels of oil from each carcass but they are in general Blackguards and no dependence can be put in them - Runaways from Ships Mostly.
Notes:

Date:  10/4/1839

Vol / Page:  82
Edition:
Quote:  [He] found it to be James Robinson, the <I>Tonguer</I> from Wongooloa [ed Anson note Glossary 166: The word is obviously a corruption of the Maori `tonga' meaning `from the South', or `Southerner'; ... ]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1840
Source:  Plain Truths
Author:  JOHNSON
Vol / Page:  60
Edition:
Quote:  After the ships had cut off the blubber ... the carcase was towed on shore by a crew of men, who call themselves `tonguers'. These men take off what little blubber the ship's crew have passed over, and also take out the tongue and try it all out.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1843
Source:  Travels in NZ
Author:  DIEFFENBACH
Vol / Page:  1/51
Edition:
Quote:  The tongue was of a white or ash colour, blackish towards the root. This organ gave several barrels of oil, and is a monopoly of the `tonguer,' or `cutter-in.' The latter operation is performed in Te-awa-iti near the shores, where by means of a windlass the whale is raised to the surface of the water under a scaffold called the `shears.' <i>Ibid.</I> 1/109 To this quantity must be added the tonguer's oil, so called from the man who `cuts-in the whale,' for which he is allowed the oil of the tongue, of the heart, and of the intestines, for his own benefit.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1845
Source:  Adventure in NZ
Author:  WAKEFIELD
Vol / Page:  1/323
Edition:
Quote:  The ["tonguer"]takes his name from having an exclusive right to the oil obtained from the tongue and other interior parts of the whale in payment for his duty of `cutting in', or dissecting the whale.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1913
Source:  Old Whaling Days
Author:  McNAB
Vol / Page:  194
Edition:
Quote:  The Americans had ... to rely to a greater extent on Maori labour, and to be indebted to the services of interpreters. These men were locally [at Cloudy Bay] called `tonguers'. <i>Ibid.</I> 322 The Robinsons, so their names were given to the Doctor [Thiercelin in January 1840 at Akaroa], acted as `carcassiers', as the French called them, collecting stray floating whales, or the intestines of whales ... blown into the Bay, and melting them down to produce an inferior [323] class of oil which they sold to the whalers. Among the English-speaking whalers these men were called `tonguers'.
Notes:  [see also 1836 citations???]

Date:  0/0/1941
Source:  NZ Slang
Author:  BAKER
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  The now-obs word tonguer was also in use in the early 1830's... These men earned their name not from the ... interpreting, but from the fact that they were given whale's carcass and tonguer to dispose of as they wished,' B., 1945: New Zealand and whalers': C. 19.

toot
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an idle or worthless person; a simpleton, fool 1888-1894; a worthless (or silly) person; also used in address: `You bloody toot!

Register:

It was supposed to help the sheep, although I never thought it did any good.

tooth-leaved beech
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Nothofagus  fusca
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: beech
Pronunciation:
Notes: [So Kirk, Botany Thames Goldfields TrNZI 1869 90]

Citations
Date:  0/0/1879
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  11/445
Edition:
Quote:  The tooth-leaved beech (<i>Fagus fusca</i>) occurs in considerable quantity at the sea level ...


Notes:   (Kirk Hauraki Gulf)

Date:  0/0/1885
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  17/300
Edition:
Quote:  [<i>Notho]fagus fusca</i>,Hook. f. ... Tooth-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Auckland and in part of Otago and Southland. Black or Bull Birch of Lake Wakatipu. Red Birch of Wellington, Nelson, and in part of Otago and Southland. It is not so easy to see why any difficulty should have occurred in the identification of this fine timber-tree apart from the misleading tendency of the common names generally applied. The thin yet firm texture of the leaf, the prominent veins, the sharply-toothed margins, are characters that can only be confused with those afforded by a careless observer. Yet merely owing to the use of common names based upon colour, and applied or rather misapplied to the leaves, bark, or wood at the fancy of the bushman, no species has been more misunderstood. <i>Ibid.</i> 302 All the men engaged at the sawmills [of West Oxford] had heard of `tooth-leaved beech,' but only one or two of them had seen it growing, and no one had seen it converted. TOOTH-LEAVED B. <i>F. fusca</i>, Hook f. All these, however, are commonly called<i> Birches. </i>
Notes:  (Kirk, NZ Beeches),

Date:  0/0/1875
Source:  Durability NZ Timbers
Author:  KIRK
Vol / Page:  17
Edition:
Quote:  With the view of obviating the confusion caused by the misuse of the common names hitherto applied to the New Zealand beeches, I would suggest the adoption of new names based on the obvious characteristics of their foliage:- For I>Fagus fusca</I>,  tooth-leaved beech; for <I>Fagus solandri</I>, entire-leaved beech; and for <I>Fagus menziesii</I>, round-leaved beech.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1876
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  64/
Edition:
Quote:  The utmost confusion prevails among the common names of the birches. There are scarcely two districts, a few miles apart, in which the same name is applied to the same tree, and a similar result may be obtained by consulting two bushmen in the same bush. With a view to obviating this difficulty Mr Kirk suggests `the adoption of new names based of the obvious characteristics of foliage [e.g.] for Fagus fusca `tooth-leaved beech'; for Fagus solandri `entire-leaved beech' etc. [This is unsuitable as foliage varies] I would suggest the retention of the common Otago names Fagus fusca - Red birch ; F. solandri - Black-heart birch ; F Menziesii - Silver birch.
Notes:  (Blair),

Date:  0/0/1880
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  12/
Edition:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  63
Edition:
Quote:  TOPE OR SCHOOL SHARK <i>Notogaleus rhinophanes</i> (Peron) The origin of the vernacular name Tope is not certain, but local fishermen who followed this occupation in Britain, said this name is a corruption of `top' in allusion to its well-known habit of following the lines to the top of the water and then snatching off Whiting or other hooked fish in full view of the helpless fisherman. Other New Zealand common names are Southern Tope and School Shark.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Marine Fishes
Author:  MORELAND
Vol / Page:  12

Date:  0/0/1981

Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  224
Edition:
Quote:  SCHOOLFISH The flesh, like that of the gummies, is quite edible and regularly marketed, usually as Lemonfish. The Schoolshark is usually dark-grey-green above and white below. Known also as Tope and Sand shark they are the only fish who close their eyes when they sleep.

Notes:

Date:  29/9/1945
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  Recently I bought some carrots from my greengrocer.   I was indignant to find that they had been weighed with great bunches of tops, which added somewhat to their weight, particularly as they had gone to seed.   When I asked that the carrots should be weighed without this top-hamper, I was told that they had been bought from the Internal Marketing Department in that condition so they were obliged to sell them with the tops on to avoid loss to themselves.

topknot
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: the kempy wool growing on a sheep's head that may cause wool-blindness.

tops
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: usually pl with def art THE TOPS, the top of a ridge; a peak; (collectively) the tops of hills, ridges, or mountains, the highest country (usually above the bushline) occas. in phrs ON TOP (cp BOTTOMS) cf also TOP MAN -
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: used regularly in weather forecasts

The `topuni' consists of a large flax cloak, into which is fastened, with every thread, a portion of dog's hair, assorted into various colours, having the exact appearance of a beautiful fur.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1979
Source:  Titi Heritage
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  55
Edition:
Quote:  Ever since the beginning, to `take' meant journeying to the islands and living there for the season and using hands or any device to catch the birds. ... to `take' also includes an `attempt to take'. During the torching season the birds run down the paths to the sea at night. Paths are used as boundaries by the [56] supervisors and in some cases the dividing line is the middle of the path. If one pursues a bird and grabs it over the other edge of the path one can be prosecuted, even although the bird came from the pursuer's manu. <i>Ibid.</I> 68 The `torching' season became known as such because the birders used flaming torches thick enough to be held aloft comfortably grasped in the hand. They were about three feet long and well soaked in muttonbird fat, before being set alight and were made from dry tree branches. Piles of these `torches' were prepared and set aside awaiting [69] the start of the `torching' and each family had their torch bearers. In most cases this duty was carried out by the children. Gradually this primitive method of `lighting the way' gave place to the European kerosene lantern and when supplies of kerosene were exhausted a lighted candle was sometimes used inside the glass globe of the lantern.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  In the Grip of an Island
Author:  SANSOM
Vol / Page:  153
Edition:
Quote:  First part of the work over except for scrapings. Coming up to torching time. Birds excellent in quality and quantity.
Notes:

Date:  14/10/1953
Source:  NZ Observer
Author:
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  About April 20 the birds start coming out of their burrows and torching begins.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1979
Source:  Titi Heritage
Author:
Vol / Page:  68
Edition:
Quote:  The 'torching' season become known as such because the birders, used flaming torches thick enough to be held aloft comfortably grasped in the hand.

Date:  0/3/1998
Source:  Geological Society of NZ Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  115/53
Edition:
Quote:  As far as I know, there is no adequate definition of the upper limit of the Torlesse. There is a default definition: the Torlesse is the rocks of the accretionary complex below a line, commonly a discordant contact, that are more deformed, less fossiliferous and generally more geologiacally intractable than those above.
Notes:

Date:  0/7/1998
Source:  Geological Society of NZ Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  116/21
Edition:

Quote:   [=? Suttonia; ? Persoonia] The Toro, this tree grows naturally into a perfect oval, and the leafs [sic] at the extremity of each branch are pink, the others quite green and printed. It seldom grows larger than 40 feet and its flower has a pleasing and odoriferous smell. [<i>glossary</i> 120 ...<i> Suttonia salicina</i>. The reference to flower odour suggests <i>Persoonia toru</i>, also sometimes known as toro].

Vol / Page:  605
Edition:
Quote:  <i>P[ersoonia] Toru,</i> A.Cunn. ... <i>North Cape to Rotorua and East Cape. ... Toru; Toro.</i> ... The specific name was given as `Toru' in Cunningham's original description ... and according to Mr Colenso this is the proper spelling of the Maori name. It was, however, changed to `Tora' ..., and was again altered to `Toro' by Sir J.D. Hooker.

Date:  0/5/2004
Source:  Footnotes
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 21/7

Quote:  They include <i>Carex cirrhosa</i> (a sedge which was growing at the edge of a boat ramp at Lake

Wairarapa), the Castlepoint daisy, not found anywhere else in the world, and shrubby tororaro or <i>Meuhlenbeckia astonii</i>, a coastal shrub ranked as nationally vulnerable.

Date:  30/12/2003

Author:
Vol / Page:  C2
Edition:
Quote:  At the far end of a flat triangular peninsula, you'll find an exclosure plot built by the Conservation Department to protect the last few shrubby tororaro in the area.
Notes:

Date:  1/9/2001
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  Muehlenbeckia astonii, the shrubby tororaro, suffered habitat disturbance, unseasonal chills, roading, quarrying, fire, and predation everything from horses, goats and possums to rabbits and invertebrates. Today there are just 44 wild plants in DOC's Wellington conservancy, and its conservation status is "highest priority threatened species".
Notes:

Date:  0/1/2004
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 67/11
Edition:
Quote:  Among the species being grown in the new reserves are <i>Muehlenbackia astonii</i> (shrubby tororaro), <i>Euphorbia glauca</i> (shore spurge, thought to have been extinct in the Wellington region for 20 years, then rediscovered in 1996/96 on a rocky stack off Kapiti Island), <i>Discaria tomentosa</i> (a species of anchor plant, one of Wellington's - and the North Island's - rarest plants), <i>Hebe speciosa</i> (showy hebe) and <i>Tetragonia tetragonioides</i> (New Zealand spinach).

Quote:  That [tobacco] which they grow universally obtains the name of Torore which signifies intoxicating.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1868
Source:  Past and Present of NZ
Author:  TAYLOR
Vol / Page:  134
Edition:
Quote:  (fn) This song has a great deal of meaning : the being bereft of pipe refers to the very heavy duty which had been put on tobacco, to make the native, who was the chief consumer, pay as much as possible; but this over-grasping defeated itself. The native, unable to purchase tobacco to the extent he formerly did, began to grow it himself, and from instructions he has contrived to pick up, he now manufactures it; this he calls <I>torore</I>; some of it is so well made that there are great smokers who will give equal weight of our best tobacco for it.
Notes:

Date:  19/1/1870
Source:  Daily Southern Cross
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  A stranger - a white man - passes through and stops to give his horse a feed; at once some twenty or thirty people turn out; and squat down in all dignity, wrapping their blankets around them like so many Roman consuls, smoke their vile burning torore (why they prefer that to our Cavendish at 8s. the lb. I can't understand), and take notes of every gesture.

Quote:  Gilbert said that he had plenty of money as he played pool, toss the coin and won quinellas at the races. He refused to `point the finger' at where Mr Maddox got the dope. `... this has spoilt a good day. I have been raging all day. I punched him over because he tried to punch me over, and put me in my place. He reckoned he was a Liverpudlian seaman who had been here for 20 years, a big toughie,' Gilbert had told him.
Notes:

In 1880 a Mr Ekberg patented an elementary type of totalisator which was first used at the Canterbury Jockey Club in that year.

Kopuawai, <i>Koputaratara, Papati </ik>and<i> Totara</i>, all these are descriptive names, implying that it is covered with sharp spines, and is inflated; this singular fish is frequently cast up on the shore, and sometimes of a large size.

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  475
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Totara, n. </i>Maori name for a lofty-spreading New Zealand tree, <i>Podpcarpus totara,</i> A. Cunn., <i>N.O. Coniferae</i>. In Maori, the accent falls on the first syllable; but in English use it is often placed on the second, and from Mr. Polack's spelling it must have been so as early as 1840. Called also <i>Mahogany-pine</i>. There are several other species, e.g. <i>P. vivalis</i>, Hook, the <i>Mountain Totara</i>; called also <i>Mahogany Pine</i>.
Notes:   see <i>Mahogany</i>, and <i>Pine.</i> [1832 on various cits]

Quote:  <i>totara n.</i> a tall coniferous forest tree of New Zealand with durable wood.

Date:  0/0/1838
Source:  New Zealand  (Polack)
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/105
Edition:
Quote:  There is scarcely a more splendid sight to behold than a New Zealand forest. In the one we now entered, we did not perceive any kouri, or yellow pine-trees; but the totara [a's-acute], or red pine, grew in vast abundance .. The rito, and innumerable other palm-trees, were in great quantity.

<i>Ibid.</I> 1/286 .. tota[acute]rra <i>Ibid.</I> 2/391 <i>Totara</i> [a's-acute] (<i>taxus australis</i>) g. coniferae .. is known as red pine.

Edition:
Quote:  Fighting above Anzac Cove in late April 1915 would be similar to fighting today on the gorse and scrub-covered slopes around Wellington Harbour and the Hutt. It `was very thick and stood about 5ft high and was of a laurel leaf type very like `Tote' that is found in New Zealand.' It was such scrub that the Anzacs laid in their coffin trenches.

Citations
Date:  0/0/1962
Source:  Pound of Saffron, A
Author:  JOSEPH
Vol / Page:  113
Edition:
Quote:  `The jade, the pounamu ... It's a beautiful stone ... Look,' he said, holding up a long hooked ear-drop of pearly translucence, `that's tau tau and the stone is called inanga. And this, the pekapeka - they say the shape comes from the bat. This is for the ear, too - the mako, like a shark's tooth ... And these,' - he ran his fingers along a row of ... nephrite adzes - `toki. See this one' - he held the heavy red-mottled adze in his palm - `that's the red kind, totoweka, woodhen's blood. The deep green, that's kawakawa.'
Notes:

totokipio
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:
Definition: the dabchick
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1873
Source:  Birds of New Zealand
Author:  BULLER
Vol / Page:  350
Edition:  1888 2nd edn 2/280
Quote:  PODICEPS RUFIPECTUS. (NEW-ZEALAND DABCHICK.) ... <i>Native names</i>.- Weweia, Totokipio \{, Taihoropi (Hokianga), and Taratimoho (Waikato)\}.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1945
Source:  Maori Place-Names of Canterbury
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  64
Edition:
Quote:  Totokepio is the `little diver' of the settler to distinguish it from the `big diver' (the crested grebe). The Canterbury compiler spells it as given, but in Southland the name is Totokipio, and if taken in sections To-toki-pio it is easy to pronounce. The kamana or crested grebe is not mentioned.
Notes:  c1880 South Island Maori Lists `Wahi Mahika Kai' in 1945 Beattie Maori Place-names of Canterbury 64

Date:  0/0/1886
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  18/113
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Podiceps rufipectus</i>. - Totokipio, Dabchick. Both Islands.
Notes:  (Martin)

touch noses
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: to hongi
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1817
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  NICHOLAS
Vol / Page:  1/91
Edition:
Quote:  Duaterra immediately recognised [the chief], and ... behaved to him with particular respect, touching noses with him, the usual mode of salutation in this part of the world, when any honour is to be paid, and which he did not do with the other chief. The latter he contemptuously described as an ittee ittee rungateeda, or a chief possessing very little power.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1820
Source:  Journal
Author:  ALEX McCRAE
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  On taking leave of these boys I touched noses with them.

Author:  HOWARD
Vol / Page:  345
Edition:
Quote:  We were received by them all sitting and after the salutation of touching noses, they eagerly enquired for what purpose we had come.

touch one's foblocker
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: to reach for or spend one's money; pay out (cf. touch one's kick etc.)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1951 Wellington (Foblocker, ? a portmanteau coinage from fob @n `small (money-)  pocket in the waistband of trousers' (OED n2) and locker `a secure cupboard (for valuables etc.))

Then came `The Dinkums' - the true fighting men as they called themselves.

Register:

Region: [none]

Pronunciation:
Notes: aka totowai

Author:
Vol / Page:  55/159
Edition:
Quote:  <i>toutouwai,</i> a bird (Miro longipes), the North Island form; the South Island form (Miro australis) bears the same name, the two forms differing only in the coloration of the breast and abdomen, which are white in the former, and in the latter the abdomen yellowish-white tinged with lemon-yellow on the breast.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

tow truck
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a truck designed to tow broken-down or damaged or illegally-parked vehicles
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim writes: BritE = <i>breakdown van</i>. Not recorded in DNZE but cf <i>towie</i> - "tow-truck driver or operator". Not in NSOD. Collins tags it as <i>US and Canadian. Tow truck</i> is standard NZE.

towai
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a tall spreading forest tree of the North Island, related to the kamahi. [Maori towai[o-macron]]. also called tawhero; <i>Weinmannia racemosa</i>, kamahi (in the n. North Island <i>W. sylvicola,</I> tawhero)
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: TOWAI( or TAWHERO) <i>W. silvicola</i> up to 15m. n.NI to 38 lat.; <i>W. racemosa </i> kamahi takes over from about 37 lat. southwards (from Manukau south) and is the `red birch' of Westland
Citations
Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2032
Edition:
Quote:  <i>To&#769;.wa-i </I>(t&omacr.&#769;.wä.&ibreve. or t&omacr.&#769;.-w&imacr.),<i> n</i>. [Maori.] <i>(Bot.)</i> A New Zealand saxifragaceous tree (<i>Weinmannia racemosa</i>); - called also <i>birch. [Local, N. Z.] </i>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1817
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  NICHOLAS
Vol / Page:  1/329
Edition:
Quote:  ... towha,another species of pine, not so large as the totara, small, narrow leaf, smooth bark, berry.[check that this is towai] <I>Ibid.</I> Nicholas NZ 2/245 The trees which the natives chiefly make subservient to their purposes, are [besides the pines cowrie, totarra, towha and zarida mentioned above] ... the henow, from which they extract a black dye, the towha, a tree resembling the sycamore, the <i>river river</i>, the grain of whose wood is similar to that of the beech, a species of cork-tree, called by these people vow, a large tree named eckoha, and another named kycata, a tall and beautiful tree, ... <i>Ibid.</I> 1/330 The<i> towha</i>, another species of pine, though not so large as the <i>totarra</i>, grew here [Waimate, Northland] at the same time to a considerable size, and the forest abounded with it. This tree has likewise a small and narrow leaf, but its bark is thin and quite smooth; it bears a berry which is eaten by the natives.

Its wood ... has a handsome deep red colour when polished. It grows to the heighth [sic] of twenty-five feet, and then is richly furnished with virent leaves. The wood is heavy and but little used hitherto.

Vol / Page:  135
Edition:
Quote:  WEINMANNIA SILVICOLA (<I>Banks & Sol.</I>) ... The `TOWAI'.- ... The wood is similar in quality to its ally<I> W. racemosa,</I> but is denser, and of finer grain; ... [136] This tree is sometimes called Tawhero, or Kamai, and is not unusually confounded with <I>W. racemosa</I>, the Tawhero or Kamai proper. In the same manner the tawhero is confused with this species by the uninitiated.

Notes:

towai

towai
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 4
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: cf 43 Towa berries; description of wood fits <i>W. racemosa</i> and not TAWA; but does kamahi have oil-bearing berries
Citations
Date:  0/0/1842
Source:  New Zealand (Heaphy)
Author:  HEAPHY
Vol / Page:  42
Edition:
Quote:  The red pines are the <i>Totara, Towa, Mahi</i>, and <i>Rata</i>, all of which are close-grained, and moderately hard. They are used principally for interior work, in house-building, and for furniture-making. They are all of a red colour, and when oiled and polished are very ornamental. ... All these red firs make good spars for ships, and are frequently used by vessels visiting the settlements. The Towa spars are considered the best for this purpose. The fore-yard of the <i>Tory</i>, a 400 ton ship, was made from a green <i>towa</i> spar obtained in Queen Charlotte's Sound, which stood many severe tests without sustaining any injury. ... The only fault of this wood is its weight, but in that respect it is less objectionable than the teak which is used for the masts of all Indian-built vessels. [43] ... The <i>Towa</i> and the <i>Kraka</i> berries also yield an useful oil, but not in such quantity as that first mentioned.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1853
Source:  Flora NZ
Author:  HOOKER
Vol / Page:  I Flowering Plants 224
Edition:
Quote:  The `Milk-tree' of the Nelson and Wellington colonists is described by Mr. Bidwill and Dr. Sinclair as producing a milk which is used with tea, and is equally suitable for the purpose with that of the cow; it is also drunk as it flows from the tree, and is good and sweet, but has a vegetable after-taste. - A large tree, 60 feet high, ... often extremely like <i>Carpodetus Serratus.</i> ... Nat. name `Towai', <i>Raoul. </i>

Quote:  ``At 10 a.m. sent a party of men on shore to destroy the town and the canoes. At noon the people returned with two pigs, having destroyed the principal part of the town and canoes with fire. At 2 p.m. the people went on shore again and set fire to the remainder part of the town, canoes, huts, and all their food, and returned with one large pig and two small ones.

town acre
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an allotment of land in a prospective town to a New Zealand Company settler. [AND 1838]; the acre-section of town land allocated by the NZ Company for every twenty acres of uncleared `suburban' land purchased
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: cf. country acre
Pronunciation:
Notes: see also town section

town acre man
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a person who owned land in town under the town acre system and did not farm his allotted rural land seriously.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1864
Source:  BLANK ENTRY
Author:  HASTIE
Vol / Page:  5

town belt
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: OED : N.Z., a belt of public land reserved chiefly for recreational purposes in or round a town; a belt of reserve land around or in a town or city, vested in the town authority and reserved for public, scenic or recreational purposes; also THE BELT

A footpath, 10 ft. wide on each side of the Belt, two roadways running parallel to the footpaths, each half a chain in width, leaving 46 ft. clear in the middle of the Belt, to be planted with trees, so as to allow a 10 ft. grass-walk down the centre of each block between the intersecting streets. Each block was to be planted with one variety of tree.

Date:  7/1/2001
Source:  Capital Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  The Town Belt was originally 1500 acres in extent. It is now only about 1100 acres (430 hectares). But this is land that was supposed to be "<i>reserved for the enjoyment of the public and not to be built upon</i>"... A need arose, an itch had to be scratched, and the Town Belt was the best/cheapest/least politically-damaging option available.

Quote:  Most Wellingtonians would be surprised at the history of the city's Town Belt, but the mystery will be unravelled at an exhibition opening at the Museum of Wellington City and Sea tomorrow... The original Town Belt Deed of 1873, which transferred the Town Belt in trust to the people of Wellington from the Provincial Government and is still an active document, will be on display.
Notes:

Date:  0/8/2001
Source:  Absolutely Positively Wellington
Author:
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  "It is indeed desirable that the whole of the town inland should be separated from the country sections by a broad belt of land which you will declare that the Company intends to be public property on the condition that no buildings ever be built on it." New Zealand Company Secretary John Ward to Surveyor General William Mein Smith, August 1839. And so the idea of Wellington's fantastic Town Belt was born... The 425 ha Town Belt, including the beloved Botanic Garden - is indeed public property - and it's admniistered by the City Council on behalf of Wellingtonians.

town day
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the day that farmers travel to town for supplies, usually on a stock sale day.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

town house
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: one of a group of similar houses especially but not essentially in the central part of town (gen. Engl. sense a house in town)
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: cf British use and Canterbury use eg of Runholder Charles H.Greenstreet He had a town house in the corner of Mays[???] Rd. Papanui.

Date:  0/0/1987
Source:  Te Reo
Author:
Vol / Page:  30/132
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Town house</i> is in, and uneasily acceptable as a `residence in town esp. of person with house in the country' although `in the country' could be better phrased; but `house in (esp. terraced) group in town' is not apt, and increasingly the style for this type of dwelling is <i>townhouse.</i> That is, `My town house is a townhouse', correctly distinguishes, on the page, and will be distinguished in speech; tow stresses for the one, and one stress (TOWNhouse) for the other. There is as well a question of nuance to be noticed. A <i>townhouse</i> is emphatically upmarket from a <i>home unit.</I>
Notes:  Smithyman Review NZPOD

Date:  16/9/1988
Source:  Victoria Univ. Weekly Staff Circular

town supply
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: the provision of fresh whole milk by farms to local milk treatment stations [requiring a proportion of autumn-calvers for milking to continue in the winter months] or the farm that provides such milk.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: aka town-supply

Notes:

township
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: a small town,a village;  occasionally in early NZ usage (or of British planners' usage) the paper or planned site for a town; but quckly developing the sense village, small town, and becoming the usual word in NZ for what in Britain (and in the usage of many early writers) would be called a village or hamlet (cp VILLAGE)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: native township, Maori township
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1960 the Main Highway signs in diminishing progression of size include: City, Borough, Township, Settlement, Settled or Populated Area, Beware Stock [check AAand/or MWD]

Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  476
Edition:
Quote:   a village, a possible future town. In the United States, the word has a definite meaning - a district, subordinate to a country, the inhabitants having power to regulate their local affairs; in Australia, the word has no such definite meaning. It may be large or small, and sometimes consists of little more than the post-office, the public-house, and the general store or shop.

Date:  0/0/1899
Source:  In the Shadow of the Bush
Author:  BELL
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  Townships are formed here and there as settlement proceeds; - at first a store and post office, a cottage or a blacksmith's shop perhaps; then a hotel, another store, and again another hotel. <I>Ibid.</I> 20  Sanguine in their anticipations, and bountifully provident for the wants of posterity, the promoters of these bush townships - whether it were the Government, private companies or individuals, or a supplementing of the former by the latter - made the boundaries of them wide enough for all possible future requirements, and gave ample scope for prospective development. This was very commendable and necessary in some instances, but where a township, as sometimes happened, did not `go off' at the sale, or if it did go off, was never subsequently embellished with a building of any kind, the effect had something of the ludicrous about it - for while settlement went on around the `township,' and the land was cleared and occupied, the `town' itself remained a solid block of standing bush, and the absentee owners of its acre or quarter-acre sections were only reminded of their possessions by the persistent recurrence of the notices to pay rates
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1954
Source:  Te Raka
Author:  MACFARLANE
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  During our short history villages have come and gone, have flourished and then decayed, and some once again flourished. There is a story behind all these happenings. These many widely-scattered urban oases in the rural desert have been known for all their short lives as `townships'. A very ugly name coming down to us from the old digging days. Village' or just `town' are now gaining ground over the ugly old name, and rightly so. You could scarcely talk of beautifying a township, but could get quite enthusiastic over improving a village.

Quote:  [The runanga] will bear the same relation to other political machinery ... as the township in the United States of America bears to the county and state organization, and ministers suggest the name of township as the most suitable English term for the community that will be represented by a single runanga. It will correspond with the division of hundreds proposed by his Excellency. [Grey's annotation] I should have preferred the term `hundred'. It is already in use here. The natives will make a strange word out of `township'.

track
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: in NZ since 1839 (as elswhere), a rough path or way usually, originally, trodden clear; a rough unsurfaced road
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also bush track
Pronunciation:
Notes: also bush track		TRACK is the general use in NZ among outdoors people (trampers, etc); also for regular paths trodden by animals, e.g. <i>sheep tracks, goat tracks; trail</i> is occasionally used, ?esp. of deer cf also MAORI TRACK [AND seems to suggest a much wider spec. use in Aust.]
Citations
Date:  23/12/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:  ACLAND
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Track.</I>- Pack<I> t</I>., etc. Originally an unformed, unfenced way, but Leach's <i>T</i>., Shand's <i>T.,</i> etc., perpetuate the name. The county councils will probably alter these in time. The Bealey <i>T.</i> (to Hororata) is oftener than not called the Bealey road. `We came upon a very bad track-- that is the name by which all roads are called, and they don’t deserve a better.'--S.L., p.76.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1935
Source:  Handbook Arthur Pass National Park
Author:  ODELL
Vol / Page:  20
Edition:
Quote:  They will no doubt be ultimately opened up by the formation of tracks and the erection of huts, and will then allow of the fullest exploitation of the winter sports attractions of the Park. <i>Ibid.</i> 25 On tracks which are little used, for instance the Upper Edwards Bush Track, much assistance could be given to subsequent parties if travellers were to renew the blaze marks so that the `blazes' attracted the attention from a distance of those unfamiliar with the district.
Notes:

Date:  0/9/1958
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:
Quote:  In the bush or in the open do you tramp on a <i>track</i>, a <i>trail</i>, or a <i>path</i>? Not on a path one may be sure, seldom if ever on a trail, almost always on a track, like a proper New Zealander... <i>Track</i> is undoubtedly the established word in New Zealand. It is the only one occurring on maps or applied to named routes, such as <i>Hongi's track</i>, the <i>Milford track</i>, the <i>Pahiatua Bush Track Road</i>. ..[25] It is interesting to compare the use of <i>track</i> and<i> trail</i> in <i>The Tramper</i>. Through the first volumes <i>track</i> is always used when referring to an actual track, and <i>trail</i> occurs rarely and then only in the expression <i>blazed trail</i> or more or less figuratively - `to fare forth on the trail'. In 1935 there is the first definite use of <i>trail</i> as a synonym for <i>track</i> in a reference to the `Handbook of Arthur's Pass National Park'. It is significant that it occurs in reference to Arthur’s Pass for trail seems to have come into use in Canterbury in this sense before it reached Wellington. It occurs once or twice in the first volume of the <i>Canterbury Mountaineer</i>, and there is the <i>B.B. Trail </i>in the Arthur's Pass Hand book of 1935. From 1939 till 1940 in <i>The Tramper, trail </i>is used moderately frequently for an actual track, e.g. `an old Maori trail', `a miner's trail', but only by the one writer, a Wellington member of the Canterbury Mountaineering Club. <i>Trail</i> shows no sign of ousting <i>track. </i>
Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Paparoas Guide

Citations
Date:  0/9/1958
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:  25
Edition:
Quote:  In recent years there seems to have been a tendency to use both <i>track</i> and<i> trail</i> and to differentiate between them. A trail seems to be something narrow and perhaps rather hard to follow - a way marked only by blazes or worn by animals, usually deer. A track seems to be something broader, cut or formed by man. ... A well-known older Club member made this distinction when, on hearing him speak of a deer trail, I asked him what he thought to be the difference between <i>track</i> and <i>trail</i>. I remarked that I thought it a very recent distinction, one not occurring in the Club until about 1957. He disagreed, believing it to be one he had always known. Yet, on looking through <i>The Tramper, </i>

I could not find <i>deer trail</i> used until 1944, but <i>deer track</i> occurs from the first number in 1928 onwards, and he himself had used it in 1940. It remains to be seen whether this distinction will become established. In the meantime<i> deer track </i>still seems to be used far more than <i>deer trail.</i>
Notes:  1958 Sep Ruth Mason `Track and Trail' in Tararua 25

tracking
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: track or the railing from which curtains or drapes are suspended
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim writes: In relation to curtains or drapes there is no entry for these words in any dictionary I have seen., <i>Track</i> may be covered, though imprecisely, under one of the general definitions but <i>tracking</i> is not. Both words are in standard use in NZ. They seem likely to be international English but may be worth checking out.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  175
Edition:
Quote:  Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs.

Date:  0/0/1938

Author:  HYDE
Vol / Page:  126
Edition:  1970
Quote:  There was a dark trail, ... and a stream came with edgings of fine malachite ferns, ... Purple berries lay fallen, rich as damsons but not as big, and good only for the fantails ...
Notes:

Date:  0/9/1958
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:
Quote:  In the bush or in the open do you tramp on a <i>track, trail</i>, or a <i>path</i>? Not on a path one may be sure, seldom if ever on a trail, almost always on a track, like a proper New Zealander. ... I well remember the shock of astonishment when in 1937 I first saw <i>trail </i>used in New Zealand. The word was on a rough signpost pointing out the beginning of White's Track at Piha. I am afraid I thought somewhat scornfully, `Hm, some townie who has never been out of the city or set foot off a pavement has got all his ideas of New Zealand outdoor life from reading books about North America.'...[25] It is interesting to compare the use of <i>track</i> and <i>trail</i> in <i>The Tramper</i>. Through the first volumes <i>track</i> is always used when referring to an actual track, and <i>trail </i>occurs rarely and then only in the expression <i>blazed trail</i> or more or less figuratively - `to fare forth on the trail'. In 1935 there is the first definite use of<i> trail</i> as a synonym for <i>track</i> in a reference to the `Handbook of Arthur's Pass National Park'. It is significant that it occurs in reference to Arhtur's Pass for trail seems to have come into use in Canterbury in this sense before it reached Wellington. It occurs once or twice in the first volume of the <i>Canterbury Mountaineer</i>, and there

is the <i>B.B. Trail</i> in the Arthur's Pass Hand book of 1935. From 1939 till 1940 in <i>The Tramper, trail</i> is used moderately frequently for an actual track, e.g. `an old Maori trail', `a miner's trail', but only by the one writer, a Wellington member of the Canterbury Mountaineering Club. <i>Trail</i> shows no sign of ousting <i>track. </I>
Notes:  1958 Sep Ruth Mason `Track and Trail' in Tararua 24

Date:  0/9/1958
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:  25
Edition:
Quote:  In recent years there seems to have been a tendency to use both <i>track</i> and <i>trail</i> and to differentiate between them. A trail seems to be something narrow and perhaps rather hard to follow - a way marked only by blazes or worn by animals, usually deer. A track seems to be something broader, cut or formed by man. ... A well-known older Club member made this distinction when, on hearing him speak of a deer trail, I asked him what he thought to be the difference between<i> track </i>and <i>trail.</i> I remarked that I thought it a very recent distinction, one not occurring in the Club until about 1957. He disagreed, believing it to be one he had always known. Yet, on looking through <i>The Tramper</i>, I could not find <i>deer trail</i> used until 1944, but <i>deer track</i> occurs from the first number in 1928 onwards, and he himself had used it in 1940. It remains to be seen whether this distinction will become established. In the meantime <i>deer track</i> still seems to be used far more than <i>deer trail.</i>
Notes:  1958 Sep Ruth Mason `Track and Trail' (deer shooters')

Author:
Vol / Page:  237
Edition:
Quote:  The Director [of Repatriation] .. soon after the passing of the Repatriation Act in 1918, set out, with the assistance of the Department of Agriculture, to establish a training-farm at Tauherenikau, in the Wairarapa district, where returned soldiers suffering from chest trouble could be trained in poultry-keeping, bee-keeping, horticulture and general light farming so as to enable them to take up small holdings of their own under the Discharged Soldiers Settlement Act. The accompanying photographs afford a very good idea of the training-farm.

Date:  0/9/1958
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:  28
Edition:
Quote:  Words that concern walking and moving about might be expected to be of interest to a tramper. First there is the word <i>tramp</i> itself. Though the Club in 1919 was the first in New Zealand and probably the first in the world to take the name of <i>tramping club</i>, and by its usage and activities has played a considerable part in establishing the term, the meaning we give to <i>tramp</i> was not of New Zealand origin, for it was used colloquially in England as early as 1908 for `to go on foot, to go on a walking expedition'. The nature of the country into which the expeditions are made may often be very different from that [29] where the term originated, but the essential idea is the same. ...
Notes:  1958 Sep Ruth Mason `Track and Trail' in Tararua 28-29

Date:  0/0/1957
Source:  NZ Geog. Society Rec.
Author:
Vol / Page:  24/15
Edition:
Quote:   ... Uranium is soluble, even more so than copper, which is commonly known as `tramp metal', and consequently uranium salts have the ability to move through rocks provided they are porous.
Notes:

Date:  10/9/1958
Source:  Weekly News
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:   ... uranium is what the old miners used to call `tramp metal' ... What they meant was that it reacts readily with the weak acids in the ground water and the salts of uranium resulting from this reaction are very soluble moving through the space in porous rocks, or the cracks in denser rocks for miles from where they originated.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Hills, The
Author:  PICKERING
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  Who were the first trampers? The first person who carried a swag and did it for pleasure and not for its own sake? What about the Maori? Did they go tramping as such or were they out for food, or greenstone, or other Maori? And what about the gold-digger and the musterer? Surely their trades came first and if they enjoyed the walk it was likely that it was because they'd found some good pasture or a `bit of the colour'.

Date:  0/0/1958

Author:  STEPHENS in MILLER
Vol / Page:  63
Edition:
Quote:  Sometimes at night the rain came down in torrents, and their tents, quite ragged with rottenness, let in the cold air and wet most piteously. In the daytime they struggled through thickets of high fern, manuka and toitoi, and waded through icy flax swamps which caused them to suffer from swollen legs, rheumatism and colds. 'We surveyors as Pioneers,' wrote Samuel Stephens,'have a great deal of this tramping, and most tiring work it is.'
Notes:  1974 edition. Original quote from Stephens' <i>Letters</i> 1/1/1843

For example, a version of Buck Buck ... under the name Jumbucks is played today by one of New Zealand's tramping clubs (hiking clubs) in its haunts near the snowline. It is said that the hobnailed boots of the players contribute strongly to the hazards of the game.

trampoline
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]

See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1879
Source:  Spangles and Sawdust
Author:  WHITWORTH
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  I was down there with Old Ashmore's lot, doing the trampoline, and so on; but things was very quizby. Everything went crooked somehow, and the gorger had a hawful cramp in his kick. Well, ramp was the word, and vamose we did, the lot on us; some here, some there. I was reg'lar beached, and I tell you when a cove 'as to spout his smish it's about time to look out. However, I got a job at a livery stable, but although that kep' me in grub, and I slep' in a spare stall, the billet was very multy, and I kep' on the kivvy for something better. [fn] 1. [trampoline] Vaulter. 2. [quizby] Bad. 3. [crooked] Wrong. 4. [cramp in his kick] Emptiness in his pockets. 5. [ramp] Clear out. 6. [vamose] Go. 7. [beached] Hard up. 8. [smish] Shirt. 9. [multy] No good. 10. [kivvy] Look out (qui vive.)

Date:  6/6/1988
Source:  Dominion Sunday Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  `Pakeha' is a word that seems to be bugging many New Zealanders. Perhaps this is the reason why the Royal Commission on Social Policy in its booklet dealing with the Treaty of Waitangi uses the word `Tauiwi' instead of `Pakeha'. For example a section of the booklet is headed `Partnership between Maori and Tauiwi'. Tauiwi, according to the booklet's glossary, means `later settlers from another country'. A Dictionary of the Maori Language ... gives `strange tribe, foreign race' as the meaning of Tauiwi.

As a New Zealander born and bred in this country I was disturbed at the unceremonious use of a word which seems to make me some sort of foreigner in my own land. ... On phoning the commission's office I was informed that despite considerable unease over the use of Tauiwi in the treaty booklet staff were told that it had to be used. I was also informed that the use of Tauiwi instead of Pakeha had been discontinued
Notes:

This [=?, or copy of treaty] instrument I consider to be <I>de facto</I> the treaty, and all signatures that are subsequently obtained are merely testimonials of adherence to the original document.

Date:  2/1/1847
Source:  Wellington Spectator
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Though by no means faultless, the measure [1846 Constitution Act] seems calculated to be a fair opening to the true history of our great Southern Colony, after the preliminary chapters of tragi-comic blundering. It sweeps away the whole system of official machinery and self-impeding sophistry established by Lord Stanley - all the `Treaty of Waitangi' nonsense, and all the past Downing-Street plans for hindering the settlement of the islands.' Henceforward, echoed the Colonial Gazette, `the humbug treaty of Waitangi' would be `very properly laid on the shelf'.




Notes:  1847 Jan 2 Wellington Spectator in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 149

Date:  21/6/2002
Source:  Dominion
Author:

Treaty trout
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: (humorous, for trout illegally taken)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1938
Source:  Brown Man's Burden
Author:  FINLAYSON
Vol / Page:  22
Edition:  1973
Quote:  The sport turned out to be spearing trout. ... Seeing Henry's wonderment, Moses gave him a sly dig in the ribs. `These the treaty trout,' he grinned. `Waitangi, you know, the Maori own all the fish for ever. God bless the Queen!'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1973
Source:  Brown Man's Burden
Author:  FINLAYSON
Vol / Page:  136 [note 11 to p.22]
Edition:
Quote:   `treaty trout'. A reference to the widely-held belief in a clause of the Treaty of Waitangi, signed in 1840 between Governor Hobson and some of the Maori chiefs, which ostensibly guarantees to Maoris the right to hunt and fish for as long as they wish in the country of which they gave sovereignty to Queen Victoria, the queen Moses blesses. Recent historical research shows that the supposed clause is not present in the Maori text that was signed, though it occurs in some of the variant English versions. ... In any case Maoris have not been exempt from laws restricting fishing and hunting.
Notes:

tree avalanche
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/1/1992
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  92
Edition:
Quote:  I find that the drowned trees had

probably come from what the Fiordlanders

call a tree avalanche. Because Fiordland

was so thoroughly gouged by glaciers,

there is virtually no topsoil on the


steeper valley sides. Even the fully-

grown forest has only the precarious hold

of a woven skin of roots that stretch

over rock. This net has a weak grip and

if one section tears free it can peel the

forest from the cliff-faces in great

strips. The fall of just one tree can

trigger a tree avalanche.

Quote:  The great uncoiling fronts [of the mamuku] are thickly clothed with dark brown scales ... It is these scales which gave the name black tree-fern in contradistinction to the name silver tree-fern given to the ponga (Cyathea dealbata) with its silvery-undersided fronds.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1969
Source:  Standard Common Names for Weeds
Author:
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  <i>black tree fern [=] mamaku [s] </i>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Plant Life in Maoriland
Author:  CROOKES
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:   ... we can be sure that the beauty-loving soul of the ancient Maori delighted whole-heartedly in these lovely inhabitants of the New Zealand bush. However, his interest in the different tree ferns was certainly not purely aesthetic. Take, for instance, the mamaku, or `black tree fern'

(<i>Cyathea medullaris</i>). This is one of the largest and most handsome of all our tree ferns. It can be distinguished by the black stalks of the fronds and the leaf scars that form a definite pattern all round the slender black stem.
Notes:

Quote:  ko[o]hutuhutu, an irregularly-growing tree (<i>Fuchsia excorticata</i>), tree-fuchsia: more commonly ko[o]tukutuku, but ko[o]hutuhutu adopted to avoid possible confusion with ko[o]tuku, white-heron. Very often called konini, but konini is the berry of kohutuhutu, edible if rather insipid.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author:  BURTON
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  Other berries popular as delicacies were the fleshy, white,  pineapple-shaped bracts and berries of the kiekie (<i>Freycinetia banksii</i>), the ripe, black berries of the makomako or wineberry

(<i>Aristotelia serrata</i>) and the small, sweet berries (known as  konini) of the kotukutuku or tree fuchsia (<i>Fuchsia excorticata</i>).

Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:

Citations
Date:  13/5/1844
Source:  Diary
Author:  TUCKETT
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Beyond the bush land, that which is called grass land chiefly produces a very cutting wiry species, very similar to that which in swamps we call tree grass, but without the stem or trunk on which the former is elevated above the water surface; these plumes of grass on this dry land in burning diffuse a fragrant and aromatic odour, ...
Notes:  1844 May 13 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 220

Date:  16/8/1844
Source:  Diary
Author:  TUCKETT
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  ... the prevailing species of trees are remo [rimu], totara, and tall manuka, all indicative of inferior soil.... The bush-like woods on the east side are of white birch, likewise no recommendation of the soil, but the chief objection to the district is, that the prairie soil affords scarcely any food for cattle ... it grows only the wiry tree grass [tussock] ... and

<I>Phormium tenax</I> [flax], no aniseed, perennial groundsel, or milk thistle, and very little couch grass. <I>? Carex secta (Niggerhead) </I> ... [Andersen notes:] Tuckett saw a grass, `a very cutting wiry species, very similar to that which in swamps we call tree grass, but without the stem or trunk on whic h the former is elevated above the water surface; these plumes of grass on this dry land in burning diffuse a fragrant and aromatic odour, but as food for cattle they are valueless.' HCE, p. 220. - Dr. D. Munro called this the grass-tree, speaking of `grass-tree swamps.' HCE, p. 245.
Notes:  1844 Aug 16 Tuckett's Diary in 1898 Hocken contributions 223-224

tree lucerne
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Chamaecytisus palmensis. A small quick-growing tree, native to the Canary islands but naturalised in NZ.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: tagasaste
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim writes: Both <i>tree lucerne</i> and <i> tagasaste</i> are recorded in Macquarie 1981 (there classified as <i>Ch. prolifer</i>) but not in any other dictionary I have seen. It is interesting that there is no reference to this tree in Guthrie-Smith's <i>Tutira</i>. Its naturalisation at least in Hawke's Bay is thus likely to be later than 1939.

Author:
Vol / Page:  55/144
Edition:
Quote:  <i>ma[a]nuka</i>, a shrub (Leptospermum scoparium), commonly called tea-tree, because Cook's people used the fresh young leaves infused for tea; but very often mis-spelt ti-tree - ti being something totally different, the cabbage tree (Cordyline). The tree-manuka is kanuka, with smaller leaves and smaller flowers than the scrub-manuka, and it is the kanuka that is usually sold for firewood.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1982

Author:  BURTON
Vol / Page:  31
Edition:
Quote:  Supplies of tropical fruits were curtailed because of the Japanese threats to the sea lanes, and tamarillo (or tree tomato as they were then known) growing began in earnest. [WWII] <i>Ibid.</I> 141 New Zealanders always used to know the tamarillo by the rather uninspired name of `tree tomato', but after the fruit became a big export business in the 1960s, the growers decided to change the name to the far more appealing `tamarillo', in 1967.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page:  821
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tree-tomato</i> tamarillo.
Notes:  [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 512]



Date:  0/4/1991
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  58
Edition:
Quote:  Although it sounds Spanish, the name ‘tamarillo' is another New Zealand invention. The former name ‘tree tomato', was considered inappropriate for use overseas where people buying the fruits for the first time might expect them to taste like tomatoes. In 1967, orchardist Bill Thomson took the Maori word ‘tama' added ‘tillo' (taken from tomatillo, a complete unrelated Mexican fruit) and then (just to make the sound more mellifluous) he replaced ‘t' with an ‘r'. Thus, ‘tamarillo' was born.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1893
Source:  Australasian Fruit Culturalist, The

Vol / Page:  II/423
Edition:
Quote:  Tree Tomato. - The plant known

under this name is Solanum betaceum

(Cyphomandra betacea), a tall evergreen

shrub or small tree, which sometimes

attains a height of twenty feet. It is

indigenous to Central America.

like a hare's foot, are very characteristic.

trefoil

Citations
Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HILGENDORF
Vol / Page:  105
Edition:  1967
Quote:  SUCKLING CLOVER (<i>Trifolium dubium</i>) was formerly named <i>T. minus</i>. Alternative common names are yellow suckling clover and little trefoil. it is common in pastures throughout all the sown grass lands and even where no sowing has taken place. Its seeds pass unharmed through sheep, and are therefore scattered wherever sheep can travel.

Trekka
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: New Zealand's only locally designed and mass-produced motor vehicle
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Citations
Date:  31/12/2001
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  8
Edition:
Quote:  "I took a Trekka down to the phonebox - I ran out of petrol - to send a telegram on behalf of the Mt Eden Committee."... The Trekka became known as  "the poor man's Land Rover", and many an unfortunate motorist made the mistake of treating their Trekka as if it were a Land Rover, and came to grief when attempting to tackle rough terrain... Even so, the maker found it necessary to suggest to new Trekka owners that "if the engine fails to start ... a push start may be sufficient."

Date:  13/11/2004

Notes:

Date:  27/5/2003
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  A10
Edition:
Quote:  Four "arts ambassadors" from public galleries will spend six weeks working as attendants at the New Zealand exhibition, <i>This is the Trekka</i>, at the 50th Venice Biennale of Art.
Notes:

Date:  7/4/2001
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  65
Edition:
Quote:  Yes, yes, that ruffled bikini looks fetching, and you've got to love those surfboards, but the star of the picture is the Trekka - a forgotten New Zealand design classic... It's a brilliant story, New Zealand's only locally designed and mass-produced motor vehicle, the Trekka, was the brainchild of Noel Turner, a millionaire who supported Labour. The first Trekka rolled off his assembly line in Otahuhu ion 1966. It came in two colours... It had a four cylinder engine, and took 11 gallons in the tank... Turner's formula was a Skoda mechanical kit, bought at basement prices from Czechoslovakia, bolted to a simple boxy body.
Notes:

Date:  22/6/2003
Source:  Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine)
Author:
Vol / Page:  26
Edition:
Quote:  Stevenson has transformed the church into an Iron Curtain-style trade fair exhibition, taking its cue from the Trekka, the only New Zealand-designed and mass-produced motor vehicle, which was based on mechanical components from then-communist Czechoslovakia... The Trekka was the ultimate product of a mnyriad of import restrictions in the 1960s, designed to foster motor vehicle assembly in New Zealand. It was loved by those who admired it's [sic] cheap no-nonsense style as a Land Rover lookalike...  "The Trekka is a way of repsenting the idea of New Zealand as an industrialised state, an example of what New Zealand in those days could become"...

Date:  0/0/1956

Vol / Page:  218
Edition:
Quote:  WAREHOU <i>Seriolella brama</i>(Gunther) In Otago, commercial and sport fishermen, auctioneers, retailers, consumers of fish and readers generally have for many years been giving the name Trevally

(Usacaranx lutescens) to small Warehou up to twelve inches in length. It is to be hoped that this misnomer will continue to be replaced by the proper name of Warehou.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1957
Source:  Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
Author:  PARROTT
Vol / Page:  65
Edition:
Quote:  The Warehou is a southern fish becoming less plentiful in the North Island. It is known as the Trevally, and sold under this name, in Dunedin and Christchurch. It is an excellent food fish, and is always in good demand. It is also found in Australia where it is known as the `Whario' a corruption of the Maori name Wharehou, and in Tasmania it is sold as `Snogtail' Trevally. <I>Ibid.</i> 170 Warehou Seriolella brama Trevally; Sea Bream

Quote:  <i>WAREHOU (a) Scientific name: <i>Seriolella brama</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Sea Bream; Bream. (c) Other common names: None known, except that in southern waters this species is sometimes called Trevally. (d) Principal localities where taken: Cook Strait; Nelson; Greymouth. ... The Spotted Warehou, <i>Seriolella punctata</i>, taken in very small quantities, is usually counted in with the warehou catch.

Date:  0/0/1898

Vol / Page:  478
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Trevally,</i> or <i>Trevalli,</i> or<i> Trevalla</i>, or <i>Travale, n.</i> an Australian fish. In various localities the name is applied to several fishes, which are most of them of the family <i>Carangidae</i>, or <i>Horse-Mackerels.</i> An Old-World name for the Horse-mackerels is <i>Cavalli</i> (Ital. <i>cavallo</i>, a little horse). ... The Maori name for the <i>Trevally</i> is

<i>Awara<i> [sic, ?Arara[sic]], and in Auckland it is sometimes called the <i>Yellow-Tail</i> (q.v.). See also quotation, 1886. Gunther says, the genus <i>Teuthis</i> is readily recognised by the peculiar structure of the ventral fins, which have an outer and an inner spine and three soft rays between.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  234
Edition:
Quote:  TREVALLY (ARAARA) <I>Usacaranx lutescens</I> (Richardson) For some unknown reason small Warehou sold on the Dunedin Fish Market and in the shops of Dunedin were called Trevally and the same fish with the same markings when grown to eighteen or twenty-four inches in length were known as Warehou. Just how and when these small Warehou received the name Trevally no one seems to know. .../ [T]he old time Maori was recognised as a student of Nature and much more observant than the Pakeha, who blindly follows other and called fish by all sorts of names without ever stopping to think - as for instance when they call Seaperch the John Dory. Each fish is totally different. The misuse of common names of fish in New Zealand is most glaring but the mistake of calling the young Warehou by the name of Trevally is not made in the North Island, as both species are caught there; only odd Trevally are caught south of Cook Strait.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1958
Source:  Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn)

Vol / Page:  421
Edition:
Quote:  <I>trevalli </I>An Australian and New Zealand edible fish; the name is Australian.

Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  [index to common names 283-293] trevally [TS] 1348-90, 2180, 2192 trevally, school 1387 and a series of black spots on the flanks ... [lost from a cit??] TREVALLIES 1347-96
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  PAUL
Vol / Page:  86
Edition:
Quote:  The trevally belongs to a large family (Carangidae) containing fishes variously known as jacks, trevallies, jack or horse mackerels, scads, and pompanos. ... <i>Trevally Caranx georgianus </i>... Known simply as trevally in New Zealand, being the only species present; called white or silver trevally in southern Australia ... Our trevally was known for a long time as <i>Caranx lutescens,</i> and distinct from though obviously related to an Australian species. In 1974 it was recognised that there was a single somewhat variable Australasian species, <i>Caranx georgianus </i>(for a while <i>Usacaranx</i>), which took this name by historical precedence.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1902
Source:  Nature in NZ
Author:  DRUMMOND & HUTTON
Vol / Page:  74
Edition:
Quote:  Most of the food fishes here are caught all the year round, but the king fish, the barracouta, and the trevally leave in the winter.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1906
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  38/550
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Caranx georgianus</i>, Cuvier. The trevalli is a common fish in the harbour.
Notes:  (Thomson, Otago)

Dr. Hector says: `The trevalli is the arara of the Maoris, or trevalli or cavalli of the fishermen.' <i>Ibid.</i> 99 [quoting Hector <i>op. cit</i>.] Trevalli or cavalli of the fishermen ... In Auckland it is sometimes called yellow-tail, but this name appears to be also used for the king-fish. The fish known as trevalli in the Dunedin market is a different fish, allied to the warehou. [<i>Neptonemus brama</i>]

Quote:  A Maori tribe is an exceedingly indefinite entity, and so also is `hapu' a word primarily signifying pregnancy, but commonly used to signify having descended from one ancestor of later date than the original ancestor of the tribe.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1949
Source:  Coming of the Maori, The
Author:  BUCK
Vol / Page:  36
Edition:
Quote:  The great migration (heke) from Hawaiki is the most famous event in Maori history, because all the tribes trace their aristocratic lineages back to the chiefs of the voyaging canoes. <i>Ibid.< /I> 333 The smallest sociological unit is the biological family, which the Maoris termed

<i>whanau,</i> derived from <i>whanau</i>, to give birth . ... The term <i>hapu </i>(pregnancy) was used to denote this expanded family group for it expressed the idea of birth from common ancestors ... The term <i>iwi</i> (bone) was brought into current use to include all the <i>hapu</i> descended from common ancestors and thus related to each other by a blood tie. To denote the groupings in English, the

<i>iwi</i> has been termed tribe and the <i>hapu</i> a sub-tribe.[check???]
