tribute
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: (mining)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1952
Source:  Faring South
Author:  LYON
Vol / Page:  168
Edition:
Quote:  As the quartz mines began to decline in output and could no longer pay a large wage sheet, it became the custom to let them on tribute, by which parties of men were given the right to mine and raise quartz from the resultant crushing, of which a proportionate share of the gold went to the company. This system might also apply to old workings of mines in actual work, but in most of these cases the tributors followed a thin but valuable lead, which might not be much thicker than a finger, but so rich as to be worth tunnelling or working as a tribute, in which the golden lead was pursued on an upward slope. It used to be rather shrewdly suspected that tributors were not `working on the blind' but had as former employees of the company marked a lead and covered the same by a piece of mine timber or rubble till a later date give them the chance to profit by their knowledge. Many of the tributors did exceedingly well; they had nothing except their labour to lose, and the company got some profit on a good lead, and so `where's the harm?'
Notes:

Date:  9/11/1972
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  And yet in June, 1928, right in the middle of the rising tide of production, the Paparoa Coal Company was forced, for financial reasons, to lay off 85 men and close the mine.

Their offer to allow the mine to be worked under tribute (which it was for several years) was bitterly opposed by the unions which claimed that the co-operative system meant the speeding of production at the expense of conditions, and that the people working in co-operative systems were little concerned about the conditions that had been built up through industrial organisation and effort over a long time.
Notes:

Date:  8/4/1918
Source:  Grey River Argus
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  After being worked for a preiod [sic] on tribute, mining operations ceased, but the right to the valuable water race was kept intact.

Quote:   The critics will no doubt note that <i>to oozle</i> and<i> to trickle</i>, which denoted much slower modes of locomotion, were comparatively little [30] used, and will not be surprised that Wellington trampers are sometimes afflicted with<i> perspidrip</i>, or describe themselves as <i>jagged. Jagged</i> (one syllable), worn out by exertion, exhausted, no doubt has some relation to the English dialect <i>on the jag</i>, a drunken spree, and the American <i>jagged</i>, tipsy, and also owes something to<i> jiggered.</i>
Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

trier

Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: one who perseveres in the face of difficulties; one who is always ready to give things a go; an active or vigorous worker; the coll. use orig f. racing slang (cf STARTER), of a horse that loses after fighting to win a race [cf AND a racehorse which is being ridden to win] e.g. in NZ

Quote:  SMOOTH LEATHER JACKET or TRIGGER-FISH <i>Allomonacanthus convexirostris </i>(Gunther) The smooth Leather Jacket, sometimes known as Spotted Leather Jacket, like the following species, Rough Leather Jacket, belongs to the Family of Trigger-fishes, so named from the large trigger-like spine on the back. <i>Ibid.</I> 374 ROUGH LEATHER JACKET, TRIGGER-FISH or FILE-FISH (KOKIRI) <i>Parika scaber</i> (Bloch and Schneider)

In other countries members of this genus are called Trigger Fishes, from the power ... of suddenly erecting the stiff spine on the back ...

Date:  0/0/1866

Author:  SHERRIN
Vol / Page:  58
Edition:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1928
Source:  Natural History of Canterbury
Author:  SPEIGHT
Vol / Page:  202
Edition:
Quote:  Our final group is the PLECTOGNATHI, a small assemblage of fishes of unusual form generally brought about by exceptional growth of the head. In the Leather jackets or Trigger fish <i>(Cantherines convexirostris)</i> the anterior dorsal fin is reduced to a couple of spines, the first of which is very large and is the characteristic `trigger'.
Notes:  1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 202

Date:  0/0/1938
Source:  TrRSNZ
Author:
Vol / Page:  68/418

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Marine Fishes
Author:  MORELAND
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:
Quote:  LEATHERJACKET [<I>Navodon scaber</I>] ... The names filefish and triggerfish are sometimes used, but more properly belong to a related group of tropical fishes. The Maori name kokiri is still in use.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  33
Edition:
Quote:  <I>LEATHERJACKET </I>(a) Scientific name: <I>Navodon scaber</I>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Creamfish (fillets); Leatherjacket. (c) Other common names: Triggerfish; Filefish. (d) Principal localities where taken: Auckland, Tauranga, Tasman Bay.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  261
Edition:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  128
Edition:
Quote:  <i>you're a trimmer!</i> a compliment or a curse; from English word `trimmer', a person who literally thrashes, meaning performs vigorously. Shepard example: `The key is stuck in the keyhole. You think you've jiggered it. Along comes your fix-it cobber and all's well. Gee, you say. You're a trimmer.' Shepard example two: `What did you move that for? I had them in the right order. Gawd, you're a trimmer.'

trimmings
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: esp of meals at hash-houses or pie-carts, with the usual extras (sc. fried onions, tomatoes, etc with grills (chips were not considered trimmings but a concomitant of the grill); peas and mashed potatoes with meat pies)

Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1945 Wellington A pie with trimmings is one with peas and mashed potatoes, and perhaps sauce. ca1950 Wellington hash-house Do you want steak and trimmings (sc eggs, onions)

Notes:  1897 McKee Wright Station Ballads `Shearing' in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 33

Date:  0/0/1938
Source:  High Country
Author:  BURDON
Vol / Page:  84
Edition:
Quote:  The sheep they shore were not so well woolled on the belly and carried less wool on the points than they do now, so that fewer short blows were required to take off the trimmings; but the shears they used were one inch and a half shorter in the blade and, being joined by a single instead of a double bow, required a wrist of iron to drive them continuously throughout a summer's day. A piece of raw hide known as a knocker is now used to prevent the shears clashing when closed, but before this was introduced the clack and snap of steel meeting steel was a noise inseparable from any busy shearing shed.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1949
Source:  High Country Days
Author:  NEWTON
Vol / Page:  51
Edition:
Quote:  Broom in hand, the fleecie would dash back down the board to sweep up the `locks' and `trimmings'.

Date:  0/0/1960
Source:  Memories of Maoriland
Author:  SCRYMGEOUR
Vol / Page:  49
Edition:
Quote:  Reaching the end of the walk, and things just going fair, he returned and again said to the tall Moree Myall, `You are still cutting too often - go easy,' but the light limbed Australian continued to strip the `Basil' from the unfortunate stud ewe he was shearing. Standing by, the Moree native engaged in taking off the trimmings around the udder, then deliberately swept the glistening steel of his razor shears across the teats of the stud ewe, and deliberately shore them off level with the belly line.

Citations
Date:  0/9/1958
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  For shelter, hillmen may seek a <i>trog</i>, a large overhanging boulder or bluff giving shelter like a cave. These are most likely to be found in the south-west of the South Island, so presumably the term

originated with those who frequent those parts. <i>Troglodyte,</i> a race or tribe dwelling in caves, suggests the origin. The word has been known to trampers for eight or nine years.
Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

Date:  19/4/1971

Vol / Page:

Homonym Number:

Sense Number:
Definition: a (reputedly or apparently loose) woman (?f. trollop and <i>moll</I>) =prostitute, a trollop spg occas. <i>trol, trull</i>, indicating both NZ pron of <i>u + l,</i> and an uncertainty of derivation cf also TRULL [?move trull cits here]

Pronunciation:

trolley
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a four-wheeled cart; a boys' go-cart, push-cart, or billy-cart
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: aka trolly; ca1920 R. Mason Auckland and Pukekohe  R. Mason notes that when the <i>soap-box derby</i> was introduced from the US after WW2, the name quickly changed to <i>trolley derby</i>.

Vol / Page:  8

Quote:  Foxchase is experiencing a bad “trot,” which went a further stage at Riccarton on Saturday.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  115
Edition:
Quote:  <i>trot </iluck, usually in `bad trot' or `good trot', mostly sport use; probably from two-up game, where a trot is a sequence of heads; eg `It's ages since I had a decent trot.' - <i>on the trot</i> a sequence, often a winning one, more usually picking a succession of horse race winners nowadays. - <i>do a trot</i> have a good run of luck. <i>trot</i> a woman, perhaps desired, as used by Gordon Slatter; probably a lightening of English word `trot', whore; c.1925.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1900
Source:  NZ Farmer
Author:
Vol / Page:  Supplement.
Edition:
Quote:  A & P Conference vii Resolution 46 which had been proposed by Timaru. 'That in the opinion of this Conference bogus bidding or 'trotting' at auction sales is detrimental to owners of stock and land.' Mr Roberts said that trotting was hard to detect. (Bogus bidding, known as white bonnetting in Scotland.)

trout

Notes: kokopu		General and unspecified.  -->1903 TrNZI 35/314 The upokororo appears to inhabit clear running streams ..., and I believe that the large fish locally called `trout', which were sometimes cast up on the beaches of the great inland lakes of Otago in the early days before trout were introduced, also belong to this species.

Date:  2/4/1964

Author:
Vol / Page:  9
Edition:
Quote:  [British and European true sea trout member of Salmon family (salmon trout) has never been seen in NZ waters] What are commonly referred to as sea trout or sea-run trout in NZ are brown trout that have taken to feeding in salt water for greater or lesser periods, entering the estuaries of rivers periodically, also running up farther to spawn. These fish acquire a coating of silvery scales, which can be rubbed off, exposing rhe brown trout markings underneath .... No rainbow trout has ever been recorded as having been taken from salt water ...
Notes:  [Letter from Ered M. Banks, Wanganui]

trucking dog
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a specially trained sheep and cattle dog kept by a truck driver of livestock [for "working" stock while loading and unloading.]


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  1/2/1930
Source:  NZ Farmer
Author:
Vol / Page:  172
Edition:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Loughnan Glossary
Author:  LOUGHNAN
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  trucking dog: a specialist dog kept by the driver of a lorry which carts livestock, and used whilst loading and unloading his crate. Undoubtedly such dogs become the most agile of all backing dogs and they quickly learn just exactly how tight or loose the dividing pens should be packed. They also need to be versatile enough to work cattle.
Notes:

Vol / Page:  25

true dink(s)
Homonym Number:
Word Class: exclamation
Sense Number:
Definition: a shortened form of true dinkum (see dinkum, dinky die) used esp. by children to express or reinforce agreement
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1935 Havelock schoolboys' e.g. I'll bring the comic back tomorrow, true dinks.

trump of the dump
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: (WW1) anyone in authority
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1935
Source:  Slang Today
Author:  PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page:  287
Edition:
Quote:  His offsider said `Give a man a fair go', so I gave him a bit of kidney pie and there was nothing lousy about him, but he said he had to be careful because the other fellow was the trump of the dump. ... Although, he said, he was the white-haired boy with the trump he was due for a shake-up and he had to take a tumble to himself as to how he gave the company-rations away. ... It's the offsider I'm talking about because he winked at me when the trump of the dump asked him if he had barbered the spuds for tomorrow's breakfast.
Notes:  1935 A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge Slang Today 287

Date:  2/4/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  18
Edition:

trumpeter
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an edible sea-fish of the south of New Zealand and southern Australia.

Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  49
Edition:
Quote:  <I>TRUMPETER </I> (a) Scientific name: <I>Latris lineata</I> . (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Striped Trumpeter. (c) Other common names: None recorded. (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier southward; Cook Strait; Foveaux Strait.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  265
Edition:
Quote:  TRUMPETER <I>Latris lineata</I> : Deep brown in colour on sides and back, with a yellowish belly; the brown is streaked with three, wide, whitish lines from the which the description `lineata' derives. The Maori name `Kohikohi', means `to gather here and there' and perhaps refers to the fact that a fisherman is unlikely to catch more than three or four at one time.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Guide

Notes:  (Henry)

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  480
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Trumpeter, n.</I> (1) A fish of Tasmanian, New Zealand, and Australian waters, but chiefly of Hobart <I>Latris hecateia</I>, Richards., family <I>Cirrhitidae</I>, much esteemed as a food-fish, and weighing sometimes 50 or 60 1bs. The name is probably for the noise made by the fish when taken out of the water. The name was formerly given to a different fish in Western Australia. See also <I>Bastard-Trumpeter, Morwong,</I> and <I>Paper-fish. ... </I>
Notes:

Dr. Hector wrote last year: `The trumpeter (<I>Latris hecateia</I>), which is the Tasmanian name for this fish, and which the Natives call kohikohi, is one of the best flavoured of any of our fishes, and though abundant, is so extremely local in its habits, remaining continually on certain patches of feeding-ground, ...

Date:  0/0/1892
Source:  NZ Official Handbook
Author:
Vol / Page:  167
Edition:
Quote:   Of the sea-fishes that are used as food in New Zealand, we have among the constant residents on all parts of our coast the hapuku, tarakihi, trevally, moki, aua, rock-cod, wrasse, and patiki; and while the snapper, mullet, and gurnet are only met with in the north, the trumpeter, butterfish, and red-cod are confined to the south.

Date:  31/5/1861
Source:  Daily Southern Cross

Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  "I forgot to mention in my remarks on Stewart's Island, that all its harbours abound in fish such as can not be equalled in any other part of New Zealand or the colonies, either for quality or variety. They comprise black cod, groper, rock cod, trumpeter, barracouta, perch, ling, congie [sic] eel, whiting, white fish, bastard trumpeter, skate, and plaice ..."
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2033
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Trump&#769;.et-er </I>(tr&ubreve.mp&#769;.&ebreve.t-&etilde.r),<i> n. Add. Bastard trumpeter (Zoö..l),</i> in Sydney, the fish <i>Latris ciliaris (called moki </i>in New Zealand); in Victoria and Tasmania, <i>Latris Forsteri</i>; in Melbourne, the morwong. -<i> Trumpeter perch. (Zoö.l.) </i>See MADO.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  259
Edition:
Quote:  BASTARD TRUMPETER <i>Latridopsis forsteri</i> (Castelnau) [ibid. 260] The Scientific name <i>Latris</i> means a rascal, hence the common name `bastard' ((Bastard Trumpeter).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  21
Edition:
Quote:  Bastard Trumpeter, n. a fish. See Morwong, Paper-fish, and Trumpeter. In Sydney it is <I>Latris ciliaris</I>, Forst, which is called Moki in New Zealand; in Victoria and Tasmania, <I>L. forsteri,</I> Casteln. [1883]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Marine Fishes
Author:  MORELAND
Vol / Page:  40
Edition:
Quote:  MOKI [<i>Latridopsis cliaris</i>] ... Known as bastard trumpeter in Australia; only the Maori name is used in New Zealand.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Guide
Author:  AYLING
Vol / Page:  246
Edition:  1984
Quote:  Five species [of trumpeter] are recorded from New Zealand but there appears to be some confusion regarding ... the bastard trumpeter <i>Latridopsis forsteri</i> and the copper moki <i>Latridopsis aerosa</i>. Though officially recognised, the bastard trumpeter appears to be identical to the young blue moki ... On the other hand the copper moki seems to be a valid species - although referred to here as <i>Latridopsis forsteri</i> <i>ibid.</i> 247 COPPER MOKI (Bastard trumpeter) <i>Latridopsis forsteri (Latridopsis aerosa)</i> ... The body is silvery with four fine zig-zag horizontal bands of pink or olive tinged pink along the back ... They are most abundant around Stewart Island and become progressively less common further north ...
Notes:

trunk

Definition:

Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1957
Source:  Canterbury Frozen Meat Company
Author:  MACDONALD
Vol / Page:  65
Edition:
Quote:  freezing was done for the first ten years [from c1882] by the cold air machines ...[66] The carcases were hung in the chambers, and the cold air was blown through kauri ducts or trunks at a temperature of minus 40[degree sign] Fahrenheit. The carcases, being relatively warmer than the air, always lost moisture to it; this formed snow which blocked the trunks, cutting down the air circulation and giving the `snow-men', who had to crawl through the trunks, a bad time in clearing them.
Notes:

try pot

Word Class: noun
Sense Number:

Quote:  This gave me good reaon to browse through a rather charming book called <i>New Zealand! New Zealand! In Praise of Kiwiana</i>, by Stephen Barnett and Richard Wolfe .. The passage reads: "More fondly recalled is the alliterative and now deceased TT2, the classic ice-block of the fifties and sixties and a mainstay of summer holidays for New Zealand children. While its name was no more meaningful than the American borrowing of 'popsicle' that has replaced it, it was ours .. Apparently there was no TT1." I think it's safe to assume that "TT2" comes from the Tip-Top brand name.

Vol / Page:  54

Quote:  In some other localities these young [smelt, <i>Retropinna</i>] are called tuarenga. The half-grown fish is termed tikihemi and the adult paraki. Certain races of fish have a broad silvery band running along the side; hence the term `silvery.' It is to be regretted that in Canterbury the term smelt is still used to apply to the minnow, <i>Galaxias attenuatus. .</i>

tuatara
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the only surviving representative of a group of reptiles which has otherwise been extinct for 100 million years, now found only on a few islands off New Zealand. [Maori]
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Environment
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: [Ma. <b>tuatara</b> ancient reptile(<i>spenodon punctatus</i>)] cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Mâori (1995) 273 (no macron).

Quote:  Stephens Island, where the queer creatures have their sanctuary, is something like 50 miles west of Plimmerton and there is no ferry service for tuataras.

Vol / Page:  412

Quote:  <i>Tuatini</i> is a species of shark, often taken ten feet long, it is very savage. The teeth were set in rows, and formerly used as knives for cutting up human bodies for the oven. <i>Ibid.</I> 626 Fam. <i>Cestracionidae</i>, represented by the <i>Tuatini,</i> whose teeth are set in blocks of half-a-dozen each, beginning with the largest and decreasing in size to the least,* it is probable that the <i>Cestracion Philippi</i> is also a visitor of the New Zealand seas.

tucker claim
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1953
Source:  Golden Bush, The
Author:  SUTHERLAND
Vol / Page:  97
Edition:  1963
Quote:  `The Jeweller's Shop' supported its owner generously and allowed him leisure and relaxation which his hard work entitled him to and exciting week-ends in the city that no `tucker' claim would have given him.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1974
Source:  Bright Fine Gold
Author:  HEINZ
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  <I>CLAIMS</I>Worthless claims or ground were called schicers or duffers. Those yielding up to [pounds]3 per week per man were known as `tucker' claims; up to [pounds]8 per week were known as `wages' claims; above [pounds]8 were known as `pilers'; the richest of all were known as `Home-ward-bounders.'
Notes:

Date:  2/1/1866
Source:  Colonist (Nelson)
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  .. and many claims, which would command a special report in the mining intelligence of the local papers in those districts, are abandoned or talked of as mere “tucker” claims in the Tokitika or Grey districts.
Notes:

Date:  4/9/1869
Source:  Tuapeka Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  Circumstances of this kind go to prove that the industrious prospector is sure of finding something worth his trouble, and at all events has a much better chance of a rise than the steady worker in a mere tucker claim.
Notes:

Date:  4/2/1887
Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  22
Edition:
Quote:  To my question to one party relative to the payable nature of the ground or otherwise, I received the following impromptu reply, "Not much good, only tucker claim, very poor," &c., &c.
Notes:

Date:  22/5/1873
Source:  Tuapeka Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  One or two claims in the gully contunue to pay the shareholders fair wages, while others are what the diggers call "tucker" claims.
Notes:

Date:  21/2/1895
Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  17
Edition:
Quote:  At the Wilson there are three or four payable alluvial claims on the terraces, while others are only tucker claims, the more so as water has been scarce for the last two months.
Notes:

Edition:
Quote:  After a few remarks about the West Coast being worked out, except as a tucker diggings, and about the good a new rush would do, the visitor goes on his way, and Bill resigns himself without a sigh to the prospect of being the sole inhabitant of the gully for the nest twelvemonths.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  West Coast Gold Rushes
Author:  MAY
Vol / Page:  107
Edition:  1962
Quote:  `The field', wrote a Waimea digger, `is what is usually termed `tucker' diggings ... there is gold everywhere, but it has been scattered with a sparing hand.'
Notes:

Date:  4/12/1873
Source:  Grey River Argus
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  Provisions are very dear, and men have to swag them over five miles, through a bad track, all crags and hills - and the returns from mining in the Bullock Creek, and the gullies of it are so small as to give it (the Haast) the name of a tucker diggings.
Notes:

Date:  15/7/1903
Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  86
Edition:
Quote:  Even at the best of times the gullies were only tucker diggings, and for every ton of alluvial there were ten tons of stones to be shifted.

Vol / Page:  5

Quote:  Let the <i>Invercargill Times </i> publish as a stern indisputable fact - th[a]t the present Switzer's is barely a tucker diggings.

tucker ground
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: OED:  6. [f. TUCK n.1 6 or v.1 10.] The daily supply of food of a gold-digger or station-hand; rations, meals; also, food generally, victuals: = TUCK n.1 6b. to earn or make one's tucker, to earn merely enough to pay for one's keep. Austral. and N.Z. slang.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
tucker ground
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: auriferous ground on which merely bare tucker can be made (cf wages ground; payable)

Quote:  <i>Tucker ground:</i> Poor ground, just rich enough to allow the miner to buy the necessities of life.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  West Coast Gold Rushes
Author:  MAY
Vol / Page:  244
Edition:  1962
Quote:  It was a matter of nice judgement. The digger recognized four classes of payable ground: `tucker ground' kept him in food with nothing to spare; a `wages claim' gave him a pound or two above living expenses; a `riser' was a rich claim; and a `piler' or `homeward bounder' the richest of all. Probably most of the `pilers' were beach-claims, where the leads were shallow and rich, the outlay small and provisions cheap because of easy access.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1865
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/46/2
Edition:
Quote:  The whole country has been prospected ... and ascertained to afford only very ordinary `tucker ground'.
Notes:

Date:  27/3/1865
Source:  Otago Daily Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  The whole country has been prospected for months, if not years, and ascertained to afford only very ordinary "tucker-ground."


Notes:

Date:  20/1/1892
Source:  Southland Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  This is abundantly proved by the testimonials which have been received from time to time, which in some instances afford striking evidence of the changes wrought in the productiveness of the soil by the application of the latest thing in plough, drill, or harrow, causing areas that were formerly, in digger parlance, only "flash tucker" ground, to yield a harvest equal to the most fertile.

Date:  0/8/1962

Author:
Vol / Page:  79
Edition:
Quote:  Tuere to the Maoris, hagfish to the [English].. and plain blind eels to you and me.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1855
Source:  Te Ika a Maui
Author:  TAYLOR
Vol / Page:  627
Edition:
Quote:  Fam. <i>Cyclostomi</i> has the<i> Tuere. (Heptatrema domberyii,)</i> found in Dusky Bay, and also in Cook's Straits, it is about two feet long, has several small feelers attached to the head, and a broad flat tail, the color [sic] is dark brown, and the body of uniform thickness; it is known as the mud eel and is remarkable for its power of emitting slime to such an extent as completely to envelop it.
Notes:

Others omitted are the tarakihi, or terakihi, the moki, the komutumutu (trevalli), the puhaiwhakarua (red-jacket), koiro (conger eel), tuere (blind eel), whai (skate), and the koekohe [sic] (trumpeter).

It was the home of the Nga Potiki, or Tuhoe people, also known as 'The Children of the Mist'.

Tuhoeland
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a name given by Elsdon Best to the Urewera and other neighbouring areas of ancestral Tuhoe lands
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1925
Source:  Tuhoe: The Children of the Mist
Author:  BEST
Vol / Page:  9
Edition:
Quote:  The bush which still covers the greater part of Tuhoeland is what an European bushman would term `light bush'. A sawmiller would not describe it as a `timber bush'. There is a good patch of timber at Te Whaiti, but elsewhere the timber trees ... are scattered, or in small clumps.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1929
Source:  Primitive Economics of NZ Maori
Author:  FIRTH

tui
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a glossy black native honeyeater with a tuft of white feathers at its throat, an excellent mimic. Prosthemadra novaeseelandiae
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: parson-bird
Pronunciation:
Notes: aka New Zealand blackbird, koko, mocking-bird, parson-bird, poe

Vol / Page:  2/597

Quote:  He has had a rough time of it surveying a block on the ranges up the Wai-o-hine in the Wairarapa [sic] .. Once [sic] .. they had nothing to eat but a tui and a more-pork .. They were stewing the two birds when a kuku-pa (bush pigeon) flew up and perched .. Bob shot it .. This is not exactly what the Britishers call `sport' - but there is more of nature about it than 30 gents in pink and tops .. waiting for a wretched little fox who, when he is killed, is not equal for culinary purposes to a more-pork. Once coming up the Waikato in 1851 your Uncle James got a pot-shot at a lot of parera (grey duck) ...
Notes:  (C.W. Richmond)

Another name is the <i>koko</i>, and the young bird is distinguished as <i>Pi-tui,</i> or <i>Pikari</i>. It is also called the <i>Mocking-bird. </i>

Date:  0/0/1838
Source:  New Zealand  (Polack)
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/108
Edition:
Quote:  Among the birds that distinguished themselves in this woodland concert, were the tui, or mocking-bird, the korimaku [a-acute], kohapiroa, and tiaki [a-acute]. The little restless piwakawaka [a2,a4-acute], a kind of thrush, who is incessantly hopping from twig to twig, put forth its single note. <I>Ibid.</I> 1/296

The <I>tui</I>, or mocking-bird, is best known to the stranger in the country. The natives vend these birds, in wicker cages, to their transient visitors : it is called tui, from the resemblance of its note to that sound.

Edition:  1870
Quote:  Then we crept softly up .. to have a good look at the Tui, or Parson-bird, most respectable and clerical-looking in its glossy black suit, .. and white wattles of very slender feathers .. curled coquettishly at each side of his throat, exactly like bands.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/147
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tui</i>, a bird (Prosthemadera novaeseelandiae), the most characteristic of the smaller Maori birds, kept by the Maori as a pet and by them taught to speak, it being an excellent mimic, and so by the settlers called the mocking-bird, shortened to mockie, and called parson-bird because of the two white curled tufts of feathers at its throat. Then, [check parson-bird inclusion - not in Journ Polyn Soc ref???] because some folk thought mockie was short for makomako, a name of the bell-bird (korimako) in some parts, some thought it was the korimako which was the mimic, and hence both birds have been called the mocking-birds.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.
Author:
Vol / Page:  176
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tui</i>: singing forest bird.

Date:  5/3/1988

Author:
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  The gate across the road into the Nga Hau e Wha Christchurch National marae is chained and double- padlocked. Behind the palisade fence the weeds are knee high. The whare nui is boarded up ... None of its carvings and tukutuku are in place and the carvings are still tapu. The whare wananga beside it, meant to house the kohanga reo, lies uncompleted, torn building paper flapping.

tukutuku
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a curse, particularly one directed towards a notable person.
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
Notes:
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  31/3/1852
Source:  New Zealander, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  .. and it is not uncommon to hear a chief complain that he has been shot at, when on explanation it appears that he has only been thus shot in effigy. This form of insult is called a "tapatapa," or "tukutuku."

Register:
Date:  0/0/1892
Source:  Proceedings RSNZ
Author:
Vol / Page:  25/397
Edition:
Quote:  Other peculiar uses of names were the <i> tapatapa </i> and <i> tukutuku </i>. To <i>tapa</i> anything was to give the name of a person to it, the effect of which was to put it, figuratively, into the keeping of the person named, after which any other person taking a liberty with it would be regarded as an insult to the person whose name had been so used.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1855
Source:  Te Ika a Maui
Author:  Taylor
Vol / Page:  94
Edition:
Quote:  Another way of obtaining revenge, was by cursing. To call any object by the name of a chief, and then strike or insult it, was regarded as a curse; this was tapatapa, or tukutuku.
Notes:

Citations
tumatakahuki
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: tukutuku pattern
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (from kiwianatown.co.nz) Tukutuku are intricately woven panels often found lining the walls of the Wharenui (meeting house).  These panels express ideas from Maori mythology, philosophy and history. The patterns displayed here are : Tumatakahuki (pattern either side) double/triple binding which ensures strength. Poutama (steps) has religious and educational connotations relating to levels of attainment. Roimata Toroa (albatross tears) denoting misadventure particularly to crops. Purapura Whetu (myriad of stars) relates to population and the peopling of a region.

Citations
Date:  23/11/2005
Source:  NZ Herald
Author:
Vol / Page:  B5
Edition:
Quote:  Vertical lines reference tumatakahuki, a procedure which binds the horizontal tukutuku rods in place - an analogy for the kind of frameworks required to maintain the Maori collective.
Notes:

tumatakuru
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: [Ma.] a prickly native shrub Discaria toumatou [commonly corrupted from the Maori tumatakuru to matagouri.]


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See: matagouri
Pronunciation:

Date:  0/0/1856
Source:  Diary
Author:  ROBERTS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Writing of the Waimea Plain in 1856: - `The ground was well grassed, but the speargrass was too plentiful. The pasturage was very good. There was a good deal of scrub in the bends of the Mataura known as `wire plant' (Olearia virgata). There were also manuka and koromiko. Maori-heads, a kind of grass tree about three feet high, abounded in the swamps, and in some we saw toitoi grass and raupo. We did not pass any cabbage trees to-day ... we proceeded slowly through tomatakuru scrub, speargrass, Spaniard, snowgrass, and other native grasses ... we camped in a bend with good feed at the Elbow and a swamp on one side. Maori cabbage abounded ...'
Notes:  1856 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 18

Author:  PYKE
Vol / Page:  1/iii/16-17
Edition:  (1889,1974)
Quote:  NOTE. - As I have no desire to mystify readers unacquainted with New Zealand flora, I append a brief description of the shrubs mentioned:- <i>Kowhai</i> - A papilonaceous flowering tree, of the <i>acacia</i> tribe. [17] <i>Bush-lawyer</i> - Native name, Tataramoa - A disagreeable bramble, very tenacious of grasp. <i>Koromiko</i> - A white flowering <i>Veronica. Tutu</i> - A berry-bearing, glossy-leaved plant, deadly to man and to all animals - except goats. <i>Tumata-kuru</i> - Better known as `Wild Irishman' - a thorny plant, very difficult to handle.

Author:  HAWKE & SCOTT

Edition:
Quote:  The tumbler sweep consisted of a number of teeth, perhaps up to a dozen, according to whether it was a one horse or a two horse sweep... It had two curved handles and often a board to sweep the hay off when the handles were released by the driver who walked [behind. When] the handles were released the sweep turned over completely and just carried on for the next load.

tumble-weed
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the dried flower-heads of <i>Scirpus frondosus,</i> pingao or nassella tussock
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: tumble weed, tumbleweed; definition not exclusive, some general use for seed heads that tumble along the ground in the wind.
Citations
Date:  1/8/1885
Source:  Poverty Bay Herald
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  Thus, a horse with caution, and a faculty for seeing everything he passes, having been startled by a piece of paper, or a tumble weed being blown under him or against his legs, may never get over shying at these particular objects.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1918
Source:  Pasture Plants & Pastures of NZ
Author:  HILGENDORF & CALDER
Vol / Page:  48
Edition:
Quote:  Nassella Tussock's ... seed heads break off when mature and are blown along the ground by strong winds. It is sometimes referred to as `tumble-weed' on this account.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1942
Source:  Maori Place Names
Author:  ANDERSEN
Vol / Page:  274
Edition:
Quote:  The globular, spiked flower-head [of the pingao] drops when the seed is mature and trundles along the beach in the wind ... The Pakeha name of such spherical flower-heads is `tumble-weed'. [Marginal pencil note on this copy: `spinifex'.]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/155
Edition:
Quote:  <i>pingao</i>, sea-shore plant (Scirpus frondosus), tumble-weed, after the stiff-spined globular seed-heads: the leaves, drying a bright-orange much used for plaiting ornamental girdles and for tukutuku[spg/hyphen???] (lattice-work) lacing in wall-panels of whares.

tumblewheel
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a hubbed wheel on six legs for feeding out and maintaining electric fence wire at the appropriate height. (invented 1980s by Taranaki farmer, Sandy Chesswas.).
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:

Citations
Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  9
Edition:
Quote:  <i>ALBACORE</i> (see also Tuna) (a) Scientific name: <i>Thunnus alaunga</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name: Albacore. (c) Other common names: Tuna, Tunny, long-finned albacore. (d) Principal localities where taken: Bay of Plenty, East Cape to Gisborne, North Taranaki Bight. <i><Ibid.</i> 49 <i>TUNA </i>(3 species excluding Albacore) (a) Scientific name: (i) <i>Katsuwonus pelamis</i> (ii) <i>Thunnus maccoyi</i> (iii) <i>Thunnus albacares.</i> (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Skipjack Tuna (ii) Southern Bluefin Tuna (iii) Yellowfin Tuna. (c) Other common names: (i) Skipjack; Striped Bonito (ii) Bluefin Tuna; Southern Bluefin; Southern Tuna (iii) Yellowfin All sometimes referred to as Tunny. (d) Principal localities where taken: (i) A summewr visitor to New Zealand ... (ii) Southern Bluefin Tuna is a large species of temperate Australasian seas and migrates south to Foveaux Strait in summer months. (iii) A widely distributed tropical species which ranges into northern waters ... in summer months.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Marine Fishes
Author:  MORELAND
Vol / Page:  52
Edition:
Quote:  STRIPED BONITO [<i>Katsuwonus pelamis</i>] ... Striped tunny or tuna, skipjack, bonito, and sometimes skipper, are alternative names in use.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  266
Vol / Page:  WILSON
Edition:
Quote:  TUNAS ... Tuna were generally known as `tunny' until the discovery of a potentially big export market to America, where tuna is rated a luxury fish. The name as then changed to conform with that used in America. Since then Southern Bluefin tuna, Yellowfin tuna and Striped, or Skipjack, tuna have been developed into important export fishes. In New Zealand the Albacore has become an important commercial fish.
Notes:

Date:  23/7/1986

Date:  0/0/1855
Source:  Te Ika a Maui
Author:  TAYLOR
Vol / Page:  413
Edition:
Quote:  New Zealand has no large fresh-water fish. The only exception is the<i> tuna</i>, or eel; there are many varieties of it, and almost all the other fresh-water fish partake more or less of a similar character. The number of names given to this fish, and the careful way they have noticed every little difference between one and another, clearly shows the great value the natives put upon it. <I>Ibid.</I> 498  The principal ones are the<i> tuna</i>, eel, the <i>pipiharau</i>, lamprey, the <i>kokopu,</i> and <i>inanga ... </I>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1882
Source:  Brighter Britain
Author:  HAY
Vol / Page:  2/151
Edition:
Quote:  In the bays and tidal rivers are the mango or sharks - the most highly-prized food-fish - the tamure or schnapper, the whapuka or rock-cod, the kahawai or mackerel, the porahi or herring, the kanae or mullet, the patiki or sole, and many others. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. In the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga).

Date:  0/2/2011
Source:  Wairarapa News
Author:
Vol / Page:  supplement: pukaha Mount Bruce p. 8
Edition:
Quote:  Today the eel population in the Wairarapa is under stress and none more so than the largest species - the majestic Tuna Kuwharuwharu.  Tuna Kuwharuwharu are one of New Zealand's most ancient inhabitatns but have decreased in number so rapidly that they are now nearing endangered status.    So it's extremely special to see a large number of female tuna kuwharuwharu being fed at Pukaha Mount Bruce which occurs daily at 1.30pm.

Quote:  <i>Gasterochisma melampus</i> Richardson. The `butterfly-fish', as it is called when young, has been taken in Otago Harbour, and is now known to be the young of the scaled tunny, described as <i>Lepidothynnus huttoni</i> Gunther.
Notes:  (Thomson, Otago)

Date:  0/0/1927
Source:  Natural History of Canterbury
Author:  SPEIGHT
Vol / Page:  199
Edition:
Quote:  The only true mackerels recorded from Canterbury are the Pacific Bonito (<I>Sarda chiliensis</I>) and the large-scaled Tunny (<I>Gasterochisma melampus</I>) which may reach a length of 6 feet; but a related family includes the well-known Barracouta (<I>Thyrsites atun</I>), the King Barracouta, <I>Jordanidia solandrii </I>(often known locally as Kingfish, but not to be confused with the North Island Kingfish which is a form or Yellowtail) and the elongated, silvery-hued frost fish (<I>Lepidopus caudatus</I>) whose curious stranding habits can hardly yet be said to be satisfactorily explained.
Notes:  1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 199

Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  9
Edition:
Quote:  <I>ALBACORE</I> (see also Tuna) (a) Scientific name: <I>Thunnus alaunga</I>. (b) Suggested commercial name: Albacore. (c) Other common names: Tuna, Tunny, long-finned albacore. (d) Principal localities where taken: Bay of Plenty, East Cape to Gisborne, North Taranaki Bight. <i>Ibid.</I> 49 TUNA (3 species excluding Albacore) (a) Scientific name: (i) <I>Katsuwonus pelamis</I> (ii) <I>Thunnus maccoyi</I> (iii) <I>Thunnus albacares</I>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Skipjack Tuna (ii) Southern Bluefin Tuna (iii) Yellowfin Tuna. (c) Other common names: (i) Skipjack; Striped Bonito (ii) Bluefin Tuna; Southern Bluefin; Southern Tuna (iii) Yellowfin All sometimes referred to as Tunny. (d) Principal localities where taken: (i) A summer visitor to New Zealand ... (ii) Southern Bluefin Tuna is a large species of temperate Australasian seas and migrates south to Foveaux Strait in summer months. (iii) A widely distributed tropical species which ranges into northern waters ... in summer months.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  266
Edition:
Quote:  TUNAS ... Tuna were generally known as `tunny' until the discovery of a potentially big export market to America, where tuna is rated a luxury fish. The name as then changed to conform with that used in America. Since then Southern Bluefin tuna, Yellowfin tuna and Striped, or Skipjack, tuna have been developed into important export fishes. In New Zealand the Albacore has become an important commercial fish.
Notes:

Date:  23/7/1986
Source:  Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:

Date:  0/0/1838
Source:  New Zealand  (Polack)
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/110
Edition:
Quote:  On emerging from Pamaki [a's-acute], we ascended another plain of some miles in circumference, covered with fern and bush, above which the tupakihi [a-acute], or native elder-berry, occasionally shewed its bending stem, yielding to the weight of the fruit, which hung in purple clusters. ... The natives, on perceiving me make use of this berry, warned me not to swallow any of the seeds, as the doing so would make me <i>ourangi</i>, drunk, or mad. <i>Ibid.</I> 2/134 The flexible tu pahihi [prob ?typo see 288] (elder berry) with its pensile clusters of ripe fruit ... <i>Ibid.</I> 1/288 The <i>korai, koutu utu, miro,</i> and <i>putuhutu</i>, are wild forest fruits, prized only by the elder natives. The <i>tu pakihi</i> (Coriaria sarmentosa), or elder-berry, is a very pleasing fruit.

So that `tupakihi,' the name by which the `tutu' is there known, appears to be a contraction of `tutupakihi,' or `tutu' of the [196] plains, which are well called `pakihi,' being for the most part arid.

Notes:

Date:  9/7/1910
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  These tracks twist in and out all over this lonely country, through the high fern and the glossy green tupakihi with its black clusters of elderberry-like fruit, and the thickets of manuka that in springtime are showered with delicate white blossom till they look as if a snowfall had powdered the face of the country, and diffuse an aromatic fragrance that is the most insistent of the grateful odours of the bush.

[fn]*(<i>NOTE</i>) A blue berry with poisonous seeds - whose juice however is wholesome, and delicious in flavour.

Notes:  (Hector Outlying Islands)

Date:  0/0/1884
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  17/216
Edition:
Quote:  The traveller who visits Stewart Island in December or January will have his attention arrested by the blaze of crimson presented by the rata (<i>Metrosideros lucida</i>), often flecked with the pale racemes of the kamahi (<i>Weinmannia racemosa</i>), the deep green leaves of the puheretaiko and the tupari (<i>Senecio rotundifolius</i> and <i>Olearia colensoi</i>), and the grass-like leaves of the inaka (<i>Drachophyllum longifolium</i>), all of which form a fringe of greater or less breadth at the water's edge, and (except the puheretaiko) often expand into large masses ascending to the crests of the hills.
Notes:  (Kirk)

tupuru
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:
Definition: sandals
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/11/2003
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 66/40
Edition:
Quote:   	Herries Beattie describes a different method: "This tussock was placed in the paraerae (sandal) and the foot inserted. Then the tussock was brought up the leg and tied above the ankle. This protection was called puru and the sandals were then known as tupuru." Patiti was also regarded as "a fine thing to put in the paraerae to keep the feet warm and if one was wading it was warmer with patiti around the feet than without it."
Notes:

turangawaewae
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the ability, conferred by belonging to a home-turf, to stand on one's own two feet; a strong homeland-based identity. [Maori turanga[u-macron] a standing + waewae foot]
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Notes:

Date:  21/8/2004
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  62
Edition:
Quote:  For the French, and almost all European winegrowers for that matter, wine is about the land, about a piece of dirt that is turangawaewae. And you can no more separate the land from the wine than you can call a Greek a Turk, or vice versa, which is why Europe is riddled with those convoluted wine regulations that read like a dialogue for a frustrated Homer Simpson - DO, DOG, AoC, VDQS, QmP, QbA! What all these mean is turangawaewae, the place that wine calls home, and there is only one.
Notes:

Date:  9/0/2002

Vol / Page:  62

Quote:  Although economic factors have helped to scatter the Maori people from their homelands, the majority of them see themselves as belonging to a tribe whose turangawaewae (place for the feet to stand) and whose ahi-ka (burning fire) are located at specific regions.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Towards Taha Maori
Author:  HOWE
Vol / Page:  23
Edition:
Quote:  Turangawaewae - this term refers to the ability to stand on one's own two feet because one belongs (see papakainga) to a piece of land which reflects one's history - one's identity. It combines therefore, the feeling of belonging and the idea of the place itself. If one loses one's papakainga, one has no turangawaewae.
Notes:

Date:  0/5/1987
Source:  Metro
Author:
Vol / Page:  70

There are eight commercial species in New Zealand : the sand flounder, yellowbelly flounder, greenback flounder, black flounder, lemon sole, common sole, brill and turbot.

Date:  8/12/1982
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  37
Edition:
Quote:  Closely related to the brill is the turbot, the largest New Zealand flatfish. It has a reddish-brown back with darker brown splotches and is found mainly on the west coasts of both the North and South Islands, although only about 20 tonnes is trawled annually... If it is any consolation, the turbot of northern waters is a slightly different species to ours, having its eyes on the other side of the head.

Author:  MEREDITH
Vol / Page:  21
Edition:
Quote:   ... we lived on the tender bleached ends of cabbage tree leaves, and the inner bark of the turipa tree, which is sweet and not unpalatable but not very satisfying.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1906
Source:  Manual NZ Flora
Author:  CHEESEMAN
Vol / Page:  632
Edition:
Quote:  <i>P[aratrophis] heterophylla, Bl.Mus.</i> ... NORTH ISLAND: ... <i>Turepo; Milk-tree</i>. ... Abounding in milky sap, which is said to be palatable.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1924
Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page:  7/186
Edition:
Quote:  In <i>Paratrophis Banksii</i> there is an example of a large-leaf form of the turepo, ot `milkwood' of the bushman. ... Growing in close proximity ... is <i>Sideroxylon costatum,</i> known to the Bay of Plenty Natives as `orewa', but given theless euphonious name of `tawaapu' by writers on the New Zealand flora.
Notes:  (Sladden)

Date:  0/0/1959
Source:  Early Travellers
Author:
Vol / Page:  37
Edition:
Quote:   ... a small tree ... about 15 feet high, with smooth cineraceous bark, solitary crimson fruit ... On cutting its bark, a profusion of thick, viscid milky juice gushed out. [fn] Presumably <i>Paratrophis heterophylla,</I> Turepo, milk-tree.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Maori Food and Cookery
Author:  FULLER
Vol / Page:  84
Edition:
Quote:  THE MILK-TREE (TUREPO) The turepo (<i>Paratrophis microphylla</i>) trunk will slowly exude a creamy sap if it is cut or bruised. The sap was used as a substitute for milk by early colonists.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author:  BURTON
Vol / Page:  20
Edition:
Quote:  Those pioneers who were without dairy cattle made a kind of `milk' from the creamy sap of the turepo or milk tree (<i>Paratrophis microphylla</i>).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Field Guide to Common NZ Trees & Shrubs
Author:
Vol / Page:  14
Edition:
Quote:  TUREPO (Milk Tree)/ <i>Paratrophis microphylla<>/I> / Tree reaching 12m. Bark whitish grey with noticeable breathing pores.
Notes:

Date:  10/8/2002
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  F14
Edition:
Quote:  For example, there have been no podocarps, rimu or matai or smaller species such as the intriguing Streblus heterophyllus, or Turepo, known to European settlers as the milk tree, because of the sweet milky sap they used in their tea.

Quote:  A dog that under pressure from sheep and backs off a little and turns right around, is said to turn tail. Turning tail shows first a lack of confidence in a young dog, and in an older animal, a lack of strength. If a youngster is let away with it, 'turning tail' will just become a habit.

Notes:

turner
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition:  a member of a harvesting-mill team who sets sheaves to be fed into the mill.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Aspiring Settlers
Author:  ANGUS
Vol / Page:  49
Edition:
Quote:  Each mill employed ten or thirteen men, three breaking down the stack, then a 'turner' who set the sheaves the right way for the 'feeder,' the man who had the skilled task of cutting the binding and letting the sheaves slide down his arm into the mill at an even rate.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Loughnan Glossary
Author:  LOUGHNAN
Vol / Page:  87
Edition:
Quote:  turner: he deposits each sheaf to the hand of the bandcutter, or the stacker - who very often works on hands and knees anyway.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  Knapdale Run, The
Author:  KERSE
Vol / Page:  148
Edition:
Quote:  The usual gang for stack threshing [c1900] was 12 men. The boss kept steam up and attended to the mill adjustments and lubrication, three men worked in the bag hole, the bag-rammer, the bag-sower, and the bag-carrier; two men were on top of the mill, a band cutter and a man to turn the sheaves to the band cutter: two men were on the stack forking to the `turner', and then there was the chaffy, two men on the straw stack, a builder and a straw `walloper' and last of all, the water joey. Threshing out of the stock required an even larger gang, usually about three more men.
Notes:

turning tail

Sense Number:
Definition: of a sheepdog, turning away from the sheep in a complete circle; failing to `face up' to the sheep all the time

Author:
Vol / Page:   23/306A
Edition:
Quote:  There are twenty-eight native species belonging to the genus <I>Odontria</I>, but all observers agree that the principal grass grub is <I>Odontria zealandica</I>. In the larval stage this is known as `grass grub,' `white grub,' or `curl grub,' and the adult stage is known as `grass grub beetle,' `brown beetle.' or `turnip fly.'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1943
Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page:  24/129A
Edition:
Quote:  Turnip-fly (<I>Odontria zealandica</I>): What is commonly referred to as `turnip-fly' is in reality the adult beetle <I>Odontria zealandica</I>, the common grass-grub beetle.
Notes:

Author:
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  The turnip fly, haltica nemorum, is a colcopterous insect, having four wings, two shorter than the others; and is one of the most destructive species, as they feed on plants, when the insects are in their larvae, and in their perfect state also.

Citations

Source:  Sheep.  Part 1, Sheep husbandry
Author:  STEVENS
Vol / Page:  86
Edition:
Quote:  The sloping surface which gives a slide in from the side of a bath, the tipping pen in which the floor moves from the horizontal to a steep angle, and the turntable pen, all have the common purpose of getting the sheep into the bath with a minimum of effort and with little risk of injury to the sheep.

turpentine
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: various shrubs or trees with aromatic leaves or resin
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: tarata
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1877
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  9 : 143
Edition:
Quote:  Turpentine - Pittosporum eugenioides. This is the largest of the mapau family; it sometimes attains a height of 40 feet, with a diameter of 24 inches. The bark is thin, and of a light colour; the leaves are silvery green, and the flowers pale yellow... The bark exudes a thick gum, and the juice of the leaves, which is somewhat similar, was formerly used by the Maoris as a perfume, but I fear it is too resinous for European tastes.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1890
Source:  PWD Catalogue of Timbers

Notes:  (?mainly East Coast, North Island)

Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Art Album NZ Flora
Author:  FEATON
Vol / Page:  34
Edition:
Quote:  PITTOSPORUM CRASSIFOLIUM (<i>Banks & Sol</i>.) ... The `KARO'.- This species is common on the coastline throughout the Northern Island ... In common with some of the other Pittosporads, it is known to the settlers as one of the `Turpentine' trees; which are probably so called on account of the gluten, in which the seeds in the capsule are immersed, emitting a peculiar odour, when expressed.
Notes:

The cultivation and tending of this tree [44] might be easily learned by the natives, and the produce would, probably, prove of great importance.

Vol / Page:  182
Edition:
Quote:  <i>DIANELLA NIGRA</i>. Turutu, blueberry, inkberry, or whistles thrives in lowland scrub, on clay banks, and along bush tracks. ... The reddish leaf-base leaves a yellow scar when broken ...; often it is folded into a tube so that skilful blowing can force air out in an ear-splitting whistle. Shining berries, ranging from palest grey to almost purple, or clean blue and white like old china, ripen in great numbers but they drop at a touch; ...
Notes:

Date:  3/10/1867
Source:  Southland Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  Few - especially runholders and others having a practical interest in those and similar improvements, and desiring to participate in the same - but must have felt that a great desideratum in Southland was the possession of some means by which the immense benefits above referred to might be rendered possible to be shared in by others without the large outlay hitherto entailed by the necessary expenses of tussocking, ploughing, &c., required previous to sowing the English grass; which expense on a large estate, was quite possible to those possessing the extensive capital which the company in question does, but just as likely to be a serious consideration to private individuals.

tussock
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: (collective) grassland of native tussock grasses. frequent early spg also <I>tussac</i>; also<i> tussuck</i>
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also nassella tussock, snowgrass
Pronunciation:
Notes: also nassella tussock, snowgrass 		includes 'the tussock', off the tussock,and 'in the tussock';  G.J.Griffiths notes: originally it meant a `tuft', `bunch', `hillock' and only later came in NZ to be transferred to the kind of vegetation that grows in that fashion; here shown Tuckett did not have `tussock' to use

Date:  0/0/1943
Source:  Pure Gold
Author:  HISLOP
Vol / Page:  116
Edition:
Quote:  Some of the lads made their bricks in what they called a pug ring, formed by driving the horses round in a circle as with the old-time chaffcutter, but Cecil made his on what they called a straight. A strip of ground about 30 yards long by four or five wide was scooped free of top soil, which was dumped on the garden nearby. It was then ploughed about ten inches deep, or according to the number of bricks required, and very well watered, which was usually done with a shovel from a tank on a sledge for even distribution, and left to soak all night. A good layer of chopped-up tussocks was then evenly spread over the top. After more watering a six-horse team was driven up and down the strip until the pug was well mixed.
Notes:  [c1910, Otago]

Date:  0/0/1947

Date:  0/0/1973
Source:  NZ Alpine Plants
Author:  MARK & ADAMS
Vol / Page:  22
Edition:
Quote:  Some of the smaller tussock (<I>Poa colensoi</I>), alpine fescue tussock (<I>Festuca matthewsii</I>) and bristle tussock (<I>Notodanthonia asetifolia</I>), have become aggressive in this way. Bristle tussock now now dominates in parts of Marlborough and North Canterbury while the other two are more important in inland areas of South Canterbury and Otago.
Notes:

tussock
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: any grass which grows in clumps (`tussocks') rather than as a mat, esp. <i>Poa</i> and <i>Arundo</i> spp., and esp. in the high country
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: pl. often tussocks
Citations
Date:  30/12/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Tussock</i>.- Up-country people only recognise the small <i>blue t. (Poa colensoi) </i>and the common yellow, usually called white t. (<i>Poa caespitosa </i>) but sometimes <i>brown </i>. and sometimes <i>yellow </i> or silver. On the other hand, some men call the blue one <i>silver </i> (rare). <i>White t.</i> includes at least two varieties, a poa and a fescue (Festuca [novae-zealandiae]). The poa is a sign of good country and the fescue is not; but five shepherds out of six can't tell them part. The dreariness of the brown tussock plains seems to have been the first thing that struck every newcomer to Canterbury. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) `In the country far distant from town, my boy,/ All desolate, drear and alone,/ Some people exist among tussocks and sheep;/ And Brittan looks after his own.' --C.RH., p. 4(2)
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  0/0/1958

Author:
Vol / Page:  426
Edition:
Quote:  <I>tussock</I> A clump of grass. A grass that grows in clumps in many of the drier parts of New Zealand, especially in the South Island. The parts where it grows are called tussock country.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Flora NZ
Author:  MARTIN
Vol / Page:  129
Edition:
Quote:   The tussocks referred to are the SNOW TUSSOCK. <I>Danthonia flavescens</I> the RED TUSSOCK (<I>D rigida</I>), and in smaller amount (<I>D.cunninhamii</I>); and the `low tussocks' are chiefly the SILVER TUSSOCK (<I>Poa caespitosa</I>) and the FESCUE TUSSOCK (<I>Festuca novae-zelandiae</I>) or more rarely Poa colensoi, the BLUE TUSSOCK. The name `tussock' is applied to those tufted grasses which hold water in the decaying leaves at the base. Tall tussock is dominant in subalpine regions and low tussock in montane and lowland country, though in Southland the red tussock reaches sea level and dominates much of the landscape.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author:  TURNER
Vol / Page:  52
Edition:
Quote:  The term <I>tussock grass</I> has been formed from the English word <I>tussock</I> `a clump' (of grass) for a kind of grass which grew in clumps. The name ... was soon shortened to <I>tussock</I>, not merely a reversal of the initial process, since it is quite possible to talk of `a clump of tussock' in New Zealand.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author:  McLINTOCK
Vol / Page:  3/705-712
Edition:
Quote:  Tussock .. .. wi .. .. <I>Poa caespitosa </I>

Edition:
Quote:  It is an interesting and creditable publication, and that it meets a want is shown by the letters written by farmers who ask for advice upon such subjects as the burning of tussock country, how to treat and combat the grass grub, and also by the correspondence written by farmers concerning their experiments in growing various grasses for stock food.

These are termed by the colonists, nigger-heads.

Date:  0/0/1971
Source:  Centenary of Invercargill
Author:  WATT
Vol / Page:  8f
Edition:
Quote:  (caption) Early view of the south portion of the town ... The tussocks are noticeable. Their removal from street lines and sections provided work for contractors, who charged so much an acre for what was known as tussocking. <i>Ibid.</i> 64 ... among them `tussacing' - the removal of tussocks from streets and town reserves. It was some time before the town clerk came round to the spelling, `tussock' ... On February 26, 1874, the council called tenders for tussocking (so spelt) the remainder of the untussocked streets south of the Puni.-->

Quote:  European swaggers were sometimes known as "tussockies" because of their habit of tying the leaves of two tussocks together to form a simple shelter to sleep beneath.

tutae kehua / tutae whetu
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: basket fungus
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/12/1922
Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page:  5/247
Edition:
Quote:  <i>CLATHRUS CIBARIUS,</i> THE `BIRD-CAGE FUNGUS'. ... This fungus, known variously as `basket fungus,'`lattice fungus,', `Devil's purse,' <i>`tutae whetu,' `tutae kehua,'</i> belongs to the Phallaceae, a family included in the Basidiomycetes. It is found commonly throughout New Zealand during the late autumn and early spring. [Distribution.- Australia; Chile; ... New Zealand]
Notes:  (Cunningham)

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  485
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Tutu</i>, or <i>Toot, n</i>. Maori name for a shrub or small tree, <i>Coriaria ruscifolia,</i> Linn., or <i>C. sarmentosa,</i> Forst., of New Zealand, widely distributed. It bears greenish flowers, and shiny pulpy black berries. From these the Maoris make a wine resembling light claret, taking care to strain out and not to crush the seeds, which are poisonous, with an action similar to that of strychnine. It goes also by the name of <i>Wineberry-bush</i>, and the Maori name is Anglicised into <i>Toot.</i> In Maori, the final <i>u</i> is swallowed rather than pronounced. In English names derived from the Maori, a vowel after a mute letter is not sounded. It is called in the North Island <i>Tupakihi.</i> In Maori, the verb <i>tutu</i> means to be hit, wounded, or vehemently wild, and the name of the plant thus seems to be connected with the effects produced by its poison. To `eat your toot': used as a slang phrase; to become acclimatised, to settle down into colonial ways.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2033
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Tu&#769;.tu</i> (tu&#769;.tu; <i>colloq. t&omacr.&omacr.t</i>), n.<i> [Maori.] [Written also</i> toot.] <i>(Bot.)</i> A New Zealand shrub (<i>Coriarai ruscifolia</i>) of the order <i>Coriariae,</i> extremely poisonous to cattle. [Local, N. Z.]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1867
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  HOCHSTETTER
Vol / Page:  139
Edition:
Quote:  The toot-plant, tutu or tupakihi of the Maoris ... is a small bush, one of the most common and widely distributed shrubs of the islands. It produces a sort of `hoven' or narcotic effect on sheep and cattle, when too greedily eaten. It bears a fruit, which is produced in clusters, not unlike a bunch of currants, with the seed external, of a purple colour. The poisonous portion of the plant to man are the seeds and seed-stalks, while their dark purple pulp is utterly innocuous and edible. The natives express from the berries an agreeable violet juice (carefully avoiding the seed), called native wine.
Notes:   (Morris)

Date:  0/0/1869
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/III/34
Edition:
Quote:  (<I>Coriaria ruscifolia</I>, var). The plant known as Tutu, on the pasture lands of Otago, is a strong robust shrub 3-6 feet high, dying down to the ground every year. <I>Ibid.</I> 40 Tutu. Coriaria ruscifolia, Linn.
Notes:  (Buchanan Botany Otago)

Date:  0/0/1873

Quote:  The too-well-known `Toot' of the Otago farmer; the `Wine-berry shrub' of the early settlers of the Bay of Islands, (according to Dr. Bennett [`Wanderings in Australia'] and the `Treasury of Botany'); the `Tutu,' `Tupakihi,' and `Puhou' of the North Island Maoris; the `Taweku' of the Waikatos; the `Tupake' [a-macron, e-acute] of Coromandel district; the `Tua-tutu' of Otago, (Hooker). ... [`Tutu'] appears also to be a generic or general [term] ...

Date:  0/0/1891
Source:  NZ Country Journal
Author:
Vol / Page:  201
Edition:
Quote:  His hearty salutation in its faultiness proved to be about on a par with `rummy rum', `triddy', and `toot'. The last word reminds me of a man near by who was even judged to be somewhat vain of his Maori accent and pronunciation. With one word indeed he was very particular, he could not bring himself to use that manifest corruption `toot'. With him it was ever `tutu'. He had to make rather a boggle or dodge of it when he used the colonial made verb formed on his favourite Maori noun.
Notes:  (T.H. Potts, Morris)

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1908
Source:  My Simple Life in NZ
Author:  STEWART
Vol / Page:  27
Edition:
Quote:  [1879 Kati Kati] Our cow, a recent purchase, was found next day staggering about, wheeling round and round in a most alarming fashion. Luckily, a half-caste passing by saw her, and said, `Your cow is 'tutu'd'; give me a sharp knife,' and promptly bled her by cutting her ears, when she fell down exhausted, but did not die, as many of our cows did from time to time later on, when having eaten too greedily of a poisonous native plant `tutu.'
Notes:

Vol / Page:  E13
Edition:
Quote:  One of my favourites, now in flower at Otari Wilton's Bush, is the greenhood orchid, tutukiwi (Pterostylis banksii)... It stands erect (tutu- stand erect; tutukiwi - standing kiwi) up to 30 centimetres tall, has four to six narrow leaves and a magnificent green, hood-like flower up to five centimetres high.

Quote:   64. <i>Thinornis Novae-zealandiae</i>, Gml. Masked Plover, Sand Plover, Shore Plover, Tuturautu.[?tuturuatu check] pretty plover is ... seen in the southern part of this island fossicking about the sandy shores at the mouths of rivers.
Notes:  (T.H. Potts)

Date:  0/0/1888
Source:  Birds of New Zealand
Author:  BULLER
Vol / Page:  2/11
Edition:
Quote:  THINORNIS NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (NEW-ZEALAND SAND-PLOVER.) ... <i>Native names.</i>- Kohutapu and Tuturuatu.
Notes:  [1873 edn 214 called the NZ sand-plover]

Date:  0/0/1912
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  HERZ
Vol / Page:  352
Edition:
Quote:  The disregard of the external evidences of culture, is shown in the speech of the people. Sad to relate, one far too often hears the younger generation talk with a twang that horrifies the ear of anyone used to good English ... A mother will request her daughter <I>`Kyte</I>' to ask

the <I>`lydy'</I> whether she will<I> `tyke'</I> another piece of </I>`cyke'. </I>The vowels and diphthongs are so drawn and twisted that it is often difficult to recognise the King's English. ... This twang is worse in Australia than in New Zealand but is gaining ground here and ought to be strenuously eradicated by school-teachers, for it really does not sound nice, and robs sweet girlish lips of all their poetry.
Notes:

[29] Billy [a back-country farm-boy] always said `didjer' [did you], and ... as no one had ever taught him ... that well-known and useful little formula `How now, brown cow!' in order to correct his colonial twang and get his vowel sounds rounded correctly, ...

twin lamb disease
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: [used elsewhere, but recorded first in NZ] antepartum paralysis or sleepy sickness in ewes.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  1/9/1937
Source:  NZ Farmer
Author:
Vol / Page:  36
Edition:
Quote:  The troubles which are most likely to affect the ewes are (i) ante-partum paralysis, or as the farmer more frequently calls it, 'dopiness' 'twin lamb disease' or 'sleepy sickness' ...
Notes:

Date:  16/7/1945
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  37
Edition:
Quote:  The more correct name for antepartum paralysis or sleepy sickness, is pregnancy toxaemia (toxaemia meaning poison). It is also sometimes known as twin lamb disease, from the fact that in 95 per cent of cases the ewes is found to be carrying two or more lambs.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1964
Source:  Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock
Author:  MILLS ET AL
Vol / Page:  98
Edition:
Quote:  Twin lamb disease is another common name for this condition [sleepy sickness] as ewes carrying twins are most susceptible.

Vol / Page:  163

Quote:  The [Collins English] dictionary does not, however, contain entries for <i>DPB, EFTPOS, GST, CNG, first fifteen, street kids, May holidays</i>, and it is still too early for <i>orange roughy, night shelter,</i> and <i>Rogernomics, twink</i> and <i>lotto</i> (New Zealand-style) ...

twinkie
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a silvereye
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/159
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tauhou</i>, a wandering bird (Zosterops halmaturina), blight-bird; twinkie; button-eye; wax-eye; ring-eye. Tauhou means stranger and this name was given by the Maori when the bird appeared, in 1856, in the central part of Newzealand, gradually spreading north and south till the islands were occupied. It is an Australian bird, and was blown across the Tasman sea in the year mentioned.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  334
Edition:
Quote:  TWISTER <i>Helcogramma medium </i>(Gunther) The name Twister was given to this small fish for two reasons, (1) from the characteristically twisted or wavy markings on each side of the body, (2) from its amazing habit in captivity of eluding other fish, `twisting' and escaping capture when a larger fish was chasing it.

Date:  15/1/1913
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  120
Edition:
Quote:  Twitch is the name applied here to several grasses, as <i>Poa pratensis, Agrostis stolonifera</i>, and  <i>Agropyron repens</i>(the true couch or twitch). There is but one means of eradication--i.e., cultivation during summer and the careful cleaning of crops. The <i>Poa</i> and the <i>Agrostis</i> can be controlled with less effort than can the true couch. More than one season will be necessary to effect the eradication of this persistent weed.
Notes:

twitch
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also vbl n twitching
Pronunciation:
Notes: OED 6. vb draw tight by means of a cord (dial); check EDD
Citations
Date:  0/0/1950
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:  R. GILBERD
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The old method of tightening the chain securing the logs to trucks is called `twitching', or `taking a twitch'. First the chain is fastened leaving it quite slack. A lever is pased through the bight and used to twist the slack up on itself. When the chain is tight enough the end of the lever is tied to the chain. A `chain-rack' is now used - a giant Hayes wire-strainer. It is sometimes, but improperly, called a `twitch'. `Twitch' is probably an amalgamation of `twist' and `hitch'.
Notes:  Okaihau

Quote:  <I>two bastards on bikes</I> reaction of those betting two heads when two tails are tossed in gambling game `two-up'; <I>two ladies on bikes</I> if betting tails.

Quote:  <i>Two ladies on bikes.</i> The figure of Britannia on the obverse of the two pennies: two-up players', esp. New Zealanders': C. 20. I.e. when both turned up tails; the `heads' betters call them the <i>two bastards on bikes.</i>

two-and-a-buck
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: half a crown
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  14/1/1899
Source:  Sydney Bulletin
Author:
Vol / Page:   (Red Page)
Edition:
Quote:  Following are other local money-names... 2.6d <i>half-bull, half-caser or two-and-a-buck..</I>.
Notes:  (Letter from <i>Loafer</i>, Tauranga) [Bill Pearson]

Date:  0/10/1977
Source:  NZ Numismatic Journal
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  The crown was called a<i> bull</i>, a <i>cartwheel</i>, a <i>caser, five bob</i>, and most familiar of all a <i>dollar</i>, the latter dating from the time when the rate of exchange was four US dollars to the pound. The only instance recorded of Cockney rhyming slang term for a coin is <i>Oxford scholar,</i> the derivation from dollar being obvious.

The half crown was called a <i>half-dollar</i>, a <i>half-bull, half-caser</i>, <i>two-and-a-kick,</i> and <i>two-and-a-buck</i>. In the latter instance buck stands for sixpence, though apparently this term was rarely used by itself for that coin denomination, but almost always in association with a number of shillings. The florin seems to have had fewer English nicknames, only <i>two bob</i> being recorded as being in use in New Zealand.
Notes:

Homonym Number:

two-cut
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1955
Source:  Wool Away!
Author:  BOWEN
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  My advice to all is to concentrate on shearing to a pattern, keeping the comb on the sheep, watching yourself for `two-cut' and keeping it to a minimum. <i>Ibid.</I> 158 TWO-CUT. This happens where the staple of wool is cut above its base on the sheep, making it necessary for the handpiece to come back and trim off a short piece of wool that has been cut before. Such short pieces are of little value.

two-thirds of five-eighths of fuck all
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: nothing
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  116
Edition:
Quote:  <i>two-thirds of five-eighths of fuck all </i>very little; eg `What did you make at the races?' `Two-thirds of five-eighths of fuck all.' From the end line of the limerick:

<i>There was a young man from Bengal/ Who had an elliptical ball.

The square root of his prick/ Time seven-eighths of his grip

Was two-thirds of five-eighths of fuck all</i>.
Notes:

Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See: agri-forestry

Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Agriculture in NZ
Author:  RENNIE
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  Where trees are grown in conjunction with pasture for animals, this is called 'two-tier' farming or agri-forestry.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1996
Source:  Practical Smallfarming
Author:  FISK
Vol / Page:  44
Edition:
Quote:  ... blanket plant it [steep land] in trees, or plant it thinly and graze stock underneath. This is known as two-tier farming and experiments so far suggest you can run as many animals, and they will do as well, if there are up to 100 stems/ha.
Notes:

Edition:
Quote:  <i>two-tooth NZ & Austral.</i> sheep about one year old, with two permanent teeth.
Notes:  [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 518]

Date:  0/0/1987
Source:  Boards, Blades & Barebellies
Author:  OGONOWSKA-COATES
Vol / Page:  94
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Ages of sheep. </I>Although there are many variations, the following names are usually used: A sheep is a <I >lamb </I> until weaned. After weaning a lamb is called a <I> hogget </I> until shorn. A male lamb is a <I> ram lamb </I> until castrated, then a <I> wether </I>. A female lamb is a <I> ewe lamb </I>. After shearing, a ewe or ram lamb is usually called a <I> shorn hogget </I> until cutting the first two teeth. It is then called a <I> two-tooth </I>. Some use the term two-tooth as soon as the lamb is shorn. Next year the sheep is a <I> four-tooth, then a <I> six-tooth </I> and then an <I> eight-tooth </I> or <I> full-mouthed </I> sheep. It is full-mouthed as long as the teeth remain perfect but then becomes broken-mouthed and gummy.
Notes:

Date:  7/2/1855
Source:  Nelson Examiner
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  The sheep were two, four, and six-tooth ewes.

two-up
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a gambling game popular with shearers and mustering gangs in the early 1900s [simply comprising two coins being tossed and players betting on the chances of their both falling the same way.]

tyke
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a (usually Irish) Catholic probably a rhyme on Mike; cf MICK DOOLAN [AND tyke 1902: prob. an alteration of TEAGUE, a nickname for an Irishman]
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Bob Cotterall writes that the word, as referring to Catholics, was "In Auckland in common use round the 1900's, and came from the number of Yorkshire Catholics in  circulation. Very common in  referring to Catholic rugby teams. USE IN PRINT. Bishop Cleary was displeased on finding the sentence "...but Tykes came again" in a report of a rugby match that appeared in the SHC Magazine round about 1929, 1930, 1931 or 1932, and referred, in "<i>The Month</i>" to (I think) '..an unpleasant epithet. Anyhow, it's there, in  print, round about 1929-32 in the Sacred Heart annual mag." ca1930 W.H. Orsman

Citations
type
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: cf. odd-bod
Citations
Date:  14/6/1951
Source:  NZ Woman's Weekly
Author:
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:
Quote:  [Mount Ruapehu] Are you a `type' or an `odd-bod'? It was several days before I fathomed this out. The cry would go up, `Ruapehu types arriving, get cracking'. The best club cups would be sorted out, an official or prominent member would greet the new-comers, show them proudly over the house and dispense tea and hospitality with a cordial air. Then I'd hear, `Odd-bods coming up the track'. A member would supervise his arrival, see that no one entered the club room with nailed boots on, and offer a cup of tea, but there was not that ostentatious display of club china, `eats' and cordiality. I found that a `type' is a member of a recognised club and therefore someone to be treated with respect. An `odd-bod' is also a tramper or mountaineer, but of no specified breed, though entitiled to shelter. The same law holds for bush and mountain; hospitality must be dispensed for folk of the right ilk, so that the billy is always on the boil. But tourists! Well, I'd just hate to be a tourist! They were treated with loftiest contempt. I suppose I come under the heading `odd-bod', vouched for by a `type' ...
Notes:
